messages.content: What is the short title of the Act?
The Act may be cited as the Labour Relations Act 2005, as per section 1(1).
When does the Act come into operation?
The Act shall come into operation on such date as the Minister shall by notice published in the gazette, appoint, as per section 1(1).
Can the Minister defer the operation of parts of the Act?
The Minister may defer the coming into operation of any part or provision of this Act for a period not exceeding twelve months from the commencement date, as per section 1(2).
What happens to deferred provisions after twelve months?
The provision whose operation is deferred shall become operational on the date appointed by the Minister or after the expiry of twelve months whichever comes earlier, as per section 1(3).
What does section 1(2) say about the Act's title and commencement?
This Act may be cited as the Labour Relations Act 2005 and shall come into operation on such date as the Minister shall by notice published in the gazette, appoint, as per section 1(1).

What does section 1(2) say about the Act's title and commencement?
This Act may be cited as the Labour Relations Act 2005 and shall come into operation on such date as the Minister shall by notice published in the gazette, appoint, as per section 1(1).
To whom does the Act apply?
The Act applies to all employees engaged to work in Zanzibar and all employers who engage such employees, as per section 2(1).
Who is excluded from the Act's application?
The Act does not apply to Judges and all Judiciary officers, Members of Special Departments, and Employees of the House of Representatives, as per section 2(2).
Does the Act apply to Free Economic Zones?
The Act shall apply to the Free Economic Zones with such restrictions as the Minister in consultation with the Labour Advisory Board shall by regulation prescribe, as per section 2(3).
Do Parts I to VI apply to trade unions and employers organisations?
Unless expressly excluded, the provisions of Part I to VI of this Act apply equally to trade unions and employers organisations, as per section 2(4).

This Act shall apply to all employees, engaged to work in Zanzibar, as per section 2(1)(a).

How should the Act be interpreted?

Interpretation of this Act shall be made in a manner that will give effect to obligation of Zanzibar under various International Labour treaties to which the United Republic of Tanzania as a member State of the International Labour Organisation has ratified, as per section 3(1).
What is the definition of 'contract of employment' in the Act?

'contract of employment' any contract whether in writing or oral, whether express or implied, to employ or to serve as an employee for any period of time or number of days to be worked, or to execute any task or piece of work or to perform any journey and includes a foreign contract of service;, as per section 3(2).
What is the definition of 'Court' in the Act?
'Court' the Industrial Court established under this Act; 10, as per section 3(2).
What is the definition of 'employee' in the Act?

'employee' any person who has entered into or works under a contract of service with an employer whether by way of manual labour, clerical work or otherwise and whether the contract is expressed or implied or is oral or in writing, and shall include any such person in the employment of the Government or of any local authority or private sector or any apprentice and learner who has entered into or works under any agreement whether expressed or implied or whether oral or in writing;, as per section 3(2).
What is the definition of 'employer' in the Act?

'employer' any person, or any firm, corporation or company, public authority or body of persons who or which has entered into a contract of service to employ any person and includes the Government;, as per section 3(2).
What is the definition of 'employers' organisation' in the Act?

'employers' organisation' any association of employers the principal purposes of which are the representation of employers' interests and the regulation of relations between employers and employees, and includes a federation of employers’ organisation;, as per section 3(2).
What is the definition of 'essential service' in the Act?

'essential service' any service, whether rendered by the Government or any other body or person, the interruption of which is likely to endanger the life, health or personal safety of the whole or part of the population, and includes services mentioned under section 64(2) of this Act;, as per section 3(2).
What is the definition of 'executive' in the Act?
'executive' the body entrusted with the 11 management of the affairs of the trade union or employers' association;, as per section 3(2).
What is the definition of 'federation' in the Act?
'federation' any combination or association of two or more trade unions which have a separate legal existence from the trade unions of which they are comprised;, as per section 3(2).
What is the definition of 'labour dispute' in the Act?

'labour dispute' any dispute or difference between an employer or employers and employees, or between employees and employees, connected with employment or non employment, or the terms or employment, or with the condition of labour, of any person, or with the economic and social interests of workers;, as per section 3(2).
What is the definition of 'local authority' in the Act?
'local authority' and includes a city council, a municipal council, town council, local council and District council;, as per section 3(2).
What is the definition of 'lock-out' in the Act?

'lock-out' any action taken by an employer in contemplation or furtherance of a labour dispute which consist in the exclusion of a group of employees from a place of employment, the suspension of employment or work of a group of employees or a refusal to continue to employ a group of employees; 12, as per section 3(2).
What is the definition of 'Minister' in the Act?
'Minister' the Minister responsible for labour;, as per section 3(2).
What is the definition of 'official' in the Act?

'official' when used with reference to a trade union, includes any member of the executive committee thereof and any official of a branch thereof, but does not include a trustee or an auditor;, as per section 3(2).
What is the definition of 'register' in the Act?
'register' the register of trade unions maintained by the Registrar under section 15 of this Act;, as per section 3(2).
What is the definition of 'registered office' in the Act?
'registered office' that office of a trade union which is registered under the provisions of section 29 of this Act;, as per section 3(2).
What is the definition of 'Registrar' in the Act?

'Registrar' the person for the time being appointed by the Minister under the provisions of section 12(1) of this Act by name or by office to be or to act as Registrar of trade unions, and includes any person appointed by the Minister under section 12(2) of this Act to be or to act as an Assistant Registrar of trade unions; 13, as per section 3(2).
What is the definition of 'strike' in the Act?

'strike' the cessation of work by a body of persons employed, acting in combination, or a concerted refusal or a refusal under a common understanding of any number of persons employed to continue to work for an employer in consequence of a trade dispute, done as a means of compelling their employer or any person or body of persons employed, or to aid other employees in compelling their employer, or any persons or body of persons employed, to accept or not to accept terms or conditions of or affecting employment;, as per section 3(2).
What is the definition of 'the Government' in the Act?
'the Government' the Revolutionary Government of Zanzibar, and includes all departments and all services, whether autonomous or semi-autonomous; 14, as per section 3(2).

What is the official title of Act No. 1 of 2005?
The official title is the Labour Relations Act 2005, as stated in the preamble and Section 1(1).
When did the Labour Relations Act 2005 receive presidential assent?
The Act received presidential assent on 5th March, 2005, as indicated in the preamble signed by President Amani Abeid Karume.
Who enacted the Labour Relations Act 2005?
The Act was enacted by the House of Representatives of Zanzibar, as stated in the preamble.
What is the main purpose of the Labour Relations Act 2005?
The Act's purpose is to provide for the regulation of labour relations and dispute resolution between employers and employees and matters related thereto, as stated in the preamble.
How does the Labour Relations Act 2005 come into operation?
The Act comes into operation on a date appointed by the Minister through notice published in the gazette, as per Section 1(1).
Can the Minister defer the commencement of any part of the Act?
Yes, the Minister may defer the coming into operation of any part or provision of the Act for up to twelve months from the commencement date, as per Section 1(2).
When does a deferred provision become operational?
A deferred provision becomes operational on the date appointed by the Minister or after the expiry of twelve months, whichever comes earlier, as per Section 1(3).
To whom does the Labour Relations Act 2005 apply?
The Act applies to all employees engaged to work in Zanzibar and all employers who engage such employees, as per Section 2(1).
Which categories of persons are excluded from the application of the Act?
The Act does not apply to: (a) Judges and all Judiciary officers; (b) Members of Special Departments; (c) Employees of the House of Representatives, as per Section 2(2).
Does the Act apply to Free Economic Zones?
Yes, the Act applies to Free Economic Zones with restrictions prescribed by the Minister in consultation with the Labour Advisory Board, as per Section 2(3).
Do Parts I to VI of the Act apply to trade unions and employers' organisations?
Yes, unless expressly excluded, the provisions of Part I to VI apply equally to trade unions and employers' organisations, as per Section 2(4).
How should the Act be interpreted?
The Act should be interpreted in a manner that gives effect to Zanzibar's obligations under various International Labour treaties ratified by Tanzania as an ILO member State, as per Section 3(1).
What does 'award' mean under the Act?
An 'award' includes agreement reached after mediation, decision of arbitrator and decision of the Court following review of an award, as defined in Section 3(2).
What is a 'bargaining unit' according to the Act?
A 'bargaining unit' means the level at which collective bargaining is taking place, as defined in Section 3(2).
How is a 'branch' of a trade union defined?

A 'branch' means any number of members of a registered trade union who have appointed their own management committee according to the union's constitution but remain under the control of the executive committee and must contribute to general funds, as defined in Section 3(2).
What does 'Commission' refer to in the Act?
'Commission' means the Labour Commission established under the Labour Act, as defined in Section 3(2).
What is meant by 'constitution' in the Act?
'Constitution' means the constitution of a trade union or organisation, as defined in Section 3(2).
How is 'contract of employment' defined in the Act?

A 'contract of employment' means any contract whether in writing or oral, express or implied, to employ or serve as an employee for any period, to execute any task, or to perform any journey, including foreign contracts of service, as defined in Section 3(2).
What does 'Court' refer to in the Act?
'Court' means the Industrial Court established under this Act, as defined in Section 3(2).
What is the 'Court of Appeal' according to the Act?
'Court of Appeal' means the Court of Appeal of Tanzania, as defined in Section 3(2).
Who is the 'Director of Public Prosecutions' under the Act?
The 'Director of Public Prosecutions' means the Director appointed under the Zanzibar Constitution, 1984, including any authorized officer acting on that behalf, as defined in Section 3(2).
What is a 'dispute resolution authority'?
A 'dispute resolution authority' means mediator, arbitrator or Court whichever has authority in respect of a particular dispute, as defined in Section 3(2).
How is 'employee' defined in the Act?

An 'employee' means any person working under a contract of service with an employer, whether manual, clerical or otherwise, expressed or implied, oral or written, including government, local authority or private sector employees, apprentices and learners, as defined in Section 3(2).
What is the definition of 'employer'?

An 'employer' means any person, firm, corporation, company, public authority or body of persons who has entered into a contract of service to employ any person, including the Government, as defined in Section 3(2).
What constitutes an 'employers' organisation'?

An 'employers' organisation' means any association of employers whose principal purposes are representing employers' interests and regulating employer-employee relations, including federations, as defined in Section 3(2).
What is an 'essential service' under the Act?

An 'essential service' means any service whose interruption is likely to endanger life, health or personal safety of the population, including services mentioned in Section 64(2), as defined in Section 3(2).
What does 'executive' mean in relation to trade unions?
'Executive' means the body entrusted with the management of trade union or employers' association affairs, as defined in Section 3(2).
What is a 'federation' according to the Act?
A 'federation' means any combination or association of two or more trade unions with separate legal existence from their constituent unions, as defined in Section 3(2).
What is the 'Labour Advisory Board'?
The 'Labour Advisory Board' means the Board established under the Labour Act, as defined in Section 3(2).
Who is the 'Labour Commissioner'?
The 'Labour Commissioner' means the Commissioner appointed under the Labour Act, as defined in Section 3(2).
What constitutes a 'labour dispute'?

A 'labour dispute' means any dispute between employers and employees, or among employees, connected with employment, non-employment, terms of employment, conditions of labour, or workers' economic and social interests, as defined in Section 3(2).
Who is a 'labour officer'?
A 'labour officer' means a Labour Officer appointed under the Labour Act, as defined in Section 3(2).
What are 'local authorities' under the Act?
'Local authority' includes city council, municipal council, town council, local council and District council, as defined in Section 3(2).
What is a 'lock-out'?

A 'lock-out' means any employer action in contemplation or furtherance of a labour dispute consisting of excluding employees from workplace, suspending employment, or refusing to continue employing a group of employees, as defined in Section 3(2).
What is 'maintenance service'?
'Maintenance service' means a service whose interruption causes material physical destruction to any working area, plant or machinery, as defined in Section 3(2).
Who is the 'Minister' referred to in the Act?
The 'Minister' means the Minister responsible for labour, as defined in Section 3(2).
Who is considered a 'minor' under the Act?
A 'minor' means a person who has not attained the age of majority under the laws of Zanzibar, as defined in Section 3(2).
Who is an 'official' of a trade union?
An 'official' includes any member of the executive committee and any branch official, but excludes trustees or auditors, as defined in Section 3(2).
What does 'organisation' mean in the Act?
'Organisation' means employers' organisation, as defined in Section 3(2).
What is 'picketing'?
'Picketing' means a peaceful means in furtherance of a strike limited to dissuading others not on strike from continuing work, as defined in Section 3(2).
What is the 'register' referred to in the Act?
The 'register' means the register of trade unions maintained by the Registrar under Section 15, as defined in Section 3(2).
What is a 'registered office'?
A 'registered office' means the office of a trade union registered under Section 29, as defined in Section 3(2).
Who is the 'Registrar' under the Act?
The 'Registrar' means the person appointed by the Minister under Section 12(1) as Registrar of trade unions, including Assistant Registrars, as defined in Section 3(2).
What is 'replacement labour'?
'Replacement labour' means labour service engaged to replace labour service of employees participating in a strike, as defined in Section 3(2).
What is a 'representative trade union'?
A 'representative trade union' means a trade union recognized as representing employees in a bargaining unit, as defined in Section 3(2).
What constitutes a 'secondary strike'?
A 'secondary strike' means a strike undertaken by employees against an enterprise in which they have no interest, in support of employees of that enterprise, as defined in Section 3(2).
Who is a 'secondary employer'?
A 'secondary employer' means employer of employees supported by other employees through secondary strike, as defined in Section 3(2).
What is the definition of 'strike'?

A 'strike' means cessation of work by employees acting in combination, or concerted refusal to continue work, done to compel employer to accept or not accept terms of employment, as defined in Section 3(2).
What does 'the Government' refer to?
'The Government' means the Revolutionary Government of Zanzibar, including all departments and services, autonomous or semi-autonomous, as defined in Section 3(2).
How is 'trade union' defined?

A 'trade union' means an association of employees having among its objects representation and promotion of employee interests and regulation of employee-employer relations, including federations, but excluding employer-dominated associations and employers' associations, as defined in Section 3(2).
What is a 'tripartite committee'?
A 'tripartite committee' means a committee established under Section 78, as defined in Section 3(2).
What does 'Union' mean in the Act?
'Union' means a trade union as defined under the Act, as defined in Section 3(2).
What is the 'Unit' referred to in the Act?
The 'Unit' means a dispute handling Unit established under Section 72, as defined in Section 3(2).
Is there a short title provision in the Act?
Yes, Section 1(1) provides the short title as 'Labour Relations Act 2005'.
Does the Act have a specific commencement date?
No specific date is given; commencement is by Ministerial notice in the gazette as per Section 1(1).
Can the Minister extend the deferral period beyond twelve months?
No, the deferral period cannot exceed twelve months as per Section 1(2).
Are employees of local authorities covered by the Act?
Yes, employees of local authorities are included in the definition of 'employee' in Section 3(2).
Does the Act apply to apprentices?
Yes, apprentices are included in the definition of 'employee' in Section 3(2).
Are foreign contracts of service included in 'contract of employment'?
Yes, foreign contracts of service are specifically included in the definition in Section 3(2).
If an employee works for a company based in Dar es Salaam but is temporarily assigned to work on a project in Zanzibar for 3 months, does the Act apply to them?
Yes, the Act applies because Section 2(1)(a) states it applies to 'all employees, engaged to work in Zanzibar,' regardless of the employer's location or the temporary nature of the assignment.
A judge's personal driver who works exclusively for the judge wants to join a trade union. Can he do so under this Act?

The Act does not apply to Judges (Section 2(2)(a)), but this refers to the judge as an employer. The driver, as an employee, would likely be covered unless specifically excluded as working for the judiciary. The Act's application to judiciary employees needs clarification based on whether 'Judiciary officers' includes support staff.
If a trade union wants to challenge a Minister's decision to defer part of the Act, what legal principle guides the interpretation of such challenge?
Any challenge must be interpreted in a manner that gives effect to Zanzibar's obligations under International Labour treaties ratified by Tanzania as an ILO member State, as per Section 3(1).
Can a 16-year-old apprentice working in a Zanzibar hotel be considered an 'employee' under the Act?
Yes, Section 3(2) specifically includes 'any apprentice' in the definition of 'employee,' regardless of age, as long as they work under a contract of service.
A foreign company with operations in Zanzibar's Free Economic Zone wants to know if they can negotiate different labour terms than those in the Act. Is this possible?

The Act applies to Free Economic Zones with restrictions prescribed by the Minister in consultation with the Labour Advisory Board (Section 2(3)). The company must comply with whatever restrictions are prescribed, which may allow some variations.
During a labour dispute, workers stage a peaceful demonstration outside their workplace urging others not to cross their picket line. Is this 'picketing' under the Act?

Yes, this constitutes 'picketing' as defined in Section 3(2): 'a peaceful means resorted in furtherance of a strike which does not go further than dissuading others who are not taking part in the strike from continuing their work.'
An employer facing a strike hires temporary workers to continue operations. What is this practice called under the Act?
This is called engaging 'replacement labour,' defined in Section 3(2) as 'labour service engaged to replace labour service of employees participating in a strike.'
A trade union with members in both Tanzania mainland and Zanzibar wants to know if their Zanzibar branch must register separately. What does the Act say?

The Act applies to employees working in Zanzibar (Section 2(1)(a)). A 'branch' is defined in Section 3(2) as members who have their own management committee but remain under the executive committee's control. The Zanzibar branch would need to comply with Zanzibar's registration requirements if operating in Zanzibar.
If a mediator helps resolve a dispute and both parties sign an agreement, what is this agreement called under the Act?
This is called an 'award,' which under Section 3(2) includes 'agreement reached after mediation.'
A factory owner locks out workers during a wage dispute. What legal term describes this action?

This is a 'lock-out,' defined in Section 3(2) as 'any action taken by an employer in contemplation or furtherance of a labour dispute which consists in the exclusion of a group of employees from a place of employment.'
Workers at Hotel A go on strike in support of workers at Hotel B who are in a dispute with their employer. What is this called?
This is a 'secondary strike,' defined in Section 3(2) as 'a strike undertaken by employees against an enterprise in which they have no interest, in support of employees of that enterprise.'
A municipal council employee is dismissed and claims unfair dismissal. Which definition in the Act covers their employment?

The employee is covered by the definition of 'employee' in Section 3(2), which includes 'any such person in the employment of... any local authority.' 'Local authority' is defined to include municipal councils.
The Minister announces that Part V of the Act will not commence until six months after other parts. Is this permissible?
Yes, Section 1(2) allows the Minister to defer any part or provision for up to twelve months from the commencement date.
A trade union wants to know if verbal employment agreements are recognized under the Act. What does the definition say?
Yes, Section 3(2) defines 'contract of employment' as including contracts 'whether in writing or oral,' so verbal agreements are recognized.
An association of employers meets regularly to discuss industry standards but doesn't negotiate with unions. Is this an 'employers' organisation' under the Act?

To qualify as an 'employers' organisation' under Section 3(2), the principal purposes must include 'the representation of employers' interests and the regulation of relations between employers and employees.' If it only discusses standards without regulating employer-employee relations, it may not meet the definition.
A dispute arises about whether water supply workers can strike. What definition should be consulted?

The definition of 'essential service' in Section 3(2) should be consulted, which includes services whose interruption endangers life, health or safety, with specific examples in Section 64(2) including water services.
If a trade union's executive committee makes a decision, what legal term describes this body?
This is the 'executive,' defined in Section 3(2) as 'the body entrusted with the management of the affairs of the trade union.'
A group of trade unions form an association but maintain separate legal identities. What is this called?

This is a 'federation,' defined in Section 3(2) as 'any combination or association of two or more trade unions which have a separate legal existence from the trade unions of which they are comprised.'
During a dispute, parties agree to appoint a mediator. What authority does this mediator have?
The mediator would be a 'dispute resolution authority,' defined in Section 3(2) as 'mediator, arbitrator or Court whichever has the authority in respect of a particular dispute.'
A trade union treasurer wants to know which government official oversees union registrations. Who is this?
This is the 'Registrar,' defined in Section 3(2) as the person appointed by the Minister under Section 12(1) to be Registrar of trade unions.
Workers cease work together to pressure their employer on safety issues. What is this action called?

This is a 'strike,' defined in Section 3(2) as 'the cessation of work by a body of persons employed, acting in combination... done as a means of compelling their employer... to accept or not to accept terms or conditions of or affecting employment.'
A company wants to know if its contract with a self-employed consultant falls under the Act's definition of employment. What should they check?

They should check the definition of 'employee' in Section 3(2), which requires 'a contract of service.' Self-employed consultants typically work under contracts for services, not contracts of service, so they likely wouldn't be considered employees.
If the Minister issues regulations for Free Economic Zones, what consultation is required?
According to Section 2(3), regulations for Free Economic Zones must be made 'in consultation with the Labour Advisory Board.'
A dispute handling Unit is established. What is its proper title under the Act?
It is called the 'Unit,' defined in Section 3(2) as 'a dispute handling Unit established under section 72.'
Can a trade union composed of both Zanzibar and mainland Tanzania employees register under this Act?

The Act applies to employees working in Zanzibar (Section 2(1)(a)). A trade union with members in Zanzibar would need to comply with the Act for its Zanzibar operations, but the Act doesn't govern mainland operations.
If an arbitrator's decision is reviewed by the Court, what is the resulting decision called?
This is called an 'award,' which under Section 3(2) includes 'decision of the Court following review of an award.'
A worker is paid by piece rate for completing specific tasks. Are they an 'employee' under the Act?
Yes, Section 3(2) defines 'contract of employment' to include contracts 'to execute any task or piece of work,' so piece-rate workers are covered if they work under a contract of service.
What government entity represents Zanzibar in labour matters according to the Act?
This is 'the Government,' defined in Section 3(2) as 'the Revolutionary Government of Zanzibar, and includes all departments and all services, whether autonomous or semi-autonomous.'
If a trade union changes its name, where should this change be recorded?
This should be recorded in the 'register,' defined in Section 3(2) as 'the register of trade unions maintained by the Registrar under section 15.'
A committee with government, employer, and worker representatives is formed. What is it called?
This is a 'tripartite committee,' defined in Section 3(2) as 'a tripartite committee established under section 78.'
If a strike affects airport operations, what type of service is being affected?
This affects an 'essential service,' defined in Section 3(2), with air traffic control specifically mentioned in Section 64(2) as part of essential services.
A company wants to know if its casual workers are covered by the Act. What should they consider?

They should consider the definition of 'employee' in Section 3(2), which includes anyone working under a contract of service 'for any period of time or number of days to be worked.' Casual workers with contracts of service would be covered.
What happens if the Minister doesn't appoint a commencement date within twelve months of deferral?
Under Section 1(3), if no date is appointed by the Minister, the deferred provision becomes operational after the expiry of twelve months from the commencement date.
Can a trade union represent workers who are not its members in collective bargaining?
A 'representative trade union' (defined in Section 3(2)) represents employees in a bargaining unit, which may include non-members within that unit.
If maintenance workers at a power plant strike, what service are they affecting?
They are affecting a 'maintenance service,' defined in Section 3(2) as 'a service the interruption of which has the effect of material physical destruction to any working area, plant or machinery.'
Are members of the House of Representatives' security staff covered by the Act?
No, Section 2(2)(c) excludes 'Employees of the House of Representatives' without distinction, so security staff would be excluded.
What legal status does a registered trade union have for signing contracts?
While Part I doesn't specify, the definition of 'trade union' in Section 3(2) must be read with registration provisions that give unions legal capacity, as further detailed in later parts of the Act.
If a dispute involves interpretation of an international labour treaty, how should the Act be interpreted?
According to Section 3(1), the Act should be interpreted 'in a manner that will give effect to obligation of Zanzibar under various International Labour treaties' ratified by Tanzania.
Can a trade union's branch have a different constitution from the main union?

A 'branch' under Section 3(2) appoints its own management committee but remains 'under the control of the executive committee' and is bound to contribute to general funds, suggesting some autonomy within the main union's framework.
What happens if there's conflict between the Act's text and Tanzania's ILO obligations?

Section 3(1) requires interpretation 'in a manner that will give effect to obligation of Zanzibar under various International Labour treaties,' suggesting ILO obligations should guide interpretation where possible.
Is a verbal promise of employment considered a contract under the Act?
Yes, Section 3(2) defines 'contract of employment' to include contracts 'whether in writing or oral, whether express or implied.'
Can a minor serve on a trade union's executive committee?
A 'minor' is defined in Section 3(2), but Part I doesn't address committee eligibility. Later parts may restrict minor participation in executive roles.
What's the difference between 'the Government' and 'local authority' in the Act?

'The Government' means the Revolutionary Government of Zanzibar (Section 3(2)), while 'local authority' includes city, municipal, town, local and District councils (Section 3(2)). Both employ workers covered as 'employees.'
If workers strike in support of better safety standards, is this a 'labour dispute'?
Yes, Section 3(2) defines 'labour dispute' to include disputes 'connected with... the condition of labour,' which includes safety standards.
Can an employers' organisation be held liable for its members' actions under the Act?
Part I defines 'employers' organisation' (Section 3(2)) but doesn't address liability. Later parts establish the legal status and liabilities of registered organisations.
What is the minimum age for trade union membership according to Part I?
Part I doesn't specify minimum membership age, only defining 'minor' in Section 3(2) as someone below the age of majority in Zanzibar.
If a trade union doesn't register, can it still represent workers?
Section 3(2) defines 'trade union' to include associations 'whether registered or not,' suggesting unregistered unions exist but may have limited rights compared to registered ones.
Are workers in autonomous government agencies covered by the Act?
Yes, Section 3(2) defines 'the Government' to include 'all services, whether autonomous or semi-autonomous,' so their employees would be covered.
What is the full title and purpose of the Labour Relations Act No. 1 of 2005?

The full title is 'An Act to Provide for the Regulation of Labour Relations and Dispute Resolution Between Employers and Employees and Matters Related Thereto,' and its purpose is to regulate labour relations, resolve disputes, and handle related matters, as stated in the long title of the Act.
Who enacted the Labour Relations Act No. 1 of 2005 and who assented to it?

The Act was enacted by the House of Representatives of Zanzibar and assented to by Amani Abeid Karume, President of Zanzibar and Chairman of the Revolutionary Council, on 5th March, 2005, as per the enactment and assent clauses.
Describe the short title, commencement date, and any deferral provisions in the Act.

The short title is the Labour Relations Act 2005. It commences on a date appointed by the Minister via gazette notice. The Minister may defer any part for up to 12 months, after which it becomes operational automatically if not appointed earlier, as per section 1(1)-(3).
To which individuals and entities does the Labour Relations Act apply, and who is excluded?

The Act applies to all employees engaged to work in Zanzibar and their employers. It excludes Judges and Judiciary officers, Members of Special Departments, and Employees of the House of Representatives. It also applies to Free Economic Zones with restrictions prescribed by the Minister in consultation with the Labour Advisory Board, as per section 2(1)-(3).
How does the Act ensure compliance with international labour standards?
The Act must be interpreted to give effect to Zanzibar's obligations under International Labour treaties ratified by the United Republic of Tanzania as an ILO member state, as per section 3(1).
Provide a detailed definition of 'award' as used in the Act.
An 'award' includes an agreement reached after mediation, the decision of an arbitrator, and the decision of the Court following review of an award, as per section 3(2).
What is the comprehensive definition of 'bargaining unit' in the context of collective bargaining?
A 'bargaining unit' means the level at which collective bargaining is taking place, such as enterprise, sector, or national level, as per section 3(2).
Describe what constitutes a 'branch' of a registered trade union.

A 'branch' is any number of members of a registered trade union who, per the union's constitution, have appointed their own management committee but remain under the control of the executive committee and are bound to contribute to the general funds, as per section 3(2).
What does the term 'Commission' refer to in the Labour Relations Act?
The 'Commission' refers to the Labour Commission established under the Labour Act, responsible for various administrative functions, as per section 3(2).
Give a thorough explanation of the definition of 'contract of employment'.

A 'contract of employment' is any contract, whether written or oral, express or implied, to employ or serve as an employee for a period, number of days, task, piece of work, or journey, including foreign contracts of service, as per section 3(2).
What is the 'Court' established under this Act?
The 'Court' is the Industrial Court established under this Act to handle labour disputes and related matters, as per section 3(2).
Elaborate on the definition of 'employee' including all inclusions.

An 'employee' is any person who enters into or works under a contract of service with an employer, by manual labour, clerical work or otherwise, express or implied, oral or written, including government, local authority, private sector employees, apprentices, and learners under agreements, as per section 3(2).
What entities are included in the definition of 'employer'?
An 'employer' is any person, firm, corporation, company, public authority, or body of persons who enters into a contract to employ any person, including the Government, as per section 3(2).
Describe the purpose and inclusion in 'employers' organisation'.

An 'employers' organisation' is an association of employers primarily for representing employers' interests and regulating relations between employers and employees, including federations of such organisations, as per section 3(2).
What services qualify as 'essential service' and why?

An 'essential service' is any service whose interruption endangers life, health, or personal safety of the population, including those listed in section 64(2), to protect public welfare, as per section 3(2).
What is the 'executive' in the context of trade unions or associations?
The 'executive' is the body entrusted with managing the affairs of the trade union or employers' association, as per section 3(2).
How is a 'federation' defined for trade unions?
A 'federation' is any combination or association of two or more trade unions with separate legal existence from the component unions, as per section 3(2).
What broad range of issues constitute a 'labour dispute'?
A 'labour dispute' is any dispute between employers and employees, or among employees, connected with employment, terms, conditions, or economic and social interests of workers, as per section 3(2).
Detail the actions that define a 'lock-out'.
A 'lock-out' is employer action in a dispute excluding employees from work, suspending employment, or refusing to employ them, as per section 3(2).
Who is the 'Minister' referred to in the Act?
The 'Minister' is the Minister responsible for labour matters, as per section 3(2).
What is encompassed in the definition of 'minor'?
A 'minor' is a person who has not attained the age of majority under Zanzibar laws, as per section 3(2).
Describe who qualifies as an 'official' of a trade union.
An 'official' includes executive committee members and branch officials, but excludes trustees or auditors, as per section 3(2).
What is the 'organisation' in the Act's context?
'Organisation' means an employers’ organisation, as per section 3(2).
Explain what 'picketing' entails.
'Picketing' is peaceful action in furtherance of a strike to dissuade non-participants from working, without exceeding that, as per section 3(2).
What is the 'register' maintained by the Registrar?
The 'register' is the register of trade unions maintained under section 16, as per section 3(2).
Define 'registered office' for a trade union.
The 'registered office' is the office registered under section 29, as per section 3(2).
Who can be appointed as 'Registrar'?
The 'Registrar' is appointed by the Minister under section 12(1), including assistants under section 12(2), as per section 3(2).
Provide the detailed definition of 'replacement labour'.
'Replacement labour' means labour engaged to replace employees participating in a strike, as per section 3(2).
What makes a trade union 'representative'?
A 'representative trade union' is one recognised as representing employees in a bargaining unit, as per section 3(2).
Describe the concept of 'secondary strike' in detail.
A 'secondary strike' is a strike by employees against an enterprise where they have no direct interest, to support other employees, as per section 3(2).
Who is a 'secondary employer'?
A 'secondary employer' is the employer of employees supported by a secondary strike, as per section 3(2).
Elaborate on the definition of 'strike'.

A 'strike' is the cessation of work by employed persons acting in combination or refusing to work under common understanding in a trade dispute to compel acceptance or rejection of employment terms, as per section 3(2).
What does 'the Government' include?
'The Government' means the Revolutionary Government of Zanzibar, including all departments and services, autonomous or semi-autonomous, as per section 3(2).
Provide the full definition of 'trade union'.

A 'trade union' is an association of employees, registered or not, for representing employee interests and regulating relations with employers, including federations but excluding employer-dominated associations or employers' associations, as per section 3(2).
What is a 'tripartite committee'?
A 'tripartite committee' is a committee established under section 78, as per section 3(2).
Define 'Union' as used in the Act.
'Union' means a trade union as defined under this Act, as per section 3(2).
What is the 'Unit' referred to?
'Unit' means a dispute handling Unit established under section 72, as per section 3(2).
List and describe the basic employee's rights.
Basic employee's rights include forming unions, fair remuneration, safe conditions, equal opportunity, and protection from unfair dismissal, as per section 4.
How does the Act protect employees' freedom of association?
Employers cannot require non-membership, prejudice for union activities, or threaten regarding union involvement, as per section 5.
What are the basic rights afforded to employers?
Employers have rights to form organisations, participate in their activities, and engage in lawful lock-outs, as per section 6.
Describe protections for basic rights of employees and employers.
No discrimination for exercising rights or participating in proceedings under the Act, as per section 7.
How is a trade union protected against interference?
No coercion, interference with formation, or termination for union activities, as per section 8.
What provisions exist for federations?
Trade unions and employers' organisations may form federations, as per section 9.
Can organisations affiliate internationally?
Yes, with international workers' and employers' associations, as per section 10.
What remedies are available for infringement of freedom of association?
Court may order compliance, reinstatement, compensation, as per section 11.
Who appoints the Registrar and officials?
The Minister appoints the Registrar and other officials, as per section 12.
What protections do officials have?
Protected from liability for good faith actions, as per section 13.
Is registration mandatory for trade unions?
Yes, trade unions must be registered, as per section 14.
Detail the application process for registration.
Unregistered unions with min members apply within 6 months, as per section 15.
What is the register of trade unions?
Registrar maintains a register of unions and organisations, as per section 16.
How is registration conducted?
In prescribed manner, with certificate issued, as per sections 17-18.
Can the Registrar request more information?
Yes, may call for further particulars, as per section 19.
Under what circumstances can name alteration be required?
If name is similar or unsuitable, as per section 20.
What are grounds for refusal of registration?
If unlawful, fraudulent, or non-compliant, as per section 21.
When can registration be cancelled?
For violations or non-operation, as per section 22.
How can one appeal registration decisions?
Appeal to the Industrial Court, as per section 23.
What happens after cancellation of registration?
Loses legal status, cannot function as union, as per section 24.
Describe the legal status after registration.
Body corporate with perpetual succession, can sue/be sued, as per section 25.
What is the liability of members in registered organisations?
No personal liability for debts, as per section 26.
How is membership determined?
Per constitution, open to eligible persons, as per section 27.
What must be included in the constitution?
Matters in the Schedule, like name, purposes, elections, as per section 28.
Why is a registered office required?
For official communications and legal service, as per section 29.
Can unions have branches or affiliate?
Yes, as provided in constitution, as per section 30.
Describe the amalgamation process.
Two or more unions may merge with ballot approval, notice to Registrar, as per section 31.
What is the Federation of Tanzania trade union?
Unions may form or join such federation, as per section 32.
How are changes like name or amalgamation notified?
Notice to Registrar in prescribed form, as per section 33.
What is the effect of name change or amalgamation?
Continues as new entity with transferred rights, as per section 34.
What meetings must trade unions hold?
Per constitution, including annual general meetings, as per section 35.
How is dissolution handled?
Per constitution, with notification to Registrar, as per section 36.
What declaration is required upon dissolution?
Declaration of assets and claims, as per section 37.
Is gazette notification required for dissolution?
Yes, Registrar notifies in gazette, as per section 38.
How is property held and liable?
Vests in trustees, liable for debts, as per section 39.
What rules govern disposal of property?
Per constitution, with member approval if necessary, as per section 40.
What are permissible applications of funds?
Only for constitutional objects, as per section 41.
Why can't funds pay fines?
Prohibited to avoid misuse, as per section 42.
What books must be kept?
Proper financial records, as per section 43.
How are accounts prepared?
Annual audited accounts, as per section 44.
What are annual returns?
Submitted to Registrar with audited accounts, as per section 45.
What powers does the Registrar have over funds?
Can inspect and require information, as per section 46.
When can an injunction be sought?
To restrain unauthorised use of funds, as per section 47.
How is legal process served?
At registered office or on officials, as per section 48.
Can regulations be made for Parts I to VI?
Yes, by the Minister, as per section 49.
Describe trade union access to workplace.
Allowed for recruitment, meetings outside working hours, as per section 50.
How are union subscriptions deducted?
Employer deducts and remits upon written authorisation, as per section 51.
What is an agency shop agreement?
Non-members pay fees for benefiting from agreements, as per section 52.
Is leave granted for union activities?
Yes, reasonable paid leave, as per section 53.
Who has the right to collective bargaining?
Employees not in excluded categories, as per section 54.
What subjects can be bargained?
Any mutual interest matters, as per section 55.
At what levels does bargaining occur?
Enterprise, sector, national, as per section 56.
How is a representative union determined?
By majority membership or largest union, as per section 57.
Is information disclosure required?
Yes, relevant information for bargaining, as per section 58.
What is good faith bargaining?
Genuine effort to reach agreement, as per section 59.
Are collective agreements binding?
Yes, on parties and employees, as per section 60.
Must agreements be registered?
Yes, with the Commission, as per section 61.
What is a strike ballot?
Secret vote for strike authorisation, as per section 62.
What is the right to strike?
Employees have right after procedures, as per section 63.
What limits the right to strike?
Essential services, minimum services, as per section 64.
Can unlawful strikes be restrained?
Yes, by Court order, as per section 65.
What protection for lawful strikes?
No dismissal or prejudice, as per section 66.
Describe secondary strikes.
Support strikes with notice, as per section 67.
Is replacement labour allowed?
No, during protected strikes, as per section 68.
What is protest action?
For socio-economic interests, with notice, as per section 69.
What rules for picketing?
Peaceful, agreed or authorised, as per section 70.
Is intimidation prohibited?
Yes, during disputes, as per section 71.
What is the dispute handling unit?
Established for dispute resolution, as per section 72.
How are disputes filed?
To the unit in prescribed form, as per section 73.
Describe mediation process.
Mediator facilitates agreement, as per section 74.
What happens to unresolved disputes?
Go to arbitration or Court, as per section 75.
Can Court assist in mediation?
Yes, in certain cases, as per section 76.
What special proceedings exist?
For urgent or complex disputes, as per section 77.
What is a tripartite committee?
For specific resolutions, as per section 78.
Is representation allowed in mediation?
Yes, by authorised persons, as per section 79.
Describe the Industrial Court's establishment.
Established with jurisdiction over labour matters, as per section 80.
How is the Court composed?
Chairman and members appointed by President, as per section 81.
Who staffs the Court?
Appointed staff for administration, as per section 82.
Where and when does the Court sit?
As determined, in public or private, as per section 83.
What are the Court's functions?
Adjudicate disputes, review awards, as per section 84.
Can awards be backdated?
Yes, retrospective, as per section 85.
How are awards interpreted?
Court can interpret upon application, as per section 86.
Where do appeals go?
To Court of Appeal, as per section 87.
Are evidence rules strict?
No, not binding, as per section 88.
Can parties use lawyers?
Yes, right to advocate representation, as per section 89.
Are Court members protected?
Yes, from liability for good faith acts, as per section 90.
Are sittings public?
May be public or private, as per section 91.
Does the Court report annually?
Yes, to the Minister, as per section 92.
What is contempt of Court?
Offence punishable by Court, as per section 93.
Is there summary procedure for contempt?
Yes, for quick handling, as per section 94.
Are sitting allowances provided?
Yes, as prescribed, as per section 95.
Are there court fees?
Yes, as prescribed, as per section 96.
Who prosecutes offences?
Director of Public Prosecutions, as per section 97.
What are general offences and penalties?
Fines or imprisonment for violations, as per section 98.
Can the Minister make regulations?
Yes, for carrying out the Act, as per section 99.
What laws are repealed?
Previous Trade Unions Ordinance, with savings, as per section 100.
What are the basic rights of every employee under section 4(1) of the Labour Relations Act?

Every employee has the right to take part in the formation of a trade union or federation of trade unions, and to be a member of a trade union subject to its constitution, as per section 4(1)(a) and (b).
Can an employee participate in trade union activities during working hours?

Yes, every member of a trade union has the right to take part in lawful activities of the trade union outside working hours, or within working hours with the consent of the employer, as per section 4(2)(a).
Does a trade union member have the right to hold office in the union?
Yes, every member has the right, subject to the constitution of the trade union, to seek and hold office in the trade union of which he or she is a member, as per section 4(2)(b).
What rights do trade union members have regarding workplace representatives?

Members have the right to take part in the election of workplace representatives where provision is made for such election, and to be elected or appointed and serve as a workplace representative where provision is made for this, as per section 4(2)(c) and (d).
Are trade union members entitled to exercise other rights under the Act?
Yes, every member has the right to exercise any other right conferred by this Act, as per section 4(2)(e).
What rights do members of a trade union that belongs to a federation have?

Such members have the right, subject to the federation's constitution, to participate in its lawful activities, participate in the election of office bearers or officials, and stand for election and hold office if elected, as per section 4(3).
Can an employer require an employee not to join a trade union?

No, no employer or person acting on behalf of an employer shall require that an employee or person seeking employment shall not join or shall relinquish membership in a trade union or not participate in lawful trade union activities, as per section 5(1)(a).
Is discrimination against employees for trade union membership allowed?

No, employers shall not discriminate, take prejudicial action, or threaten dismissal against employees because of trade union membership, participation in lawful activities, exercise of rights under the Act, or participation in proceedings, as per section 5(1)(b).
Can an employer offer benefits to employees for not exercising rights under the Act?
No, employers shall not benefit, advantage, or promise advantage to employees for not exercising rights under the Act or for not participating in proceedings, as per section 5(1)(c).
Are contract terms that restrain rights under the Act valid?

No, any term in a contract of employment or collective agreement that seeks to restrain an employee from exercising rights conferred or recognised by this Act is null and void, whether agreed before or after the Act's commencement, as per section 5(2).
Does section 5 prevent fair dismissal for valid reasons?
No, nothing in section 5 prevents an employer from fairly dismissing or disciplining an employee for a valid reason in accordance with the Labour Act or other relevant law, as per section 5(3).
What basic rights do employers have under the Act?
Every employer has the right to take part in the formation of an employers’ organisation and to be a member of such organisation in accordance with its constitution, as per section 6(1).
What rights do members of employers' organisations have?
Members have the right, subject to the constitution, to take part in lawful activities, hold office, and exercise rights conferred by the Act, as per section 6(2).
What additional rights do members of federations of employers' organisations have?
They have the right, subject to the federation's constitution, to take part in lawful activities, participate in elections of office bearers, and exercise rights under the Act, as per section 6(3).
Does every eligible person have the right to join a trade union or employers' organisation?
Yes, any eligible person under the constitution has the right to membership on payment of dues and to remain a member while complying with the constitution, as per section 7(1).
Is membership in a trade union compulsory?
No, any person who has the right to join also has the right not to join such trade union or organisation, as per section 7(2).
Are closed shop agreements allowed under the Act?
No, any term in an agreement precluding employment of non-members or requiring union membership as a condition of employment is null and void, as per section 7(3).
Can trade unions or organisations discriminate in membership?

No, they shall not discriminate on grounds of race, colour, national extraction, social origin, religion, political opinion, sex, marital status, family responsibilities, age, or disability, as per section 7(4).
Are affirmative action programmes allowed despite anti-discrimination rules?
Yes, provisions, programmes, or activities aimed at improving conditions of disadvantaged persons are lawful, as per section 7(5).
Can a member be penalised for refusing to participate in unlawful actions?

No, no person refusing to participate in unlawful actions shall be subject to disadvantage, prejudice, cancellation of membership, removal from office, or penalty by the organisation, as per section 7(6).
Is employer domination of trade unions permitted?
No, no employer or employers' organisation shall promote or support a trade union under employer domination or control by financial or other means, as per section 8(1).
Can trade unions have political affiliations?
No, no union or organisation shall join or form part of a trade union movement and shall be independent from political affiliation with any political party, as per section 8(2).
Can trade unions form federations?
Yes, trade unions and employers' organisations may form and be members of federations and take part in their activities in accordance with their constitutions, as per section 9.
Are international affiliations allowed for trade unions and employers' organisations?
Yes, they may affiliate with international workers' or employers' associations, participate in activities, make contributions, and receive assistance, as per section 10.
How can infringements of Part II be addressed?
Any complaint of infringement may be presented to the Labour Court, as per section 11(1).
Who bears the burden of proof in discrimination cases under Part II?
In cases of alleged discrimination, dismissal, or prejudice, the employer must prove the action was for a valid reason, as per section 11(2).
What remedies can the Court order for infringements of freedom of association?
The Court may order reinstatement if requested, restoration of benefits, compensation for damages, and where appropriate, a punitive indemnity, as per section 11(3).
Explain the fundamental rights granted to employees in forming and joining trade unions.
Every employee has the right to participate in forming a trade union or federation and to become a member subject to the union's constitution, as per section 4(1).
Describe the rights of trade union members regarding participation in union activities.

Members can participate in lawful activities outside working hours or with employer consent during working hours, seek and hold office, and participate in workplace representative elections, as per section 4(2).
What protections exist against employer interference in freedom of association?
Employers cannot require non-membership, discriminate for union activities, or offer benefits for non-exercise of rights; such contract terms are void, as per section 5.
Explain the parallel rights provided to employers in forming organisations.
Employers mirror employee rights: formation, membership, participation in activities, holding office, and federation rights, as per section 6.
Describe the non-discrimination and voluntary membership principles in section 7.
Eligible persons have right to join and remain members or not join; no compulsory membership clauses; no discrimination on prohibited grounds, with affirmative action allowed, as per section 7.
What safeguards prevent employer control over trade unions?
Prohibition on promoting or financially supporting dominated unions, and requirement for independence from political parties, as per section 8.
Explain the provisions for forming federations and international affiliations.
Unions and organisations can form federations and affiliate internationally, including financial contributions and assistance, as per sections 9 and 10.
Detail the remedies available through the Labour Court for violations of Part II.
Complaints go to Court; employer proves valid reason in discrimination cases; remedies include reinstatement, restoration of benefits, compensation, and punitive indemnity, as per section 11.
Why is freedom of association considered fundamental in the Act?
Part II establishes core rights for both employees and employers to associate freely, with strong protections and remedies to ensure independence and non-interference, as per sections 4-11.
How does the Act balance employee and employer organisational rights?
It provides nearly identical rights to form, join, participate in, and federate organisations for both sides, with mutual protections against interference, as per sections 4-6.
What is the significance of section 5(2) regarding contract terms?
It declares void any contractual restraint on exercising Act rights, protecting freedom even against pre-existing agreements, as per section 5(2).
Explain the exception for valid dismissals in section 5(3).
Protections do not prevent fair dismissal for valid reasons under other laws, ensuring balance with disciplinary needs, as per section 5(3).
Describe the anti-discrimination grounds in section 7(4).
Unions cannot discriminate on race, colour, national extraction, social origin, religion, political opinion, sex, marital status, family responsibilities, age, or disability, as per section 7(4).
Why does section 7(5) allow certain preferential programmes?
To permit lawful affirmative action for disadvantaged groups without violating anti-discrimination rules, as per section 7(5).
What protection exists for members refusing unlawful actions?
No disadvantage or penalty for refusing unlawful activities, protecting internal democracy, as per section 7(6).
Explain the prohibition in section 8(1).
Prevents employer domination or control of trade unions through promotion or support, ensuring genuine worker representation, as per section 8(1).
Why must unions be independent from political parties under section 8(2)?
To maintain independence of the trade union movement from political affiliation, as per section 8(2).
What benefits does international affiliation provide under section 10?
Allows participation, contributions, and receipt of assistance from international bodies, strengthening global solidarity, as per section 10.
Explain the burden of proof shift in section 11(2).
Shifts burden to employer to prove valid reason in discrimination cases, easing employee claims, as per section 11(2).
What punitive measures can the Court impose under section 11(3)?
Punitive indemnity in addition to compensation, reinstatement, and benefit restoration, deterring violations, as per section 11(3).
Summarise the key principle of freedom of association in Part II.
Part II guarantees free, voluntary, and independent association for employees and employers without interference or discrimination, with effective remedies, as per sections 4-11.
How does Part II align with ILO conventions on freedom of association?
By providing formation, membership, activity, and protection rights mirroring ILO Convention 87 and 98 principles, reinforced by section 3(1).
What scenario would violate section 5(1)(b)?
Dismissing or threatening an employee for participating in lawful union activities or proceedings under the Act, as per section 5(1)(b).
If an employer promises promotion for leaving a union, is this legal?
No, it violates section 5(1)(c) by advantaging non-exercise of rights.
Can a pre-2005 contract require union non-membership?
No, such terms are null and void regardless of when agreed, as per section 5(2).
Is dismissing a shop steward for poor performance protected under section 5?
Yes, if valid reason and fair process under other laws, as per section 5(3).
Can an employer refuse to hire someone because they are not union-recommended?
Yes, such preclusion is null and void, as per section 7(3)(i).
Is a union constitution clause excluding women valid?
No, it discriminates on sex grounds, violating section 7(4).
Can a union fine a member for refusing an illegal strike?
No, such penalty is prohibited, as per section 7(6).
If an employer funds a union to control it, what section is violated?
Section 8(1) prohibiting support for dominated unions.
Can a trade union be affiliated with a political party?
No, unions must be independent from political parties, as per section 8(2).
What if a union receives funds from an international labour organisation?
Permitted under section 10.
If dismissed for union membership, what must the employer prove?
Valid reason unrelated to union activity, as per section 11(2).
What remedies might an employee get for unfair dismissal due to union activity?
Reinstatement, back pay, compensation, and punitive indemnity, as per section 11(3).
An employee wants to help start a new trade union at their workplace. What right do they have under the Act?
Every employee has the right to take part in the formation of a trade union, as per Section 4(1)(a).
Can an employer prevent workers from joining an existing trade union?
No, Section 5(1)(a) prohibits employers from requiring employees not to join or to relinquish membership in a trade union.
A factory owner wants to create an association with other factory owners to negotiate with unions. What right does he have?
Every employer has the right to take part in the formation of an employers' organisation, as per Section 6(1)(a).
Maria wants to attend a union meeting during working hours. Does she need permission?
According to Section 4(2)(a), employees can participate in union activities during working hours only with the employer's consent. Outside working hours, no consent is required.
An employer offers a promotion to a worker if they quit their union. Is this legal?
No, Section 5(1)(c) prohibits offering benefits or advantages to employees for not exercising rights conferred by the Act, including union membership.
Can a trade union refuse membership to someone because of their religion?
No, Section 7(4) prohibits discrimination on grounds including religion. Trade unions cannot discriminate in membership based on religion.
John wants to run for a position in his trade union's executive committee. What right does he have?
Every union member has the right to seek and hold office in their trade union, subject to its constitution, as per Section 4(2)(b).
A company fires a worker for participating in a lawful strike. What protection does the worker have?
Section 5(1)(b)(i) prohibits dismissal due to participation in lawful trade union activities. The worker can complain to the Labour Court under Section 11.
Can an employer require new hires to join a specific trade union as a condition of employment?
No, Section 7(3)(ii) states that any term requiring an employee to become a union member is null and void. Section 7(2) also affirms the right not to join.
A trade union wants to establish a scholarship program for members' children from poor families. Is this allowed?
Yes, Section 7(5) allows programs that improve conditions of economically disadvantaged persons, even if they involve differential treatment.
Can an employer provide financial support to a struggling trade union?
No, Section 8(1) prohibits employers from supporting trade unions with financial means if the object is to place the union under employer control.
Where should a worker file a complaint if they're threatened for union activities?
Any complaint of infringement of Part II may be presented to the Labour Court, as per Section 11(1).
A union member refuses to participate in an illegal strike called by union leaders. Can the union expel them?
No, Section 7(6) protects members who refuse to participate in unlawful actions from penalties like cancellation of membership.
Can trade unions in Zanzibar affiliate with international labor organizations?
Yes, Section 10 allows trade unions to affiliate with and participate in international workers' associations and receive assistance from them.
What happens if a collective agreement contains a clause preventing union membership?
Section 5(2) states such terms in collective agreements are null and void, whether agreed before or after the Act came into force.
A worker is demoted after testifying in a labour dispute. What protection applies?
Section 5(1)(b)(iii) prohibits prejudicial action against employees for participation in proceedings under the Act. This would include demotion for testifying.
Can employers form a federation with employers from mainland Tanzania?
Section 9 allows employers' organisations to form federations according to their constitution, which could potentially include mainland employers if the constitution permits.
What remedy is available if a worker is unfairly dismissed for union activities?
Section 11(3) allows the Court to order reinstatement, restoration of benefits, compensation for damages, and potentially punitive indemnity.
Can a union require members to support a specific political party?
No, Section 8(2) requires unions to be independent from political affiliation with any political party.
Who has the burden of proof if a worker claims dismissal for union activities?
Section 11(2) places the burden on the employer to prove the dismissal was for a valid reason, not for union activities.
A disabled worker is denied union membership due to their disability. Is this legal?
No, Section 7(4) specifically prohibits discrimination based on disability in union membership.
Can an employer create a 'company union' that they control?
No, Section 8(1) prohibits employers from promoting establishment of employee organisations under employer domination.
What rights do union members have regarding federation activities?
Section 4(3) gives union members in a federation the right to participate in lawful activities, elect officials, and stand for election themselves.
Can an employer discriminate against a job applicant known to be a union organizer?
No, Section 5(1) applies to both employees and persons seeking employment, prohibiting discrimination based on union affiliation.
A union charges higher dues for female members. Is this permissible?
No, Section 7(4) prohibits discrimination based on sex, which would include discriminatory fee structures.
What election rights do workplace representatives have?
Section 4(2)(c) gives members the right to take part in workplace representative elections, and Section 4(2)(d) allows them to be elected or appointed as representatives.
Can an employer threaten workers with relocation if they form a union?
No, Section 5(1)(b) prohibits threatening any prejudicial action, including transfers or relocations, due to union activities.
Must a union accept everyone who applies and pays dues?
Section 7(1) states eligible persons have a right to membership upon payment of dues, but eligibility is determined by the union's constitution.
Can a union expel a member for criticizing union leadership?
Expulsion must comply with the union's constitution and cannot be based on discriminatory grounds under Section 7(4), but the Act doesn't specifically protect internal dissent.
What if an employment contract signed before 2005 bans union membership?
Section 5(2) makes such terms null and void whether agreed before or after the Act came into force.
Can employers attend union meetings as observers?
The Act doesn't address this directly, but Section 8(1) prohibits employer interference, which might include unauthorized attendance at union meetings.
A union wants to create a women's leadership program. Is this discriminatory?
Section 7(5) allows programs aimed at improving conditions of disadvantaged groups, so a women's leadership program could be lawful if it addresses disadvantage.
What rights do employers have in their organizations similar to union rights?
Section 6 gives employers parallel rights to participate in formation, membership, activities, and holding office in employers' organisations.
Can a union require members to participate in political rallies?
Section 8(2) requires union independence from political parties, and Section 7(6) protects members who refuse unlawful actions, but political activity itself isn't necessarily unlawful.
What if a worker is harassed by coworkers for being a union member?
Section 5 prohibits employer discrimination but doesn't directly address coworker harassment. However, employers may have a duty to prevent hostile work environments.
Can a union have different membership categories with different rights?
Section 7(4) prohibits discriminatory conditions, but Section 7(5) allows affirmative action for disadvantaged groups, suggesting some differentiation may be permissible.
What constitutes 'lawful trade union activities' under Section 4?
The Act doesn't define this specifically, but it would include activities permitted by the union's constitution and not prohibited by law, including meetings, elections, and collective bargaining.
Can an employer favor non-union workers in promotions?
No, Section 5(1)(b)(i) prohibits discrimination based on union membership, which would include preferential treatment for non-members.
What if a union's constitution limits office holding to certain ethnic groups?
Section 7(4) specifically prohibits discrimination based on national extraction (ethnicity) in union constitutions or actions.
Can employers collectively decide not to hire union members?
No, Section 5(1) applies to employers and persons acting on their behalf, prohibiting discrimination against union members in hiring.
What rights do members have when their union joins a federation?
Section 4(3) gives members rights to participate in federation activities, elect federation officials, and stand for federation office.
Can a union charge different dues based on income level?
Section 7(5) might allow this as a program to assist economically disadvantaged members, but Section 7(4) prohibits discriminatory obligations, so it depends on implementation.
What if an employer fires a worker for poor performance who happens to be a union leader?
Section 5(3) allows fair dismissal for valid reasons, but Section 11(2) places the burden on the employer to prove the dismissal wasn't due to union activities.
Can unions accept donations from political parties?
Section 8(2) requires union independence from political affiliation, which likely prohibits financial ties that create dependence on political parties.
What protections exist for workers who refuse to join a union?
Section 7(2) explicitly grants the right not to join a trade union, and Section 7(3) voids employment terms requiring union membership.
Can an employer provide meeting space for union activities?
The Act doesn't prohibit this, but Section 8(1) would prohibit it if done with the object of controlling the union.
What if a union's election procedures disadvantage older members?
Section 7(4) prohibits discrimination based on age, so election procedures must be accessible to members of all ages.
Can employers be members of trade unions?
Section 4 grants rights to employees, and 'trade union' is defined as an association of employees, so employers cannot be union members.
What constitutes 'valid reason' for dismissal under Section 5(3)?
The Act refers to the Labour Act or other relevant laws for what constitutes valid reasons for dismissal, indicating it's determined by general labor law principles.
Can a union have a maternity leave policy for its own staff?
Yes, and Section 7(5) would specifically allow such policies as improving conditions of persons with family responsibilities.
What if an employer promises bonuses for departments with no union members?
Section 5(1)(c) prohibits offering advantages for not exercising rights under the Act, which would include this indirect pressure against unionization.
Can unions engage in international activities without government approval?
Section 10 allows affiliation with international associations without requiring prior government approval, suggesting autonomy in international engagement.
What if a worker wants to change unions?
Section 4(1)(b) gives the right to be a member of a trade union, and Section 7(2) gives the right not to join, implying freedom to change union affiliation.
Can employers require union approval before hiring workers?
No, Section 7(3)(i) specifically voids terms that preclude employers from engaging non-union members or require union approval for hiring.
What if a union excludes workers from a particular region?
Section 7(4) prohibits discrimination based on social origin, which could include regional background if it constitutes social origin discrimination.
Can union officials take time off for union duties?
Section 4(2)(a) allows participation in union activities during working hours with employer consent, suggesting time off may be negotiated.
What if an employer discriminates against a worker for filing a labour complaint?
Section 5(1)(b)(iii) specifically prohibits prejudicial action for participation in proceedings under the Act, which includes filing complaints.
Can a union have religious requirements for membership?
No, Section 7(4) explicitly prohibits discrimination based on religion in union membership or actions.
What if a company provides funds for 'worker welfare' that goes to a union?
Section 8(1) prohibits financial support if the object is to control the union, so it depends on the purpose and effect of the funding.
Can employers form multiple organizations for different industries?
Yes, Section 6 gives employers the right to form organizations, and nothing limits them to one organization per employer.
What if a union requires members to attend all meetings?
Reasonable attendance requirements are likely permissible, but Section 7(6) protects members who refuse unlawful activities, suggesting some limits on mandatory participation.
Can a union be affiliated with a political party's youth wing?
Section 8(2) requires independence from political affiliation with 'any political party,' which would likely include affiliated wings.
What if an employer gives worse assignments to union activists?
Section 5(1)(b) prohibits discriminatory action including unfavorable work assignments due to union activities.
Can a union have age limits for certain positions?
Section 7(4) prohibits discrimination based on age, but Section 7(5) might allow age-based programs for disadvantaged age groups if properly structured.
What if a worker is fired during union organizing efforts?
Section 11(2) places the burden on the employer to prove the dismissal was for valid reasons unrelated to union activities during organizing.
Can unions receive training from international organizations?
Yes, Section 10 allows receiving financial and other assistance from international associations, which would include training.
What if a union's fees are too high for low-paid workers?
Section 7(5) might allow reduced fees for economically disadvantaged members as a program to improve their condition.
Can employers monitor union meetings on company property?
Section 8(1) prohibits employer interference, which would likely include surveillance of union activities.
What if a worker faces retaliation for supporting a different union candidate?
Section 4(2)(b) gives the right to seek office, and Section 5(1)(b) prohibits retaliation for exercising rights, suggesting protection for election activities.
Can a union require members to disclose political affiliations?
Section 7(4) prohibits discrimination based on political opinion, so requiring disclosure could facilitate such discrimination and may be problematic.
What if an employer provides positive references only for non-union workers?
Section 5(1)(b) prohibits discrimination including favorable treatment based on union membership status.
Can a union have different voting rights for different membership categories?
Section 7(4) prohibits discriminatory conditions, but reasonable distinctions based on membership duration or type might be permissible if not discriminatory.
What if management participates in union decision-making?
Section 8(1) prohibits employer domination of unions, which would include management participation in internal union decisions.
Can a union expel a member for working during a strike?

Section 7(6) protects members who refuse to participate in unlawful actions, but working during a lawful strike might be considered contrary to union solidarity and subject to constitutional discipline.
What if an employer offers better benefits to departments that reject unionization?
