While Section 15(1)(b) mentions 'federation of such trade unions or employers' organisation' as registrable, the definition comes from Section 3(2): 'any combination or association of two or more trade unions which have a separate legal existence from the trade unions of which they are comprised.' A federation must consist of at least two member unions maintaining separate legal identities.
Can the Registrar request additional information beyond the Section 15(2) requirements?

Yes. Section 19 allows the Registrar to call for further information required under Section 15 to satisfy themselves that the application complies with Section 15 or that the union is entitled to registration. This discretionary power ensures thorough review of applications.
How does the Registrar determine if a name 'nearly resembles' another under Section 20?

Section 20 gives the Registrar discretion to determine if a proposed name 'so nearly resembles such name as to be likely to deceive or mislead the public or the members.' This subjective determination considers factors like phonetic similarity, visual appearance, and likely public confusion. The Registrar's opinion on potential deception is sufficient ground for requiring name alteration.
Scenario: A multi-trade union representing both hotel workers and construction workers applies. What special requirement applies?

Under Section 21(1)(c), if an association consists of persons engaged in more than one trade/calling, its constitution must contain suitable provisions for protecting and promoting their respective trade union interests. Without such provisions, the Registrar may refuse registration to ensure each trade group's interests are adequately represented and protected within the union structure.
What constitutes 'good faith' immunity under Section 13?

Section 13 protects officers for acts/omissions done 'in good faith and without negligence and in intended exercise of any power or performance of any duty.' 'Good faith' generally means honest intention without malice or ulterior motive. Protection requires all three elements: good faith, absence of negligence, and intended exercise of authority. Negligent or malicious actions would not be protected.
Can a branch of an unregistered parent union register independently?

No. Section 21(1)(d) explicitly allows refusal if the applicant 'is a branch of a trade union or organisation other than a registered trade union or organisation.' Branches must be part of registered parent organizations. This prevents fragmentation and ensures proper oversight through registered parent entities.
What notice period applies to voluntary dissolution under Section 22(1)?

Section 22(2) requires three months' notice in the gazette and media before the Registrar exercises cancellation powers under Section 22(1). This applies to both voluntary dissolution requests and cases where the Registrar believes the organization has ceased to exist. The notice period allows interested parties to respond before cancellation.
Scenario: A registered union's accounts show irregularities. What cancellation ground applies?

Section 22(3)(g) allows cancellation application if 'the accounts of the union or organisation are not being kept in accordance with the provisions of this Act and of its constitution.' Financial mismanagement or failure to maintain proper accounts as required by the Act and constitution justifies cancellation proceedings to protect members' funds.
What is the difference between Sections 22(4) and 22(5) notice periods?

Section 22(4) requires 'not less than one month previous notice in writing' to the union before applying for cancellation. Section 22(5) then gives the union 'a period of one month' from notice to show cause. These are sequential: first a minimum one-month notice of intended action, then a one-month response period, totaling at least two months before the Registrar can file the cancellation application under Section 22(6).
Who can appeal under Section 23(1) and within what timeframe?

Section 23(1) allows 'any person aggrieved by the refusal of the Registrar to register' to appeal within 30 days. 'Person aggrieved' likely includes the applicant union/organization, its officials, or members affected by the refusal. The 30-day limit ensures timely challenges while providing finality to registration decisions.
What happens to a union's liabilities after cancellation?

Section 24(1)(a) specifies that cancellation doesn't prejudice 'any liabilities incurred or to be incurred by the trade union or organisation which may be enforced against the union and its assets.' Despite losing registration privileges, the union remains liable for existing debts and obligations, which creditors can enforce against remaining assets during dissolution.
Can former officials handle union affairs during dissolution?

Section 24(1)(d) permits limited actions: defending/bringing legal proceedings, or dissolving the union and disposing of funds according to its constitution. However, they cannot 'take any part in its management or organisation, or act or purport to act on behalf of the union or as an officer' for regular activities. This balances winding-up needs with preventing continued unauthorized operation.
Scenario: A union fails to deliver its certificate within 60 days of cancellation. What penalties apply?

Under Section 24(2), failure to deliver the certificate within 60 days (or extended time allowed by Registrar) makes the union, its officers, and anyone acting as an official guilty of an offense. Penalties include fines up to 200,000 shillings or imprisonment. The Registrar has discretion to grant extensions in particular cases.
What is the evidentiary value of a certified register copy?

Section 16(2) states that a register copy certified by the Registrar 'shall, until the contrary be shown, be proof of the facts specified therein, as on the date of such certified copy.' This creates a rebuttable presumption of truth, shifting the burden to anyone challenging the facts to provide contrary evidence.
How does Section 17 interact with other registration provisions?

Section 17 states the Registrar 'shall register the trade union or organisation in the prescribed manner' subject to the Act's provisions and Minister's Regulations. This creates a duty to register compliant applications, but 'subject to the provisions of this Act' incorporates refusal grounds in Sections 20-21. Registration isn't automatic but mandatory for applications meeting all requirements.
What constitutes 'prescribed manner' under Section 17?

The 'prescribed manner' refers to procedures established by Regulations made under the Act (see Section 49). Until specific regulations are issued, the Registrar follows the general requirements in Sections 15-16. The Minister has authority under Section 49 to make regulations detailing registration procedures, forms, and requirements.
Scenario: A union changes its constitution but doesn't notify the Registrar. What cancellation ground applies?

Section 22(3)(f) covers situations where a union 'has wilfully and after notice from the Registrar contravened any of the provision of this Act or allowed any rule to continue in force which is inconsistent with any provision of this Act.' Failure to notify constitutional changes (likely required under Section 16(1)) could constitute such violation, especially if willful and after notice.
Can the Registrar cancel registration without court involvement?

Yes, for two specific cases under Section 22(1): at the union's request upon dissolution, or if satisfied the union has ceased to exist. For all other grounds in Section 22(3), the Registrar must apply to the Court for cancellation. This judicial oversight protects unions from arbitrary administrative cancellation for substantive violations.
What is the purpose of the one-month 'show cause' period?

Section 22(5)'s one-month period allows the union to respond to cancellation allegations in writing. This procedural fairness requirement gives unions opportunity to:
1. Challenge factual allegations
2. Explain or rectify violations
3. Present arguments against cancellation
4. Request the inquiry mentioned in Section 22(5)
It embodies natural justice principles before severe sanctions like cancellation.
How are appeals handled under Section 23?

Section 23 establishes a two-tier appeal system:
1. First appeal to the Court (Industrial Court) within 30 days
2. Further appeal to Court of Appeal
Section 23(3) authorizes the Chief Justice to make procedural rules. Section 23(4) ensures the Registrar can participate. Section 23(5) provides finality: if appeal dismissed, dissolution takes effect immediately.
What happens to union funds after cancellation?

Section 24(1)(b) requires dissolution with funds disposed according to the union's constitution. If no constitutional provision exists, the Registrar gives directions. This prioritizes members' constitutional rights while ensuring orderly distribution when the constitution is silent. Funds cannot be diverted to unauthorized purposes after cancellation.
Scenario: A union continues operations after cancellation. What offenses occur?

Multiple offenses under Section 24:
1. Union itself commits offense by not dissolving
2. Officers commit offenses by continuing management
3. Anyone acting as official commits offense
All face fines up to 200,000 shillings or imprisonment under Section 24(2). Additionally, acting as official of a deemed-dissolved union under Section 21(3) carries separate penalties up to 500,000 shillings.
Can Assistant Registrars perform all Registrar functions?

Section 12(3) allows appointment of Assistant Registrars 'as may from time to time be required.' Their authority depends on delegation by the Minister or Registrar. As 'officers appointed under section 12,' they enjoy the same Section 13 immunity when acting within their authority in good faith without negligence.
What is the significance of the six-month application deadline?

The six-month deadline in Sections 14-15 serves several purposes:
1. Encourages timely regularization of existing unions
2. Prevents prolonged operation without oversight
3. Creates certainty about union status
4. Allows enforcement against non-compliant groups
5. Reflects balance between organizing freedom and regulatory need
Automatic dissolution for non-compliance creates strong incentive for timely applications.
How does cancellation affect ongoing collective bargaining?

Section 24(1)(a) states cancellation ends 'any of the rights, immunities, or privileges of a registered trade union.' Since collective bargaining rights typically require registered status (see later parts), cancellation would likely terminate bargaining authority. However, existing collective agreements might remain binding depending on their terms and other provisions of the Act.
What is the relationship between Sections 14 and 15 timeframes?

Section 14 establishes the general requirement: unions must apply within six months of formation or Act commencement. Section 15 adds that eligible unions 'may apply... within six months of its formation.' Both sections harmonize to create a single six-month application window from the relevant starting point (formation or commencement, whichever later).
Scenario: A union appeals refusal, but the Court dismisses the appeal. What is the effective dissolution date?

Section 23(5) specifies that when a union appeals Registrar refusal and the appeal is dismissed, 'the trade union or organisation shall be deemed to be dissolved with effect from the date of the dismissal of such appeal.' This differs from Section 21(2)'s dissolution from notification date, creating an extended operational period during appeal.
Can a dissolved union reapply for registration?

The Act doesn't explicitly prohibit reapplications. However, a dissolved union under Section 21(2) or 23(5) ceases to exist legally. Members could form a new union and apply under Section 15, but they must meet all requirements anew, including the six-month timeframe from new formation date under Section 14(2).
What constitutes 'wilful' violation under Section 22(3)(f)?

'Wilful' suggests intentional, knowing violation rather than accidental non-compliance. Section 22(3)(f) requires both wilfulness AND notice from the Registrar. This two-step process: first notice of violation, then continued wilful violation, justifies severe sanction of cancellation. It allows unions opportunity to correct issues before facing cancellation.
How does media notice under Section 22(2) work?

Section 22(2) requires 'three months' notice in the gazette and media' before cancellation under Section 22(1). 'Gazette' means official government publication. 'Media' likely includes newspapers, radio, or television. This public notice informs members, creditors, and the public of impending cancellation, allowing them to protect their interests.
What is the role of the Court in cancellation proceedings?

For Section 22(3) grounds, the Registrar must apply to Court for cancellation (Section 22(3) opening). The Court hears the application, considers evidence and union's defense, and decides whether to cancel registration. This judicial process adds independent review for serious allegations beyond simple non-existence or voluntary dissolution handled administratively under Section 22(1).
Scenario: A union changes officials but doesn't update the register. What consequence?

Section 16(1) requires recording 'any alteration or change... in the... officials, executive committee' in the register. Failure to notify changes violates this requirement. Under Section 22(3)(f), if willful and after Registrar notice, it could support cancellation. Additionally, inaccurate register information might affect legal proceedings or members' rights relying on official records.
Can the Registrar cancel for violations occurring before registration?

Section 22(3)(b) allows cancellation if 'objects actually carried on' would have justified refusal at registration. This covers situations where a union's actual activities diverge from stated objects. Section 22(3)(h) also covers being a branch of an unregistered union 'at the time of its registration.' These allow addressing pre-registration issues discovered later.
What is the purpose of certified constitution copies?

Section 15(2)(b) requires 'two certified copies of the constitution.' Certification ensures authenticity. The Registrar reviews the constitution for compliance with Act requirements (see Schedule under Section 28). One copy likely remains with Registrar, one may be returned stamped as filed. This creates official record of governing documents for reference in disputes.
How does Section 22(7) protect unions?

Section 22(7) requires the Registrar's cancellation application to 'specify briefly the grounds' and be 'served on the trade union or association affected.' This notice requirement ensures unions know allegations against them, can prepare defense, and exercise Section 22(5) right to show cause. It's a fundamental fairness protection in cancellation proceedings.
What happens during the Section 22(5) inquiry?

If a union shows cause under Section 22(5), 'the Registrar shall hold such inquiry as he or she may consider necessary in the circumstances.' The Act doesn't specify inquiry procedures, giving Registrar discretion. Likely includes reviewing written submissions, hearing witnesses, examining evidence. The inquiry informs Registrar's decision whether to proceed with court application under Section 22(6).
Can individuals be liable for union registration offenses?

Yes. Section 21(3) makes 'any person acting as an official' of a deemed-dissolved union guilty of an offense with individual liability. Section 24(2) also imposes individual liability on 'any officer thereof, and any person acting as an official thereof' for post-cancellation offenses. Personal penalties include fines and imprisonment, not just organizational sanctions.
What is the effect of 'deemed dissolved' under Section 21(2)?

'Deemed dissolved' creates legal fiction: the union is treated as dissolved from notification date regardless of actual winding up. This triggers Section 21(3) offenses for continued operation and Section 21(4) exceptions for limited winding-up activities. It provides clear cutoff date for legal status, avoiding uncertainty about when dissolution actually occurs.
How are registration requirements for employers' organizations different?

Key differences under Section 15:
1. Minimum members: 5 for employers' organizations vs. 20 for trade unions (Section 15(1)(c) vs (a))
2. Definition: 'employers' organisation' defined in Section 3(2) vs 'trade union'
3. Objects: Must represent employers' interests vs employees' interests
Other procedures (application, documents, fees) appear similar under Section 15(2).
What constitutes 'unlawful purpose' under Section 22(3)(e)?

'Unlawful purpose' means any objective or activity prohibited by law. This broad ground allows cancellation if a union engages in criminal activities, promotes violence, violates other laws, or uses registration as cover for illegal operations. Combined with Section 22(3)(c) (unlawful principal objects), it comprehensively addresses misuse of union status for illegal ends.
Can registration be conditional or provisional?

The Act doesn't provide for conditional or provisional registration. Sections 17-18 suggest registration is binary: either registered with full certificate or not registered. However, Section 19 allows Registrar to request additional information, potentially creating de facto provisional status during review. But once certificate issues under Section 18, it's 'conclusive evidence' of registration.
What is the relationship between Sections 22 and 24?

Section 22 establishes grounds and procedures for cancellation. Section 24 outlines consequences once cancellation occurs. They work sequentially: first cancellation under Section 22, then dissolution and other effects under Section 24. Section 24 applies regardless of which Section 22 ground led to cancellation, providing uniform post-cancellation regime.
Scenario: A union misses the 30-day appeal deadline. Any recourse?

Section 23(1) specifies 'within 30 days.' Courts typically strictly enforce statutory time limits. However, Section 23(3) allows Chief Justice to make rules 'prescribing the time within which such appeals shall be brought.' Rules might provide for extensions in exceptional circumstances. Otherwise, missed deadline likely bars appeal, making refusal final.
How does cancellation affect existing contracts?

Section 24(1)(a) preserves 'liabilities incurred or to be incurred... which may be enforced against the union and its assets.' This suggests existing contractual obligations remain enforceable during dissolution. However, the union cannot enter new contracts after cancellation since it lacks legal capacity. Contract partners should consider union's impending dissolution when enforcing rights.
What constitutes 'negligence' losing Section 13 immunity?

Section 13 immunity requires acts/omissions 'without negligence.' Negligence means failure to exercise reasonable care expected of a registration official. This could include:
1. Careless review of applications
2. Failure to follow required procedures
3. Ignoring obvious compliance issues
4. Reckless decision-making
Negligent officials lose personal immunity and could face lawsuits for damages caused.
Can the Registrar reconsider a refusal decision?

The Act doesn't provide for administrative reconsideration. Once refusal occurs under Section 21, the union's remedy is appeal under Section 23, not requesting Registrar to reconsider. However, before formal refusal, the Registrar could allow amendment of deficient applications under Section 19 (requesting further information) or Section 20 (requiring name changes).
What is the purpose of the registration fee?

Section 15(2)(d) requires 'prescribed fee.' Fees likely set by Minister under Section 49. Purposes include:
1. Covering administrative costs of registration process
2. Discouraging frivolous applications
3. Contributing to registration system maintenance
4. Ensuring serious intent by applicants
The fee amount and payment procedures would be specified in Regulations.
How does cancellation for non-independence work?

Section 22(3)(a) allows cancellation 'in the case of a trade union, it has ceased to be independent of employer or employers' organisation.' This addresses 'company unions' controlled by management. Independence is fundamental to genuine collective bargaining. Evidence might include employer funding, management involvement in union decisions, or coordination undermining genuine worker representation.
What records must the Registrar maintain beyond basic registration data?

Section 16(1) requires recording 'all such other matters as may be required to be contained therein under this Act or any Regulations made thereunder.' This catch-all allows Minister via Regulations under Section 49 to specify additional record-keeping: perhaps membership statistics, financial reports, disciplinary actions, or other data needed for effective oversight of registered organizations.
Can a union operate while waiting for registration decision?

Section 14 requires application within six months to avoid dissolution, but doesn't explicitly prohibit operation during application processing. However, Section 21(3) penalizes acting as official of dissolved union. Prudent approach: unions can organize but avoid exercising rights reserved for registered unions (like collective bargaining) until registration granted. Operating as unregistered union carries risks if application ultimately refused.
What constitutes 'branch' status affecting registration?

Section 21(1)(d) concerns 'branch of a trade union or organisation other than a registered trade union or organisation.' 'Branch' is defined in Section 3(2). This prevents fragments of unregistered parent bodies from registering separately. It ensures registration integrity: either the whole organization registers properly, or none of its branches can register independently.
How are continuing offenses penalized?

Section 21(3) provides for 'a fine not exceeding ten thousand shillings for each day during which the offence continues.' This per diem penalty for continuing offenses creates strong incentive to cease unauthorized operations immediately after dissolution. It addresses situations where offenders might consider one-time fine as cost of doing business, making ongoing violation increasingly costly.
What is the Registrar's role in dissolution?

The Registrar has several dissolution roles:
1. Verifying voluntary dissolution requests (Section 22(1)(a))
2. Determining if union has ceased to exist (Section 22(1)(b))
3. Giving directions for fund disposal if constitution silent (Section 24(1)(b))
4. Receiving returned certificates (Section 24(1)(c))
5. Granting time extensions for compliance (Section 24(2))
This oversight ensures orderly dissolution protecting members' interests.
Can registration be transferred or assigned?

The Act doesn't provide for transfer or assignment of registration. Registration is specific to the applying organization meeting Section 15 criteria. If members want to reorganize, they would need to form new entity and apply anew. However, Sections 33-34 address name changes, amalgamations, and federations, which are different from transfers of registration between unrelated entities.
What constitutes 'ceased to exist' under Section 22(1)(b)?

'Ceased to exist' likely means the union is no longer functioning as a going concern. Evidence might include:
1. No activities for extended period
2. No remaining active members
3. No functioning leadership
4. Inability to locate officials
5. Empty bank accounts
Before cancellation under this ground, Section 22(2) requires three months' public notice to confirm non-existence.
How does the appeal process protect against arbitrary refusal?

Section 23's appeal process provides judicial review of Registrar's decisions. Protection elements:
1. Independent Court review (Section 23(1))
2. Further appeal to higher court (Section 23(2))
3. Court can make 'such order as it thinks proper' (Section 23(1))
4. Registrar must justify refusal (implied)
5. Timely 30-day appeal right
This checks administrative discretion, ensuring refusals are law-based not arbitrary.
What happens to a union's name after cancellation?

The Act doesn't explicitly address name availability after cancellation. However, Section 20 prevents registration of names identical or confusingly similar to existing registered unions. Once cancelled, the name might become available for new applicants, but the Registrar would consider whether re-use could deceive under Section 20, especially if the cancelled union was well-known.
Can the Registrar initiate cancellation for pre-registration misrepresentation?

Section 22(3)(b) covers situations where 'objects actually carried on' would have justified refusal at registration. This addresses post-registration discovery that the union misrepresented its objects or activities during application. If the actual activities diverge significantly from stated objects justifying registration, cancellation is available even for pre-registration conduct.
What is the effect of automatic dissolution under Section 14?

Section 14 creates automatic dissolution for failure to apply timely. Unlike Section 21(2) dissolution after refusal notice, Section 14 dissolution appears self-executing after six-month deadline passes. However, practical enforcement likely requires Registrar determination that dissolution occurred. Once dissolved, operating would violate Section 21(3) for acting as official of dissolved union.
How are 'prescribed' forms and fees determined?

'Prescribed' means specified by Regulations made under the Act. Section 49 gives Minister power to make regulations for various matters, including 'the fees to be charged for registration' (Section 49(2)(viii)) and 'the books and registers to be kept... and the forms thereof' (Section 49(2)(ii)). Until regulations issue, the Registrar likely uses interim forms and fees.
What constitutes 'suitable provisions' for multi-trade unions?

Section 21(1)(c) requires 'suitable provisions for the protection and promotion of their respective trade union interests' in multi-trade unions. What's 'suitable' depends on circumstances but might include:
1. Separate representation for each trade group
2. Proportional voting or representation
3. Protection of each trade's specific interests
4. Fair resource allocation across trades
5. Mechanisms to prevent domination by one trade
Without such provisions, registration can be refused.
Can a union be registered with conditions?

The Act doesn't provide for conditional registration. Section 17 says Registrar 'shall register... in the prescribed manner' if requirements met. Section 18 provides for certificate issuance. This suggests binary outcome. However, Section 19 allows requesting further information, and unions must maintain compliance post-registration to avoid cancellation under Section 22 for subsequent violations.
What is the relationship between Parts II and III regarding registration?

Part II establishes fundamental rights (like forming unions). Part III implements those rights through registration system. While Part II gives right to form unions, Part III regulates how they gain legal status through registration. Registration enables exercise of other rights (like collective bargaining). However, Section 3(2) defines 'trade union' to include unregistered associations, suggesting some Part II rights might apply even without registration.
How does cancellation affect a union's ability to sue or be sued?

Section 24(1)(d) allows continued action 'for the purpose of defending or bringing legal proceedings.' This exception preserves access to courts during dissolution for winding up affairs. However, the union cannot initiate new regular business lawsuits unrelated to dissolution. After assets distributed and dissolution complete, the former union ceases to exist and cannot sue or be sued.
What constitutes 'reasonable' extension under Section 24(2)?

Section 24(2) allows Registrar discretion to grant 'such extended time as the Registrar may in his or her discretion in any particular case allow' for delivering certificate after cancellation. 'Reasonable' extension considers factors like:
1. Distance or logistical challenges
2. Genuine attempts to comply
3. Complexity of dissolution
4. Impact on members/creditors
5. Reasons for delay
Arbitrary refusal of reasonable extension might be challengeable.
Who appoints the Registrar under the Labour Relations Act?
The Minister appoints the Registrar of trade unions and employers' organisations, as well as Assistant Registrars and other officials as required, as per section 12.
Are officials protected from lawsuits?
Yes, no suit lies against officers for good faith acts without negligence under the Act, as per section 13.
Must all trade unions register?
Yes, unregistered ones must apply or dissolve within six months, as per section 14.
How many members needed for a trade union to register?
At least 20 members, as per section 15(1)(a).
What fee is required for registration?
The prescribed fee, as per section 15(2)(d).
What is maintained by the Registrar?
A register of trade unions and organisations with prescribed particulars, as per section 16.
What evidence does the registration certificate provide?
Conclusive evidence of due registration unless cancelled, as per section 18.
Can the Registrar change a union's name?
Yes, require alteration if similar or misleading, as per section 20.
What happens if registration is refused?
Union deemed dissolved, with offences for acting as official, as per section 21.
How can registration be cancelled?
At request, if ceased to exist, or by Court on serious grounds, as per section 22.
Can you appeal a refusal to register?
Yes, to the Industrial Court within 30 days, as per section 23.
What happens to rights after cancellation?
Cease to enjoy registered rights and privileges, as per section 24.
Must the certificate be returned after cancellation?
Yes, within 60 days, as per section 24.
Is acting as official after cancellation an offence?
Yes, with fines or imprisonment, as per section 24(2).
What is the minimum number of members for an employers' organisation to register?
Five or more members, as per section 15(1)(c).
Can federations apply for registration?
Yes, federations of qualifying trade unions or employers' organisations can apply, as per section 15(1)(b).
Is a constitution required for registration application?
Yes, two certified copies of the constitution and rules (if any), as per section 15(2)(b).
What proof does a certified register entry provide?
Proof of facts until contrary shown, as per section 16(2).
Can the Registrar refuse if the name is identical to an existing union?
Yes, and require alteration, as per section 20.
What are some grounds for refusal of registration?
Non-compliance, unlawful objects, inadequate multi-trade provisions, or being unregistered branch, as per section 21(1).
Is public notice required for some cancellations?
Yes, three months in gazette and media for cessation cases, as per section 22(2).
Can the Registrar hold an inquiry before cancellation?
Yes, if cause shown, as per section 22(5).
What happens to funds on cancellation?
Disposed per constitution or Registrar directions, as per section 24(1)(b).
Is there a time limit for returning the certificate?
Yes, 60 days, extendable at Registrar discretion, as per section 24.
Can liabilities be enforced after cancellation?
Yes, against assets, as per section 24(1)(a).
What if a union has only 15 members?
Cannot apply for registration until reaching 20 members, as per section 15(1)(a).
If a union forms in January 2026, when must it apply?
Within six months of formation, as per section 14(2).
What if the proposed name is 'Zanzibar Workers Union' but one exists?
Registrar requires alteration, refusing until changed, as per section 20.
If refused, does the union automatically dissolve?
Yes, deemed dissolved from notification date, as per section 21(2).
Can someone continue as secretary after refusal?
No, offence unless for proceedings or dissolution, as per section 21(3)-(4).
If a union wants to dissolve voluntarily, what happens?
Requests cancellation, verified, with public notice, as per section 22(1)-(2).
What if accounts are not proper after registration?
Ground for Court cancellation application, as per section 22(3)(g).
If Registrar suspects loss of independence, what can happen?
Apply to Court for cancellation after notice and process, as per section 22(3)(a).
What if a union fails to show cause against cancellation?
Registrar may file Court application after one month, as per section 22(6).
If appeal against refusal is dismissed, what occurs?
Union deemed dissolved from dismissal date, as per section 23(5).
Can the Registrar extend time for certificate return?
Yes, in discretion for particular cases, as per section 24(2).
If an official acts negligently, are they protected?
No, immunity only without negligence, as per section 13.
What additional acts can the Registrar do?
As directed by the Minister, as per section 12(2).
For pre-Act unions, what is the grace period?
Six months from commencement or formation, later date, as per section 14(1).
If application incomplete, what can Registrar do?
Call for further information, as per section 19.
What if name could mislead members?
Require alteration, as per section 20.
If multi-trade but no interest protection, registerable?
No, refusal ground, as per section 21(1)(c).
What daily fine for continuing offence after refusal?
10,000 shillings per day, as per section 21(3).
If union ceases to exist, how cancelled?
By Registrar with public notice, as per section 22(1)(b)-(2).
What if objects become unlawful post-registration?
Ground for cancellation, as per section 22(3)(b)-(c).
If show cause satisfies Registrar, what happens?
No application filed, as implied in section 22(5)-(6).
What must cancellation application specify?
Brief grounds, served on union, as per section 22(7).
Who makes appeal rules?
Chief Justice, as per section 23(3).
If certificate not delivered, offence?
Yes, fine up to 200,000 or imprisonment, as per section 24(2).
Can legal proceedings continue after cancellation?
Yes, allowed acting for that purpose, as per section 24(1)(d).
Explain the comprehensive process for a new trade union to become registered under Part III.

A new union with at least 20 members must apply within six months using prescribed form, constitution copies, information, and fee. Registrar assesses, may request more details or name change, registers if compliant issuing certificate, or refuses with grounds leading to dissolution, with appeal rights, as per sections 14-23.
Discuss the safeguards and penalties ensuring compliance with registration requirements.

Mandatory application timelines, refusal/dissolution for non-compliance, offences for acting post-dissolution (fines/imprisonment), notice and show cause for cancellations, appeals, and certificate return requirements enforce compliance while providing fairness, as per sections 14, 21, 22, 24.
In a scenario where a union's name is too similar to an existing one and it has unlawful objects, what steps would the Registrar take?

Require name alteration (refusing until changed), and refuse registration on unlawful objects ground with written notification, leading to deemed dissolution and potential offences for continued acting, as per sections 20-21.
How does the Act handle post-registration issues like loss of independence or improper accounts through cancellation?

Registrar gives notice, opportunity to show cause (possibly inquiry), then applies to Court specifying grounds like independence loss or improper accounts; if ordered, cancellation results in loss of rights, fund disposal, certificate return, and offences for non-compliance, as per section 22-24.
Describe the full appeal process for a refused registration application.

Aggrieved party appeals to Industrial Court within 30 days; Court makes order (possibly registration) with costs directions; Registrar heard; further appeal to Court of Appeal possible; dismissal deems dissolution, governed by Chief Justice rules, as per section 23.
What complex consequences follow if a registered union fails to dissolve after cancellation order?

Loss of rights/privileges (liabilities remain), required fund disposal, certificate return within time (extendable), prohibition on management except proceedings/dissolution, and offences (fines/imprisonment) for union/officers if not complied, enforcing finality, as per section 24.
Analyse how Part III balances administrative efficiency with procedural fairness.

Efficiency through Registrar powers (requests, refusals, cancellations) and timelines, balanced by written grounds, notice periods, show cause opportunities, inquiries, appeals to courts, and exceptions for proceedings, ensuring regulation without arbitrariness, as per Part III.
In a complex case where a union becomes employer-controlled and has improper accounts, outline the cancellation procedure.

Registrar issues one month notice specifying grounds (independence loss, improper accounts); union shows cause; inquiry if needed; if unsatisfied, files Court application with grounds served; Court decides; if cancelled, consequences under section 24 apply, as per section 22.
Explain the interaction between Registrar discretion and judicial oversight in Part III.

Registrar has broad discretion (information requests, name requirements, refusals, voluntary cancellations, inquiries), but serious cancellations require Court, refusals/cancellations appealable, ensuring checks on power through judicial review, as per sections 19-23.
How does the registration framework in Part III support the fundamental rights in Part II?

By mandating registration for legal operation while protecting against arbitrary denial through grounds, appeals, and fairness procedures, enabling exercise of association rights with legitimacy and protections, linking Parts II and III.
What would happen if a federation of 3 small unions applies without individual registration?
If component unions unregistered or below size, likely refusal as not complying or branch issue, requiring proper underlying registration, as per sections 15 and 21.
Analyse the public transparency measures in cancellation processes.
Gazette/media notice for cessation cases, written notice with grounds for Court applications, service on union, fostering accountability and awareness, as per section 22.
In a scenario of continuing offence after refusal, what escalating penalties apply?
Initial fine up to 500,000, plus 10,000 daily continuing, or imprisonment minimum 3 months, deterring persistent violation, as per section 21(3).
How does the Act protect officials while maintaining accountability?
Immunity for good faith non-negligent acts encourages duty performance, but no protection for negligence, balancing protection with responsibility, as per section 13.
Explain the evidentiary and administrative role of the register and certificate.

Register records details/changes for official reference; certified copies presumptive proof; certificate conclusive of registration, facilitating legal recognition and transactions, as per sections 16 and 18.
What complex interplay exists between voluntary dissolution and forced cancellation?

Voluntary simpler with verification and notice; forced for breaches requires detailed process with safeguards, both leading to similar consequences under section 24, allowing orderly or corrective exits.
If a union appeals successfully after refusal, what can the Court order?
Registration or other proper order, including costs, reversing Registrar decision, as per section 23(1).
How are member interests protected on cancellation?
Funds disposed per constitution preferably, or Registrar directions; liabilities enforceable but rights lost, preserving assets for members, as per section 24(1).
What if Registrar allows extended time but union still fails?
Offence triggers with fines/imprisonment for non-dissolution/certificate return, as per section 24(2).
Analyse why branches of unregistered entities cannot register.
Prevents indirect legitimacy for non-compliant parent bodies, maintaining registration integrity, as per section 21(1)(d).
How does the Act ensure name uniqueness?
Registrar discretion to require change if identical, similar (deceptive), or misleading, preventing public/member confusion, as per section 20.
What if a union wilfully contravenes after notice?
Ground for cancellation, showing serious non-compliance, as per section 22(3)(f).
Explain the show cause mechanism's fairness.
Written response within month, possible inquiry, prevents abrupt cancellation, as per section 22(5).
In complex multi-ground cancellation, what must application include?
Brief specification of all grounds, served, ensuring union knows case, as per section 22(7).
How does appeal dismissal affect status?
Immediate deemed dissolution from dismissal, finalising refusal, as per section 23(5).
What exceptions allow post-cancellation activity?
Only defending/bringing proceedings or dissolving/disposing funds, limiting to winding up, as per section 24(1)(d).
Analyse liability persistence post-cancellation.
Rights/immunities lost but liabilities remain enforceable against assets, preventing avoidance of obligations, as per section 24(1)(a).
How does Part III facilitate orderly union lifecycle?
From mandatory registration for legitimacy, through monitoring/changes, to voluntary or forced dissolution with fund protection, providing structure from formation to end.
What if a union ignores show cause notice?
Registrar can proceed to Court application after period, as per section 22(6).
Explain Registrar's role in voluntary dissolution.
Verifies request, issues public notice, cancels upon satisfaction, as per section 22(1)-(2).
In what way does the register support legal certainty?
Central official record with presumptive certified proof, as per section 16.
How are different entity types treated?
Unions (20+), employers' orgs (5+), federations separately eligible, tailored thresholds, as per section 15.
What if additional information reveals issues?
Can lead to refusal on grounds, as per sections 19 and 21.
Explain multi-trade union special requirement.
Constitution must protect respective interests, preventing dominance, as per section 21(1)(c).
What verification for cessation cancellation?
Registrar satisfied union no longer exists, with public notice, as per section 22(1)(b).
How does inquiry enhance decision-making?
Allows fact-finding in contested cases, as per section 22(5).
What costs consideration in appeals?
Court can direct, possibly against losing party, as per section 23(1).
Explain fund disposal preference.
Per union constitution first, member-democratic, fallback Registrar, as per section 24(1)(b).
What if extended time still exceeded?
Offence triggers, as per section 24(2).
How does immunity encourage officials?
Protects from frivolous suits for proper duties, as per section 13.
What evidence must the Registrar provide when applying to court for cancellation under section 22(3)?

**Evidentiary Requirements for Cancellation Application**:

1. **Section 22(7)**: Application must 'specify briefly the grounds for the cancellation'

2. **Supporting Evidence Likely Required**:
   - For independence loss (22(3)(a)): Evidence of employer control/funding
   - For unlawful objects (22(3)(c)): Constitution excerpts, activity records
   - For unlawful use (22(3)(e)): Evidence of illegal activities
   - For violations after notice (22(3)(f)): Copy of notice, proof of continued violation
   - For improper accounts (22(3)(g)): Financial records, audit reports
   
3. **Procedural Evidence**:
   - Proof of section 22(4) notice service
   - Union's response (or lack thereof) under section 22(5)
   - Inquiry records if held under section 22(5)

4. **Court's Role**: Will examine whether Registrar is 'satisfied' as required by section 22(3) opening phrase

5. **Union's Rights**: Can present contrary evidence, challenge Registrar's satisfaction

**Standard**: Likely balance of probabilities, given civil nature of cancellation.
How can a union prove it has 'ceased to exist' to request voluntary cancellation under section 22(1)(a)?

**Proving Cessation of Existence for Section 22(1) Cancellation**:

**Evidence Requirements**:
1. **Section 22(1)(a)**: 'to be verified in such manner as the Registrar may require'
2. **Registrar's Discretion**: Determines verification method

**Likely Evidence**:
- **Formal Resolution**: Minutes showing dissolution decision per constitution
- **Membership Records**: Showing no active members
- **Financial Records**: Bank statements showing no activity
- **Activity Records**: No meetings, events, or operations
- **Officer Statements**: Affidavits from last officials
- **Public Notice**: Evidence of dissolution announcement to members

**Registrar's Verification Process**:
1. May request specific documents
2. Could conduct inquiry
3. Might require statutory declarations
4. Could verify with members/creditors

**Section 22(2) Notice**: Even voluntary cancellation requires 3 months' gazette/media notice

**Practical Tip**: Union should contact Registrar for specific verification requirements before submitting request.
What happens if the Registrar makes a procedural error in cancellation proceedings?

**Consequences of Procedural Errors in Cancellation**:

**Key Procedural Requirements**:
1. **Section 22(4)**: One month written notice with grounds
2. **Section 22(5)**: Opportunity to show cause
3. **Section 22(7)**: Application served on union

**Error Scenarios & Remedies**:

**1. Inadequate Notice**:
- Failure to specify grounds under section 22(4)
- **Remedy**: Union could challenge in Court response
- **Effect**: Court might dismiss application or require proper notice

**2. No Show Cause Opportunity**:
- Denying section 22(5) right
- **Remedy**: Judicial review or appeal under section 23
- **Effect**: Procedural fairness violation

**3. Defective Service**:
- Failure to serve application under section 22(7)
- **Remedy**: Challenge service validity
- **Effect**: Might invalidate proceedings

**4. No Inquiry When Cause Shown**:
- Section 22(5): 'shall hold such inquiry'
- **Remedy**: Argue mandatory duty breached

**Court's Approach**:
- Likely requires strict compliance with mandatory procedures
- Might invalidate cancellation for serious procedural breaches
- Balance: Substance vs. procedure

**Union's Strategy**:
1. Document all procedural errors
2. Raise in Court response to cancellation application
3. Consider separate judicial review if available

**Prevention**: Registrar should follow procedures meticulously to avoid challenges.
Who do the UDOM undergraduate regulations apply to upon approval?
The UDOM undergraduate regulations apply to all continuing and prospective undergraduate students at the University of Dodoma upon approval by the Council, as per section 1.1.
Where can prospective UDOM students find minimum entry requirements?

Prospective UDOM students can find minimum entry requirements in the Undergraduate Admission Guidebook prepared annually by TCU, accessible through the TCU website at www.tcu.go.tz, as per section 2.1.
What is the short title and commencement of the Labour Relations Act?
The short title of the Act is the Labour Relations Act 2005, and it shall come into operation on such date as the Minister shall by notice published in the gazette, appoint, as per section 1.
To whom does the Labour Relations Act apply?

The Act applies to all employees engaged to work in Zanzibar, all employers who engage employees described under paragraph (a), and does not apply to Judges and all Judiciary officers, Members of Special Departments, Employees of the House of Representatives, notwithstanding any law to the contrary the Act shall apply to the Free Economic Zones with such restrictions as the Minister in consultation with the Labour Advisory Board shall by regulation prescribe, and unless expressly excluded the provisions of Part I to VI of this Act apply equally to trade unions and employers organisations, as per section 2.
What are the basic employee's rights outlined in the Act?
The basic employee's rights include the right to fair remuneration, safe working environment, equal opportunity, and protection from discrimination, as per section 4.
What protections are provided for basic employee's rights in respect of freedom of association?
Every employee has the right to form, join, or participate in the activities of a trade union, and no employer shall discriminate against an employee for exercising this right, as per section 5.
What is the basic employer's right according to the Act?
Every employer has the right to form and join an employers' organisation and to participate in its lawful activities, as per section 6.
What protections are there for employers' and employees' basic rights?
No person shall discriminate against an employer or employee for exercising any right conferred by this Act or participating in any proceedings under this Act, as per section 7.
What is the protection for trade unions against interference?
No person shall interfere with the lawful activities of a trade union, including inducing members to resign or preventing formation, as per section 8.
What are federations according to the Act?
Federations mean any combination or association of two or more trade unions or employers' associations, as per section 9.
What remedies are available for infringement of freedom of association?
Any person whose freedom of association is infringed may apply to the Court for remedies including injunctions and compensation, as per section 11.
Who appoints the Registrar and officials for trade unions?
The Minister appoints the Registrar and officials for trade unions, as per section 12.
What protections are there for officials of trade unions?
Officials of trade unions are protected from civil suits for acts done in good faith on behalf of the union, as per section 13.
What entities must apply for registration under the Act?

Unregistered trade unions with 20 or more members, federations of such unions, and employers' organisations with five or more members must apply for registration within six months of formation, as per section 15.
What is required in the constitution of every trade union or organisation?
The constitution must provide for matters such as name, purposes, contributions, elections, ballots, accounts, and dissolution, as per section 28 and the Schedule.
What are the organizational rights for trade unions at the workplace?
Every employer must permit trade union activities at the workplace, including establishing branches, conducting meetings, and entering premises to recruit or serve members, as per section 50.
What is the right to collective bargaining under the Act?
The right to collective bargaining applies to all employees not excluded, such as public officers in administration or senior management, as per section 54.
What is the short title and commencement of the Labour Relations Act?
The short title of the Act is the Labour Relations Act 2005, and it shall come into operation on such date as the Minister shall by notice published in the gazette, appoint, as per section 1.
To whom does the Labour Relations Act apply?

The Act applies to all employees engaged to work in Zanzibar, all employers who engage employees described under paragraph (a), and does not apply to Judges and all Judiciary officers, Members of Special Departments, Employees of the House of Representatives, notwithstanding any law to the contrary the Act shall apply to the Free Economic Zones with such restrictions as the Minister in consultation with the Labour Advisory Board shall by regulation prescribe, and unless expressly excluded the provisions of Part I to VI of this Act apply equally to trade unions and employers organisations, as per section 2.
What are the basic employee's rights outlined in the Act?

Every employee shall have the right to take part in the formation of a trade union or federation of trade unions, be a member of a trade union of his or her choice, participate in lawful activities of a trade union, participate in a lawful strike, fair remuneration, reasonable working conditions, fair treatment and equal opportunity, and protection from unfair dismissal, among others, as per section 4.
What protections are provided for basic employee's rights in respect of freedom of association?

No employer shall require an employee not to be or become a member of any trade union, prejudice him or her because of trade union membership or activities, or threaten him or her to induce membership changes, as per section 5.
What is the basic employer's right according to the Act?

Every employer has the right to take part in the formation of an employers’ organisation or federation of employers’ organisations, be a member of an employers’ organisation, participate in lawful activities of an employers’ organisation, and participate in a lawful lock-out, as per section 6.
What protections are there for employers' and employees' basic rights?

Any person who is eligible under the constitution of a trade union or organisation has a right to membership and to participate in its lawful activities, and no person shall discriminate against an employer or employee for exercising rights under this Act, as per section 7.
What is the protection for trade unions against interference?

No employer or employers' organisation shall interfere with, restrain or coerce employees in the exercise of their rights, interfere with the formation or registration of any trade union, or terminate employment for trade union activities, as per section 8.
What are federations according to the Act?

A federation means any combination or association of two or more trade unions which have a separate legal existence from the trade unions of which they are comprised, and trade unions and employers' organisations may form and join federations, as per section 3(2) and section 9.
What remedies are available for infringement of freedom of association?
Any complaint of infringement may be presented to the Labour Court, which may make orders for compliance, including reinstatement and compensation for losses suffered, as per section 11.
Who appoints the Registrar and officials for trade unions?
The Minister shall appoint a Registrar of trade unions and employers organisations and such other officials as may be required, as per section 12.
What protections are there for officials of trade unions?
No suit shall lie against any officer appointed under section 12 for anything done or omitted in good faith and without negligence in the exercise of duties under this Act, as per section 13.
What entities must apply for registration under the Act?

Any unregistered trade union with not less than 20 members, federation of such trade unions, unregistered employers' organisation with not less than five members, or federation of such employers' organisations must apply for registration within six months after its formation, as per section 15.
What is required in the constitution of every trade union or organisation?

The constitution shall provide for all matters specified in the Schedule, including name and address, purposes, membership qualifications, contributions, elections, ballots, accounts, and dissolution, as per section 28 and the Schedule.
What are the organizational rights for trade unions at the workplace?

Every employer is required to permit the activities of trade union at the work place, including establishing and maintaining branches, conducting meetings during non-working hours, and entering the work premises to recruit new members and serve the interests of its members, as per section 50.
What is the right to collective bargaining under the Act?

The right to collective bargaining shall apply to all employees not excluded under this Act, such as public officers in the administration, senior management, and confidential capacity, as per section 54.
What is the short title of the Act?
The Act may be cited as the Labour Relations Act 2005, as per section 1(1).
When does the Act come into operation?
The Act shall come into operation on such date as the Minister shall by notice published in the gazette, appoint, as per section 1(1).
Can the Minister defer the operation of parts of the Act?
The Minister may defer the coming into operation of any part or provision of this Act for a period not exceeding twelve months from the commencement date, as per section 1(2).
What happens to deferred provisions after twelve months?
The provision whose operation is deferred shall become operational on the date appointed by the Minister or after the expiry of twelve months whichever comes earlier, as per section 1(3).

This Act may be cited as the Labour Relations Act 2005 and shall come into operation on such date as the Minister shall by notice published in the gazette, appoint, as per section 1(1).

How should the Act be interpreted?

Interpretation of this Act shall be made in a manner that will give effect to obligation of Zanzibar under various International Labour treaties to which the United Republic of Tanzania as a member State of the International Labour Organisation has ratified, as per section 3(1).
What is the definition of 'contract of employment' in the Act?

'contract of employment' any contract whether in writing or oral, whether express or implied, to employ or to serve as an employee for any period of time or number of days to be worked, or to execute any task or piece of work or to perform any journey and includes a foreign contract of service;, as per section 3(2).
What is the definition of 'Court' in the Act?
'Court' the Industrial Court established under this Act; 10, as per section 3(2).
What is the definition of 'employee' in the Act?

'employee' any person who has entered into or works under a contract of service with an employer whether by way of manual labour, clerical work or otherwise and whether the contract is expressed or implied or is oral or in writing, and shall include any such person in the employment of the Government or of any local authority or private sector or any apprentice and learner who has entered into or works under any agreement whether expressed or implied or whether oral or in writing;, as per section 3(2).
What is the definition of 'employer' in the Act?

'employer' any person, or any firm, corporation or company, public authority or body of persons who or which has entered into a contract of service to employ any person and includes the Government;, as per section 3(2).
What is the definition of 'employers' organisation' in the Act?

'employers' organisation' any association of employers the principal purposes of which are the representation of employers' interests and the regulation of relations between employers and employees, and includes a federation of employers’ organisation;, as per section 3(2).
What is the definition of 'essential service' in the Act?

'essential service' any service, whether rendered by the Government or any other body or person, the interruption of which is likely to endanger the life, health or personal safety of the whole or part of the population, and includes services mentioned under section 64(2) of this Act;, as per section 3(2).
What is the definition of 'executive' in the Act?
'executive' the body entrusted with the 11 management of the affairs of the trade union or employers' association;, as per section 3(2).
What is the definition of 'federation' in the Act?
'federation' any combination or association of two or more trade unions which have a separate legal existence from the trade unions of which they are comprised;, as per section 3(2).
What is the definition of 'labour dispute' in the Act?

'labour dispute' any dispute or difference between an employer or employers and employees, or between employees and employees, connected with employment or non employment, or the terms or employment, or with the condition of labour, of any person, or with the economic and social interests of workers;, as per section 3(2).
What is the definition of 'local authority' in the Act?
'local authority' and includes a city council, a municipal council, town council, local council and District council;, as per section 3(2).
What is the definition of 'lock-out' in the Act?

'lock-out' any action taken by an employer in contemplation or furtherance of a labour dispute which consist in the exclusion of a group of employees from a place of employment, the suspension of employment or work of a group of employees or a refusal to continue to employ a group of employees; 12, as per section 3(2).
What is the definition of 'Minister' in the Act?
'Minister' the Minister responsible for labour;, as per section 3(2).
What is the definition of 'official' in the Act?

'official' when used with reference to a trade union, includes any member of the executive committee thereof and any official of a branch thereof, but does not include a trustee or an auditor;, as per section 3(2).
What is the definition of 'register' in the Act?
'register' the register of trade unions maintained by the Registrar under section 15 of this Act;, as per section 3(2).
What is the definition of 'registered office' in the Act?
'registered office' that office of a trade union which is registered under the provisions of section 29 of this Act;, as per section 3(2).
What is the definition of 'Registrar' in the Act?

'Registrar' the person for the time being appointed by the Minister under the provisions of section 12(1) of this Act by name or by office to be or to act as Registrar of trade unions, and includes any person appointed by the Minister under section 12(2) of this Act to be or to act as an Assistant Registrar of trade unions; 13, as per section 3(2).
What is the definition of 'strike' in the Act?

'strike' the cessation of work by a body of persons employed, acting in combination, or a concerted refusal or a refusal under a common understanding of any number of persons employed to continue to work for an employer in consequence of a trade dispute, done as a means of compelling their employer or any person or body of persons employed, or to aid other employees in compelling their employer, or any persons or body of persons employed, to accept or not to accept terms or conditions of or affecting employment;, as per section 3(2).
What is the definition of 'the Government' in the Act?
'the Government' the Revolutionary Government of Zanzibar, and includes all departments and all services, whether autonomous or semi-autonomous; 14, as per section 3(2).
