What is the short title of the Act?
The Labour Relations Act, 2005.
When was the Act assented to?
5th March, 2005.
Who assented to the Act?
Amani Abeid Karume, President of Zanzibar and Chairman of the Revolutionary Council.
How does the Act commence?
On a date appointed by the Minister by notice in the Gazette.
Can provisions be deferred?
Yes, for up to twelve months.
To whom does the Act apply?
All employees engaged to work in Zanzibar and their employers.
Who is excluded from the Act?
Judges, judicial officers, members of Special Departments, and employees of the House of Representatives.
How must the Act be interpreted?
In a manner that gives effect to obligations under ratified International Labour Organisation treaties.
What is the definition of 'award'?
Agreement after mediation, arbitrator's decision, or Court decision.
What is a 'bargaining unit'?
The level at which collective bargaining takes place.
What is a 'branch' of a trade union?
Members with a committee managing branch affairs.
What is an 'employee'?
Person working under a contract of service, including apprentices.
What is an 'employer'?
Person or entity that employs others under a contract of service.
What is an 'essential service'?
Service whose interruption endangers life, health, or safety.
What is a 'strike'?
Concerted cessation or refusal of work to compel demands.
What is a 'lock-out'?
Employer action closing workplace to compel terms.
Do employees have freedom of association?
Yes, right to form and join trade unions.
Is interference with trade unions prohibited?
Yes.
Can trade unions affiliate internationally?
Yes.
Must trade unions register?
Yes.
What status does registration give?
Body corporate with perpetual succession.
What is member liability limited to?
Subscriptions and written pledges.
What must a union constitution contain?
Matters listed in the Schedule.
Must unions have a registered office?
Yes.
Can unions amalgamate?
Yes, with proper ballot.
What approval is needed for immovable property disposal?
Majority at general meeting.
Can union funds pay member fines?
No.
Must accounts be audited?
Yes, annually.
Must employers allow union activities?
Yes.
Can union officials enter workplace?
Yes, with notice.
Can employees authorise deductions?
Yes, for subscriptions.
What is an agency shop agreement?
Deduction of fee from non-members.
Is leave for union activities allowed?
Yes.
Is collective bargaining a right?
Yes.
Is there a right to strike?
Yes, subject to procedures.
Is there a Zanzibar Industrial Court?
Yes.
Can the Court make retrospective awards?
Yes.
Can Minister make regulations?
Yes.
What is the overall balance in Part VI?
Strong union rights with reasonable employer protections and safeguards.
How many moderate Q&A for Part VI?
Approximately 70 moderate-level pairs covering organisational rights comprehensively.
What are the main organisational rights in Part VI?
Workplace access, deduction of subscriptions, agency shop agreements, and leave for union activities.
What limitation applies to rights in the domestic sector?
No entry into employer's home without agreement.
What conditions can be attached to organisational rights?
Reasonable conditions on time, place, and manner for safety and non-disruption.
What additional rights do representative trade unions have?
Representation on health/safety, productivity consultation, monitoring compliance.
How long is the notice period for revoking deduction authorisation?
Three months.
What majority is needed for a valid agency shop agreement?
More than 50% membership in the bargaining unit.
Can agency shop agreements compel membership?
No.
Is negotiation time considered paid leave?
Yes, deemed paid.
What is a representative trade union in Part VI?
One recognised under section 57.
How does Part VI support freedom of association?
By providing practical workplace mechanisms for union organisation and representation.
What balance does Part VI strike?
Strong union rights balanced with employer protections and reasonable safeguards.
What is the short title of this Act?
Labour Relations Act 2005, as per Section 1(1).
When does this Act come into operation?
On a date appointed by the Minister by notice in the gazette, per Section 1(1).
To whom does this Act apply?
To all employees working in Zanzibar and their employers, per Section 2(1).
Who is excluded from this Act?
Judges, judiciary officers, members of special departments, and employees of the House of Representatives, per Section 2(2).
What fundamental right does every employee have?
The right to form and join trade unions, per Section 4(1).
Can an employer prevent an employee from joining a union?
No, per Section 5(1)(a).
What is the penalty for infringing freedom of association?
The Court may order reinstatement, restoration of benefits, and compensation, per Section 11(3).
Who appoints the Registrar?
The Minister, per Section 12(1).
Are trade unions required to register?
Yes, within six months of formation, per Section 14(2).
What is the minimum membership for a trade union registration?
20 members, per Section 15(1)(a).
What is the minimum membership for an employers' organization registration?
5 members, per Section 15(1)(c).
Can a trade union be registered if its name is misleading?
No, the Registrar can require alteration of the name, per Section 20.
What happens if registration is refused?
The trade union is deemed dissolved, per Section 21(2).
How can registration be cancelled?
By the Registrar on specified grounds, per Section 22.
Is there an appeal against refusal of registration?
Yes, to the Court within 30 days, per Section 23(1).
What is the legal status of a registered trade union?
It is a body corporate with perpetual succession, per Section 25(1).
What is the liability of a union member?
Limited to unpaid subscriptions and written pledges, per Section 26.
Who can be a member of a trade union?
Any person aged 17+ engaged in the trade, per Section 27(1) and (3).
Can a minor be on the executive committee?
No, per Section 27(4).
What must a union's constitution contain?
All matters specified in the Schedule, per Section 28(1).
Must a trade union have a registered office?
Yes, per Section 29(1).
What is the penalty for operating without a registered office?
A fine up to 20,000 shillings per day, per Section 29(3).
Can trade unions amalgamate?
Yes, with approval by secret ballot, per Section 31.
What notice is required for a name change?
Written notice to the Registrar within one month, per Section 33(1).
Does a name change affect legal proceedings?
No, per Section 34(1).
Must unions hold annual general meetings?
Yes, per Section 35(1).
How is a union dissolved?
By resolution at a general meeting, per Section 36(1).
What happens to union property upon dissolution?
It is disposed of according to the constitution, per Section 36(3).
What declaration is required upon dissolution?
Declaration of assets and claims, per Section 37.
Is gazette notification required for dissolution?
Yes, per Section 38.
How is union property managed?
By trustees according to the constitution, per Section 39(1).
What is the liability limit upon dissolution?
Limited to net asset value, per Section 39(2).
Can union immovable property be sold?
Yes, with majority approval at a meeting, per Section 40(1).
How can union funds be used?
For specified purposes like salaries, administration, legal proceedings, etc., per Section 41(2).
Can union funds pay members' fines?
No, per Section 42(1).
What financial records must unions keep?
Books of account showing all transactions, per Section 43.
When must annual returns be submitted?
By March 31st each year, per Section 45(1).
Can the Registrar inspect union records?
Yes, per Section 46(1).
What is the penalty for obstructing the Registrar?
A fine up to 200,000 shillings, per Section 46(2).
Can members seek an injunction against officials?
Yes, if 25% of members or the Registrar applies, per Section 47.
How is legal process served on a union?
On the chairman, treasurer, secretary, or at the registered office, per Section 48.
Who can make regulations under this Act?
The Minister, per Section 49(1).
Must employers permit union activities at work?
Yes, per Section 50(1).
What union activities are allowed at work?
Establishing branches and holding lawful meetings, per Section 50(2).
Can union officials enter the workplace?
Yes, with reasonable notice, per Section 50(3).
What functions does a representative union perform?
Representation on health, safety, productivity, etc., per Section 50(4).
Are there limits to union access rights?
Yes, reasonable conditions apply, per Section 50(5).
Can a union enter an employer's home?
Not in the domestic sector without consent, per Section 50(6).
Can employers deduct union subscriptions?
Yes, with employee authorization, per Section 51(1).
How quickly must remittances be made?
As soon as possible, before next salary payment, per Section 51(2).
How can authorization be revoked?
By giving three months' notice, per Section 51(3).
Can employers charge deduction fees?
No, unless agreed in collective agreements, per Section 51(4).
What is an agency shop agreement?
An agreement to deduct fees from non-members, per Section 52(1).
When is it valid?
When over 50% of the unit are union members, per Section 52(2).
What is the maximum agency fee?
Equal to or less than member subscriptions, per Section 52(3).
How must agency fees be managed?
In a separate bank account, per Section 52(4).
Can agency fees fund non-union purposes?
No, per Section 52(5).
On what grounds can it be objected?
Illegality or discrimination, per Section 52(6).
Can the Court cancel an agency shop agreement?
Yes, for non-compliance, per Section 52(8).
Can union office bearers take leave?
Yes, reasonable paid leave, per Section 53(1) and (3).
Must notice be given for union leave?
Yes, reasonable notice, per Section 53(4).
Who has the right to collective bargaining?
All employees not excluded, per Section 54(1).
Who is excluded from collective bargaining?
Public officers, senior managers, and others specified, per Section 54(2).
What can be bargained collectively?
Work conditions, employment terms, relations, etc., per Section 55.
At what levels can bargaining occur?
Enterprise, industry/sector, or national level, per Section 56(1).
Who has exclusive bargaining rights?
The representative trade union, per Section 57(1).
What is a representative trade union?
One representing the majority at the bargaining level, per Section 57(2).
Must employers disclose information for bargaining?
Yes, relevant information, per Section 58(1).
What information need not be disclosed?
Legally privileged, confidential, or private information, per Section 58(2).
Is there a duty to bargain in good faith?
Yes, per Section 59(1).
What does good faith bargaining include?
Efforts to reach agreement, genuine negotiation, avoiding delays, per Section 59(2).
Are collective agreements binding?
Yes, on parties and represented employees, per Section 60.
Must collective agreements be registered?
Yes, with the Court, per Section 61(1).
When can the Court refuse registration?
If unenforceable or inconsistent with law, per Section 61(6).
Is a strike ballot required?
Yes, by secret ballot, per Section 62(1).
Can a ballot be nullified?
Yes, for fraud or unfairness, per Section 62(3).
Do employees have the right to strike?
Yes, subject to conditions, per Section 63(1).
What conditions apply to strikes?
Dispute of interest, exhausted procedures, notice given, per Section 63(2).
Who cannot strike?
Essential service workers, managers, etc., per Section 64.
What are essential services?
Water, electricity, health, air traffic, fire, transport, per Section 64(2).
Can unlawful strikes be restrained?
Yes, by Court injunction, per Section 65(1).
Are striking employees protected?
Yes, if lawful, per Section 66(1).
Must strikers be paid?
No, per Section 66(2).
What is a secondary strike?
A strike in support of another enterprise's employees, per Section 67.
Can replacement labour be used during strikes?
Only for maintenance services as per regulations, per Section 68.
What is protest action?
Lawful action called by a registered union, per Section 69.
Is picketing allowed?
Yes, for peaceful demonstration, per Section 70(1).
What constitutes intimidation?
Violence, threats, property damage, etc., per Section 71(1).
What is the penalty for intimidation?
Fine up to 100,000 shillings or imprisonment, per Section 71(1).
What is the Dispute Handling Unit?
A special unit under the Commission for labour disputes, per Section 72(1).
Where are disputes first filed?
With the Unit, per Section 73(1).
What is the mediation period?
30 working days, extendable, per Section 74(2).
What happens if mediation fails?
A certificate of unresolved dispute is issued, per Section 74(4).
What recourse exists after failed mediation?
Arbitration or industrial action, per Section 75.
Is arbitration compulsory for essential services?
Yes, for disputes of interest, per Section 75(1)(a).
Can the Court assist in mediation?
Yes, per Section 76.
What if a party fails to attend mediation?
Various consequences apply, per Section 77.
What is the Tripartite Committee?
A committee advising on dispute resolution, per Section 78.
Who can represent parties in mediation?
As agreed or ordered, per Section 79(1).
What is the Zanzibar Industrial Court?
A division of the High Court for labour disputes, per Section 80(1).
What is the Court's jurisdiction?
Hearing labour disputes, registering agreements, etc., per Section 80(2).
Who composes the Court?
A presiding judge and two assessors, per Section 81(1).
How is the Court constituted?
With a judge and at least one assessor, per Section 83.
What are the Court's functions?
Inquiring into disputes, hearing submissions, etc., per Section 84.
Can awards be retrospective?
Yes, per Section 85.
How are awards interpreted?
By application to the Court, per Section 86.
Is there appeal from the Court?
Yes, to the Court of Appeal, per Section 87(1).
Are rules of evidence binding?
No, per Section 88(1).
Can parties be represented by advocates?
Yes, per Section 89(1).
Are Court members protected?
Yes, for bona fide acts, per Section 90(1).
Are Court proceedings public?
Yes, but can be in camera, per Section 91.
Must the Court report to the Minister?
Yes, per Section 92.
What constitutes contempt of Court?
Disobeying orders, disrespect, etc., per Section 93.
What is the penalty for contempt?
Imprisonment up to 3 months, per Section 93.
Is there summary procedure for contempt?
Yes, per Section 94.
Do assessors get sitting allowances?
Yes, per Section 95.
Are Court fees payable?
Yes, as per rules, per Section 96.
Who prosecutes offences?
The Director of Public Prosecutions, per Section 97(1).
Which court tries offences?
Regional Magistrate Court, per Section 97(2).
What are some offences under this Act?
Operating unregistered unions, recruiting for them, infringing rights, per Section 98.
What is the penalty for offences?
Fine up to 400,000 shillings or imprisonment, per Section 98.
Can the Minister make regulations?
Yes, per Section 99.
Which Acts are repealed?
Trade Unions Act 2001 and Industrial Court Act 1994, per Section 100(1).
What transitional provisions exist?
Existing registrations continue, pending matters handled accordingly, per Section 100(2).
What must be in a union constitution?
Name, purposes, funds, contributions, fines, etc., per Schedule.
When was this Act passed?
January 19, 2005, per last page.
Explain the Minister's power to defer commencement of provisions under Section 1(2).

The Minister may defer the operation of any part or provision of the Act for up to 12 months from the commencement date. The deferred provision becomes operational either on the date appointed by the Minister or after 12 months, whichever is earlier.
How does the Act apply to Free Economic Zones?
The Act applies to Free Economic Zones with restrictions prescribed by the Minister in consultation with the Labour Advisory Board, notwithstanding any contrary law.
Interpret the definition of 'employee' under Section 3(2).

'Employee' means any person working under a contract of service, whether manual, clerical, expressed/implied, oral/written, including government employees, local authority employees, private sector employees, apprentices, and learners.
What constitutes a 'labour dispute'?
Any dispute between employers and employees, or between employees, connected with employment/non-employment, terms of employment, conditions of labour, or economic and social interests of workers.
Define 'essential service' as per the Act.

Any service whose interruption endangers life, health, or personal safety of the population, including water, sanitation, electricity, health services, air traffic control, fire services, and necessary transport services.
What protections exist for employees exercising union rights?
Employers cannot require employees to relinquish membership, discriminate, threaten, or take prejudicial action against them for union activities or exercising rights under the Act.
Explain the consequences of a union constitution containing discriminatory provisions.

Any provision that discriminates on grounds of race, color, national extraction, social origin, religion, political opinion, sex, marital status, family responsibilities, age, or disability is unlawful under Section 7(4).
What is the role of the Registrar in union registration?
The Registrar examines applications, may require further particulars or name changes, and can refuse registration if requirements aren't met. They also maintain the register and issue certificates.
Describe the grounds for cancellation of registration.

Grounds include: union ceasing to be independent, unlawful objects, unlawful constitution, use for unlawful purposes, contravention of Act provisions, improper accounts, or being a branch of an unregistered union.
What happens to union rights after cancellation of registration?
The union loses all rights, immunities, and privileges of registration but remains liable for existing obligations. It must be dissolved and its funds disposed of according to its constitution.
Explain the membership eligibility criteria for trade unions.
Must reside in Tanzania, be engaged in the trade (or formerly engaged for 18+ months, elected to office, or seeking employment), and be 17+ years old. Minors cannot serve on executive committees.
What are the requirements for union amalgamation?
Requires a secret ballot with at least 50% of eligible members voting, and approval by a margin of 20% or more of total votes cast.
How does federation with Tanzania Mainland unions work?
A Zanzibar federation may join with a Mainland federation to form a union. It must register under this Act but isn't considered a separate entity due to dual registration.
Explain the financial accountability requirements for unions.
Unions must keep proper books, have accounts audited annually by March 31st, submit annual returns, and allow Registrar inspection. Officers must render true accounts of all monies.
What is the purpose of the agency fee in agency shop agreements?
To require non-member employees who benefit from union representation to contribute financially to the union's costs, without compelling membership.
Analyze the difference between disputes of interest and disputes of right.
Disputes of interest involve creating new rights or terms (subject to strike/lockout), while disputes of right involve enforcing existing rights (subject to arbitration/adjudication).
What procedural safeguards exist for lawful strikes?
Requirements include: dispute of interest, exhaustion of dispute resolution, strike ballot, prior notice (48 hours generally, 7 days for government), and compliance with union rules.
Explain the concept of 'maintenance service' during strikes.
A service whose interruption causes material physical destruction to work areas, plant, or machinery. Replacement labour may be engaged for such services during strikes under regulations.
What distinguishes protest action from strikes?

Protest action is for broader social/economic issues (not specific employment disputes), requires union calling, mediation attempt, and 14 days' notice. It's treated like strike for employment protection.
Describe the dispute resolution hierarchy under Part IX.

1. Filing with Unit → 2. Mediation (30 days) → 3. If unresolved: arbitration (compulsory for essential services/rights disputes) or industrial action (for interest disputes) → 4. Court adjudication if arbitration fails or for legal interpretation.
What are the Court's powers regarding evidence?
The Court isn't bound by formal evidence rules, can elicit necessary information, require particulars/document production, summon witnesses, but cannot compel self-incriminating evidence.
Explain the liability protection for Court members and arbitrators.
No civil/criminal liability for bona fide acts/omissions in exercising functions. They cannot be summoned to give evidence about information learned in their capacity.
What constitutes a valid collective agreement under Section 60?
Binds: (1) employer and union members in the unit; (2) non-members if majority are members; (3) all members of multi-employer organizations. Remains binding for agreement period and to new members.
Analyze the good faith bargaining requirements.
Requires: making every effort to reach agreement, engaging in genuine/constructive negotiation, avoiding unjustified delays. This implies substantive engagement, not just procedural compliance.
What are the implications of the Act's interpretation clause referencing ILO treaties?

The Act must be interpreted to give effect to Tanzania's ILO obligations, meaning ILO conventions ratified by Tanzania (like freedom of association, collective bargaining) inform the Act's interpretation and application.
Explain the constitutional requirements for union governance.

Must provide for: name/address, purposes, fund use, contributions, fines, amendment process, official election/removal (≤3 year terms), decision-making by ballot, proper accounts, investment rules, dissolution procedures, member voting rights, record-keeping.
What remedies exist for unlawful interference with union rights?
Complaint to Labour Court, which may order: reinstatement, restoration of benefits, compensation for damages, and punitive indemnity. Burden shifts to employer to prove valid reason for action.
Analyze the balance between union independence and political affiliation prohibition.

Unions must be independent from employer domination AND political parties. They cannot be part of any political affiliation while maintaining independence from employer control—ensuring focus on member interests.
What are the procedural requirements for lawful picketing?

Must be: authorized by registered union, peaceful, for supporting lawful strike/persuading support/opposing lockout, held in public places or employer premises with permission, and not involve intimidation.
Explain the Court's role in collective agreement registration.

Court examines agreements for: enforceability, consistency with law, compliance with minimum standards. May register unchanged, with modifications (with party consent), or refuse registration and refer back with instructions.
What are the limitations on secondary strikes?
Must: support a lawful primary strike, give 7 days' notice to secondary employer, be reasonable in justification/impact. Court may restrain if contravening Act or unjustified.
Describe the Tripartite Committee's advisory functions.
Advises on: arbitrator/mediator panels, appointment criteria, professional/ethical standards, Court assessors, monitoring dispute resolution system, and making improvements.
What is the significance of the Court not being bound by assessors' opinions?

While assessors provide expertise from employer/employee perspectives, the judge makes the final decision, ensuring legal correctness while considering practical insights. Disagreements must be recorded with reasons.
Analyze the transitional provisions for previously registered unions.

Unions registered under repealed Acts are deemed registered under this Act from their original registration date, ensuring continuity without re-registration. Pending applications/matters continue under old law but are deemed under new Act.
What is the legal effect of a registered collective agreement?
Once registered, it becomes an award with the same enforceability as a Court decision, binding on all parties and represented employees, and can be enforced as a Court decree.
Who has the right to collective bargaining?
All employees not excluded under the Act, per Section 54(1).
Which employees are excluded from collective bargaining?
Public officers, senior managers, and other categories the Minister may exclude, per Section 54(2).
What can be included in a collective agreement?
Work conditions, employment terms, employer-employee relations, and other agreed matters, per Section 55.
At what levels can collective bargaining take place?
Enterprise, industry/sector, or national level, per Section 56(1).
Who decides the bargaining level?
The employer/employers' organization and trade union(s), per Section 56(2).
Who has exclusive bargaining rights?
The representative trade union, per Section 57(1).
What is a representative trade union?
A registered union representing the majority of employees at the bargaining level, per Section 57(2).
How does a union become recognized as representative?
By raising the issue with the employer, per Section 57(3).
What if the employer doesn't recognize the union?
The matter goes to the disputes resolution authority, per Section 57(4).
Must employers share information for bargaining?
Yes, relevant information, per Section 58(1).
What information can be kept confidential?
Legally privileged, confidential, or personal information, per Section 58(2).
What is the duty to bargain in good faith?
To make every effort to reach agreement, negotiate genuinely, and avoid delays, per Section 59.
Is a collective agreement binding?
Yes, on the employer and union members, per Section 60(1).
Are non-union members bound by agreements?
Yes, if the majority in the unit are union members, per Section 60(2).
How long does an agreement remain binding?
For the whole agreement period, per Section 60(5).
How can an indefinite agreement be terminated?
By giving reasonable written notice, per Section 60(6).
Must collective agreements be registered?
Yes, with the Court, per Section 61(1).
What can the Court do with an agreement?
Register it, modify it (with consent), or refuse registration, per Section 61(4).
What happens after registration?
The agreement becomes an award, per Section 61(5).
When can the Court refuse registration?
If unenforceable or below minimum legal standards, per Section 61(6).
When does an agreement become effective?
From the date appointed by the parties, per Section 61(8).
Does every employee have the right to collective bargaining?
No, some categories are excluded, as per section 54(1)-(2).
Who is excluded from collective bargaining rights?
Public officers in government administration, senior managers, and other categories specified by the Minister, as per section 54(2).
Can the Minister exclude more categories?
Yes, in consultation with the Labour Advisory Board by Gazette notice, as per section 54(2)(c).
What matters can be covered in a collective agreement?
Work conditions, terms of employment, relations between parties, and any other necessary matters, as per section 55.
What are the levels of collective bargaining?
Enterprise, industry/sector, and national level, as per section 56(1).
Who decides the bargaining level?
The employer and trade union(s), case by case or by agreement, as per section 56(2).
What is a representative trade union?
A registered trade union representing the majority of employees at the bargaining level, as per section 57(2).
Does a representative trade union have exclusive bargaining rights?
Yes, as per section 57(1).
How is representative status determined?
Raised with employer; if disputed, referred to dispute resolution authority, as per section 57(3)-(4).
Must employers disclose information for bargaining?
Yes, relevant information to enable effective bargaining, as per section 58(1).
Is there any information employers do not have to disclose?
Yes, legally privileged, prohibited by law, confidential causing harm, or private personal information without consent, as per section 58(2).
What happens if there is a dispute over disclosure?
Referred to the Court, as per section 58(3).
Is there a duty to bargain in good faith?
Yes, for employers and trade unions, as per section 59(1).
What does bargaining in good faith include?
Effort to reach agreement, genuine negotiation, and avoiding unjustified delays, as per section 59(2).
Who is bound by a collective agreement with a single employer?
The employer and members (or deemed represented non-members if majority), as per section 60(1)-(2).
Who is bound by multi-employer agreements?
All members of the entities and represented employees, as per section 60(3).
Does a collective agreement bind new members?
Yes, for the whole period, as per section 60(5).
Can indefinite agreements be terminated?
Yes, with reasonable written notice, as per section 60(6).
Must collective agreements be registered?
Yes, submitted to the Court, as per section 61(1).
What can the Court do with a submitted agreement?
Register without change, with consented modifications, or refuse, as per section 61(4).
When can the Court refuse registration?
If unenforceable, inconsistent with law, or below minimum standards, as per section 61(6).
What is a registered agreement deemed to be?
An award, as per section 61(5).
When does a collective agreement become effective?
From the date appointed by parties, even if modified by Court, as per section 61(8).
Can senior managers bargain collectively?
No, excluded, as per section 54(2)(b).
Can relations between unions and employers be bargained?
Yes, as per section 55(c).
Can national level bargaining occur?
Yes, as per section 56(1)(c).
Must a union have majority to be representative?
Yes, as per section 57(2).
Can personal information be withheld?
Yes, without consent, as per section 58(2)(c).
Must parties avoid delays in bargaining?
Yes, unjustified delays, as per section 59(2)(c).
Are non-members bound if majority?
Yes, deemed represented, as per section 60(2).
Must agreements be submitted to Court?
Yes, for registration, as per section 61(1).
Can the Court modify agreements?
Yes, with parties' consent, as per section 61(4)(b).
What is Part VII about?
Collective bargaining rights, subjects, levels, representation, good faith, and agreement binding/registration.
Can public officers bargain?
No, if engaged in government administration, as per section 54(2)(a).
Can any matter be included in agreements?
Yes, deemed necessary by parties, as per section 55(e).
Can parties agree on bargaining level?
Yes, generally or per case, as per section 56(2).
Must recognition be formal?
Yes, under section 57.
Can confidential information be withheld?
Yes, if substantial harm, as per section 58(2)(b).
Must parties try to reach agreement?
Yes, every effort, as per section 59(2)(a).
Does agreement bind successors?
Yes, new members/represented, as per section 60(5).
Must a copy go to Commission?
Yes, with submission to Court, as per section 61(1).
Can Court refuse if below standards?
Yes, minimum standards, as per section 61(6)(b).
What happens if Court refuses registration?
Refers back to parties with instructions, as per section 61(7).
Can terms of employment be bargained?
Yes, as per section 55(a).
Can enterprise level bargaining happen?
Yes, as per section 56(1)(a).
Must union be registered to be representative?
Yes, as per section 57(2).
Can privileged information be withheld?
Yes, legally privileged, as per section 58(2)(a).
Must negotiations be constructive?
Yes, genuine, as per section 59(2)(b).
Is agreement binding on non-parties?
Only if expressly identified or deemed represented, as per section 60(4).
Must Court keep register?
Yes, as per section 61(2).
Can modifications be made?
Yes, with consent, as per section 61(4)(b).
Is registered agreement an award?
Yes, as per section 61(5).
Can any law matters be included?
Yes, permitted under laws, as per section 55(d).
Can sector level bargaining occur?
Yes, as per section 56(1)(b).
Must majority be at appropriate level?
Yes, bargaining level, as per section 57(2).
Can Court decide disclosure disputes?
Yes, as per section 58(3).
Must parties make effort?
Yes, to agree, as per section 59(2)(a).
Does binding continue for period?
Yes, whole period, as per section 60(5).
Must any party submit?
Yes, to Court, as per section 61(1).
Can Court register without change?
Yes, as per section 61(4)(a).
Can Court refuse if inconsistent?
Yes, with law, as per section 61(6)(a).
What effective date?
Appointed by parties, as per section 61(8).
Can employer and organisation bargain?
Yes, as per section 55.
Can multiple unions bargain?
Yes, as per section 55.
Must recognition be sought?
Yes, raised with employer, as per section 57(3).
Can objection be raised?
Yes, by another union, as per section 57(4).
Must disclose to enable bargaining?
Yes, relevant, as per section 58(1).
Must genuine negotiation?
Yes, as per section 59(2)(b).
Is termination with notice?
Yes, indefinite, as per section 60(6).
Must Court examine agreement?
Yes, as per section 61(3).
Can refuse if not enforceable?

Why are certain categories of employees excluded from collective bargaining rights?

To prevent involvement of public officers in government administration and senior managers in operational decisions, ensuring administrative neutrality and management prerogative, as per section 54(2).
How does the Act provide flexibility in bargaining subjects?
Allows broad coverage including terms, relations, and any matter parties deem necessary or permitted by law, enabling comprehensive agreements, as per section 55.
What flexibility exists in choosing bargaining levels?
Parties can determine level per case or generally agree, accommodating different structures from enterprise to national, as per section 56.
How is majority representation determined for bargaining rights?
Based on majority at the appropriate bargaining level, with formal recognition process and dispute referral if contested, as per section 57.
What purpose does information disclosure serve in bargaining?
Enables effective engagement by representative union, with exceptions protecting privilege, confidentiality, and privacy, as per section 58.
How does good faith bargaining promote successful outcomes?
Requires effort to agree, genuine negotiation, and avoiding delays, fostering constructive dialogue, as per section 59.
How does the binding nature of agreements extend to non-members?
Deemed representation if majority members, extending coverage without compulsory membership, as per section 60(2).
What continuity protections exist in collective agreements?
Bind new members/represented for full period, ensuring stability, as per section 60(5).
Why is registration of agreements required?
For Court scrutiny, legal enforceability as award, and public record, as per section 61.
What safeguards does Court registration provide?
Refusal if unenforceable, illegal, or below minimum standards, with referral back for correction, as per section 61(6)-(7).
How does exclusive representative status affect bargaining?
Centralises negotiation with majority union, streamlining process while protecting minority rights indirectly.
What balance does disclosure strike?
Mandates relevant information for effective bargaining but protects sensitive data, with Court resolution for disputes.
How does majority threshold for representation promote democracy?
Ensures union has substantial support before exclusive rights, democratic legitimacy.
Why allow indefinite agreements with termination notice?
Provides stability but flexibility to end when needed, reasonable notice protects parties.
What practical effect of registered agreements being awards?
Enforceable through Court mechanisms, stronger legal status.
How does the Act encourage multi-level bargaining?
Explicitly permits enterprise, sector, national levels with party determination, accommodating different needs.
What role does the Commission play in registration?
Receives copy and may report to Court for informed decision.
How does good faith duty prevent surface bargaining?
Requires genuine effort and constructive engagement, prohibiting mere going through motions.
What protections for confidentiality in disclosure?
Exemptions for harm-causing, privileged, or Court-prohibited information.
How does exclusion of senior managers affect bargaining?
Aligns interests with employer, preventing conflict in management roles.
If employer refuses recognition despite majority?
Union refers to dispute resolution authority for determination, as per section 57(4).
If parties disagree on information relevance?
Referred to Court for decision, as per section 58(3).
If agreement below minimum wages?
Court may refuse registration, protecting standards, as per section 61(6)(b).
If no majority but agreement reached?
Still registerable if parties consent, but no exclusive rights.
If indefinite agreement, how terminated?
Reasonable written notice to other parties.
How does Part VII promote orderly bargaining?
Through representative exclusivity, good faith, disclosure, and registration safeguards.
What democratic element in representation?
Majority support requirement at bargaining level.
How does flexibility in subjects aid bargaining?
Allows tailoring to specific workplace needs beyond standard terms.
What protection against weak agreements?
Court refusal if below minimum legal standards.
How does binding on non-members work?
Deemed representation when majority members, extending benefits/burdens.
If Court modifies and parties refuse?
Not registered, matter referred back.
What effective date protection?
Parties' appointed date preserved even with modifications.
How link to organisational rights?
Representative status from Part VI enables exclusive bargaining here.
What role of Labour Advisory Board?
Consulted by Minister for exclusions.
How multi-employer agreements bind?
All entity members and represented employees.
What if unenforceable clause?
Court may refuse or require modification.
How good faith enforced?
Through broader unfair labour practice or dispute mechanisms.
What overall purpose of Part VII?
Structured, fair, enforceable collective bargaining framework.
Explain the requirements for a valid strike ballot under Section 62 and the circumstances in which it can be challenged.

A valid strike ballot must be conducted as a proper secret ballot according to the trade union's rules (Section 62(1)). If the union has no rules on strike ballots, it must be conducted in a transparent and fair manner (Section 62(2)). Any union member can apply to the Court to nullify a strike ballot on grounds of fraud, non-observance of rules, or unfairness (Section 62(3)), and the Court may issue a restraining order pending determination of such application (Section 62(4)).
Analyze the procedural conditions that must be satisfied before a lawful strike can occur under Section 63(2).

For a lawful strike: (a) the dispute must be of interest (not of right); (b) the dispute must have been referred to the Court and dispute resolution procedures exhausted, with either an order that the dispute remains unsolved or 30 days (or agreed extended period) passing since such order; (c) at least 48 hours' prior written notice must be given to the employer/employers' organization (or 7 days if the government is the employer); (d) for lock-outs, similar notice to the trade union or employees is required. All conditions must be met for the strike to be lawful (Section 63(2)-(3)).
Describe the categories of employees prohibited from striking under Section 64 and explain the rationale for these restrictions.

The following cannot strike: (a) public authority employees engaged in management; (b) employees engaged in managing the employer's business; (c) employees in essential services or minimum service provision (Section 64(1)). Essential services include water/sanitation, electricity, health services, air traffic control, fire services, and necessary transport (Section 64(2)). These restrictions balance union rights with public interest, ensuring continuity of critical services and maintaining managerial functions during disputes.
Explain the legal consequences for employees participating in a lawful strike versus an unlawful strike under Sections 66 and 65.

For lawful strikes (Section 66): Employees are not deemed to have breached their employment contracts, face no civil/criminal liability, but are not entitled to remuneration for work not performed. For unlawful strikes (Section 65): The Court may grant injunctions restraining participation and order compensation for losses attributable to the unlawful action. Additionally, the government and aggrieved parties may take measures to prevent unlawful strikes (Section 63(4)).
What are the conditions and limitations for a secondary strike under Section 67?

A secondary strike is only lawful if: (a) the primary strike being supported is lawful; (b) the secondary employer receives at least 7 days' written notice before commencement; (c) the secondary strike is reasonable in justification and impact to the primary employer (Section 67(1)). The Court may restrain a secondary strike if it contravenes the Act or is unjustified (Section 67(2)).
Explain the restrictions on replacement labour during strikes and lock-outs under Section 68.

During a strike, employers cannot engage temporary employment services (directly or via contractors) except as provided in regulations for maintenance services and other necessary services (Section 68(1), (3)). For lock-outs, temporary replacement labour cannot be engaged to perform locked-out employees' work unless the lock-out is in response to a strike (Section 68(2)). These restrictions protect the effectiveness of industrial action while allowing essential maintenance.
Describe the procedural requirements for lawful protest action under Section 69 and how it differs from a strike.

Protest action is lawful if: (a) called by a registered trade union/federation; (b) the matter is referred to mediation with at least 30 days for resolution; (c) if unresolved, the union gives 14 days' written notice explaining purpose, nature, place, and date (Section 69(2)). Unlike strikes (which address specific employment disputes), protest action addresses broader social/economic issues but receives similar employment protection (Section 69(4)). The mediation authority may fix conditions if parties don't agree (Section 69(3)).
What constitutes lawful picketing under Section 70 and what limitations apply to its conduct?

Lawful picketing must be: (a) authorized by a registered trade union; (b) peaceful; (c) for supporting lawful strikes, persuading non-strikers to support, or opposing lawful lock-outs (Section 70(1)). It may be held in public places outside employer premises or inside with employer permission (Section 70(2)). Picketing cannot involve intimidation (Section 71) and must respect the rights of others to work and access premises.
Analyze the definition of 'intimidation or annoyance' under Section 71 and its implications for industrial action.

Intimidation includes: (a) violence or threats to persons/property; (b) persistent following; (c) hiding/damaging tools/property; (d) watching/besetting workplaces/homes; (e) disorderly following in streets (Section 71(1)). Such conduct is an offense punishable by fine up to 100,000 shillings or imprisonment up to 3 months. This provision protects individuals' rights during disputes while allowing peaceful protest, distinguishing lawful industrial action from coercive behavior.
Explain the concept of 'dispute of interest' versus 'dispute of right' in the context of strike eligibility under Section 63.

A 'dispute of interest' involves creating new rights or terms (e.g., wage increases, new benefits) and is subject to strike/lock-out after dispute resolution exhaustion. A 'dispute of right' involves enforcing existing rights (e.g., contract violations, unfair dismissals) and is not subject to strike action but rather to arbitration/adjudication. This distinction ensures that strikes are used only for creating new terms, not for enforcing existing agreements, maintaining industrial relations stability.
How does the requirement for a strike ballot under Section 62 balance democratic legitimacy with practical union governance?

The mandatory secret ballot ensures member consent and democratic legitimacy for industrial action, while deferring to union rules (or fairness if none exist) respects internal governance. Challenge rights via Court protect minority members from irregular processes, preventing abuse while not unduly restricting unions.
Analyse the procedural hurdles in Section 63(2) and their impact on the effectiveness of strike action.

Requiring dispute of interest classification, exhaustion of resolution procedures (with time delays), and strict notice periods creates significant hurdles, cooling tensions and encouraging settlement but potentially weakening strike impact through delay and procedural non-compliance risks.
Discuss the rationale behind absolute prohibitions on strikes in certain categories under Section 64 and potential human rights implications.

Prohibitions on managerial employees and essential services protect operational continuity and public welfare, reflecting societal interest override. This aligns with ILO allowances for essential services restrictions but raises proportionality concerns regarding complete denial versus minimum service agreements.
Compare and contrast legal protections and consequences for lawful versus unlawful strikes under Sections 65 and 66.

Lawful strikes provide immunity from breach/civil/criminal liability but no pay, preserving contract while accepting economic pressure. Unlawful strikes expose participants to injunctions and compensation liability, enabling swift employer/Court intervention to halt action and recover losses.
Evaluate the proportionality test implicit in secondary strike limitations under Section 67.

Requiring primary strike lawfulness, extended notice, and reasonable justification/impact balances solidarity rights with preventing disproportionate harm to neutral employers, embodying proportionality by limiting secondary action scope.
How do replacement labour restrictions in Section 68 affect the balance of power in industrial disputes?

General prohibition (except regulated maintenance) preserves strike pressure by preventing easy workforce substitution, strengthening worker leverage while allowing essential continuity, shifting power toward unions compared to unrestricted replacement regimes.
Examine how protest action provisions in Section 69 extend industrial rights beyond workplace disputes.

Protest action addresses socio-economic issues with mediation requirement and notice, extending protected action while requiring resolution attempts, broadening freedom of association beyond bilateral disputes with procedural safeguards.
Analyse the interplay between picketing rights under Section 70 and intimidation prohibitions under Section 71.

Peaceful authorised picketing is protected expression/support, but broad intimidation definition (including besetting) criminalises coercive conduct, delineating lawful persuasion from unlawful pressure while risking overreach against vigorous action.
Discuss the significance of distinguishing disputes of interest from disputes of right in strike eligibility.

Restricting strikes to interest disputes channels rights enforcement through adjudication, preserving agreement stability and rule of law while allowing economic weapon use only for new claims, preventing disruption over existing obligations.
How does Part VIII overall balance collective worker power with societal and employer interests?

Grants robust strike/protest rights with procedural requirements, essential service bans, replacement restrictions, and intimidation controls, empowering workers economically while protecting public welfare, neutral parties, and peaceful conduct.
If a strike ballot is irregular but majority support exists, can the Court nullify?
Yes, on fairness/rule grounds, potentially halting action despite support, prioritising process.
If government employer, what notice period?
7 days instead of 48 hours, reflecting public sensitivity.
If essential service minimum staffing agreed?
Strike prohibition remains absolute under Section 64(1).
If unlawful strike causes loss, what remedies?
Injunction and compensation orders.
If secondary strike disproportionate?
Court may restrain despite primary lawfulness.

Generally prohibited except regulated maintenance.
If protest mediation fails, notice period?
14 days.
If picketing blocks access?
Likely intimidation/besetting, criminal offence.
If dispute over existing agreement term?
Dispute of right, no strike eligibility.
How does Part VIII integrate with dispute resolution?
Strike only after exhaustion, positioning industrial action as last resort.

Association/strike rights versus public safety limitations.
How replacement ban affects lock-out strategy?
Limits employer pressure except in response strikes.
If protest on political issue?
Permitted if socio-economic, with protection.
How intimidation definition risks chilling effect?
Broad terms like besetting may deter vigorous picketing.
What strategic considerations for secondary action?
Extended notice and proportionality scrutiny require careful justification.
How ballot challenge protects internal democracy?
Allows minority enforcement of fair process.
If notice defective?
Strike unlawful, exposing to remedies.
How no-pay rule affects strike duration?
Economic pressure on workers limits prolonged action.

How does Part VIII align with ILO standards?
Protects strike right with essential service/public order exceptions.

Yes, pending determination.

Prohibited during strike.

Yes, if parties disagree.

Prohibited.

Court-ordered for attributable losses.

Purpose, nature, place, date.

Strike premature, unlawful.
