Strengthens union presence, facilitates collective bargaining, promotes industrial peace.
How link to collective bargaining?
Provides infrastructure (access, representation, funding) for effective bargaining in Part VII.
What if multiple unions?
All have basic rights; representative status determines enhanced functions.
How agency fee equivalent in multi-union?
Representative union's subscription applies, as per section 52(3) proviso.
What if federation office bearer?
Entitled if affiliated to representative union, as per section 53(1).
How reasonable notice defined?
Contextual, sufficient for employer planning, no fixed period.
What core paid activities?
Meetings, negotiation, consultation with employer, as per section 53(3).
How domestic exception practical?
Other rights (e.g., deductions, leave) apply, but physical entry needs consent.
What if no collective agreement on charges?
Employer cannot charge, free service, as per section 51(4).
How Court ensures fairness?
Restrictions on application, compatible with purposes, as per section 52(7).
What if disruption despite conditions?
Employer can further restrict or challenge reasonableness.
How Part VI empowers workers?
Direct workplace presence, funding stability, representation mechanisms.
What employer obligations beyond permission?
Facilitate deductions, allow entry/activities under conditions, agree leave where possible.
How agency shops encourage membership?
Financial equivalence reduces free-rider incentive, while no compulsion preserves choice.
What if no agreement on leave conditions?
Default to reasonable entitlement, with paid core protected.
How representative status incentivised?
Grants stronger rights, encouraging organisation and recognition.
What practical effect of entry right?
Enables recruitment, communication, grievance handling at source.
How deductions support union finances?
Reliable, employer-administered collection with prompt remittance.
What if objection on other grounds?
Invalid, limited to illegality/discrimination, as per section 52(6).
How leave supports federation?
Office bearers of affiliated federations entitled, broader coordination.
What overall balance in Part VI?
Strong union rights with reasonable employer protections and safeguards.
How many moderate Q&A for Part VI?
Approximately 70 moderate-level pairs covering organisational rights comprehensively.
What is the official short title of this Act?
The official short title of the Act is the Labour Relations Act 2005, as per section 1(1).
When did the President assent to the Labour Relations Act?
The President assented to the Act on 5th March, 2005, as stated in the assent clause before section 1.
Who assented to the Labour Relations Act No.1 of 2005?
Amani Abeid Karume, President of Zanzibar and Chairman of the Revolutionary Council, assented to the Act, as stated in the assent clause.
Can the Minister delay the implementation of certain provisions of the Act?
Yes, the Minister may defer the coming into operation of any part or provision of this Act for a period not exceeding twelve months from the commencement date, as per section 1(2).
What happens if the Minister defers a provision under section 1(2)?
The deferred provision shall become operational on the date appointed by the Minister or after the expiry of twelve months, whichever comes earlier, as per section 1(3).
Does the Labour Relations Act apply to employees in Free Economic Zones?

Yes, notwithstanding any law to the contrary, the Act shall apply to the Free Economic Zones with such restrictions as the Minister in consultation with the Labour Advisory Board shall by regulation prescribe, as per section 2(3).
Which employees are excluded from the application of the Act?
The Act shall not apply to Judges and all Judiciary officers, Members of Special Departments, and Employees of the House of Representatives, as per section 2(2).
Do the provisions of Parts I to VI apply to employers' organisations?
Yes, unless expressly excluded, the provisions of Part I to VI of this Act apply equally to trade unions and employers organisations, as per section 2(4).
How must this Act be interpreted in relation to international labour standards?

Interpretation of this Act shall be made in a manner that will give effect to obligations of Zanzibar under various International Labour treaties to which the United Republic of Tanzania as a member State of the International Labour Organisation has ratified, as per section 3(1).
What does 'award' mean in the Labour Relations Act?
'award' includes agreement reached after mediation, decision of arbitrator and decision of the Court following review of an award, as per section 3(2).
What is the definition of 'bargaining unit'?
'bargaining unit' means the level at which collective bargaining is taking place, as per section 3(2).
What does 'branch' mean in relation to a trade union?

'branch' means any number of the members of a registered trade union who have in accordance with the constitution of the registered trade union appointed their own management committee but who are under the control of the executive committee of such trade union and are bound under the constitution of such trade union to contribute to its general funds, as per section 3(2).
What is meant by 'Commission' in the Act?
'Commission' means the Labour Commission established under the Labour Act, as per section 3(2).
What is the definition of 'contract of employment'?

'contract of employment' means any contract whether in writing or oral, whether express or implied, to employ or to serve as an employee for any period of time or number of days to be worked, or to execute any task or piece of work or to perform any journey and includes a foreign contract of service, as per section 3(2).
What does 'Court' refer to in this Act?
'Court' means the Industrial Court established under this Act, as per section 3(2).
What is the definition of 'employee' under the Labour Relations Act?

'employee' means any person who has entered into or works under a contract of service with an employer whether by way of manual labour, clerical work or otherwise and whether the contract is expressed or implied or is oral or in writing, and shall include any such person in the employment of the Government or of any local authority or private sector or any apprentice and learner who has entered into or works under any agreement whether expressed or implied or whether oral or in writing, as per section 3(2).
Who is considered an 'employer' according to the Act?

'employer' means any person, or any firm, corporation or company, public authority or body of persons who or which has entered into a contract of service to employ any person and includes the Government, as per section 3(2).
What is an 'employers' organisation'?

'employers' organisation' means any association of employers the principal purposes of which are the representation of employers' interests and the regulation of relations between employers and employees, and includes a federation of employers’ organisation, as per section 3(2).
What constitutes an 'essential service' under the Act?

'essential service' means any service, whether rendered by the Government or any other body or person, the interruption of which is likely to endanger the life, health or personal safety of the whole or part of the population, and includes services mentioned under section 64(2) of this Act, as per section 3(2).
What does 'executive' mean in the context of a trade union or employers' association?
'executive' means the body entrusted with the management of the affairs of the trade union or employers' association, as per section 3(2).
What is a 'federation' as defined in the Act?
'federation' means any combination or association of two or more trade unions which have a separate legal existence from the trade unions of which they are comprised, as per section 3(2).
What is the definition of 'labour dispute'?

'labour dispute' means any dispute or difference between an employer or employers and employees, or between employees and employees, connected with employment or non employment, or the terms of employment, or with the condition of labour, of any person, or with the economic and social interests of workers, as per section 3(2).
What does 'lock-out' mean under the Act?

'lock-out' means any action taken by an employer in contemplation or furtherance of a labour dispute which consists in the exclusion of a group of employees from a place of employment, the suspension of employment or work of a group of employees or a refusal to continue to employ a group of employees, as per section 3(2).
What is the meaning of 'Minister' in this Act?
'Minister' means the Minister responsible for labour, as per section 3(2).
What is a 'strike' according to the Labour Relations Act?

'strike' means the cessation of work by a body of persons employed, acting in combination, or a concerted refusal or a refusal under a common understanding of any number of persons employed to continue to work for an employer in consequence of a trade dispute, done as a means of compelling their employer or any person or body of persons employed, or to aid other employees in compelling their employer, or any persons or body of persons employed, to accept or not to accept terms or conditions of or affecting employment, as per section 3(2).
What does 'trade union' mean in the Act?

'trade union' means an association of employees, whether registered or not, having among its objects the representation and promotion of the interests of employees and the regulation of relations between employees and employers and includes a federation of trade unions unless it is clear from the context that only the first level association is meant, but does not include an association that is dominated by an employer and shall not include employers' association, as per section 3(2).
An employer threatens to dismiss an employee if they join a trade union. Is this allowed?
No, such action constitutes interference with freedom of association and is prohibited, as per sections 5 and 8.
Can a trade union affiliate with an international workers' organisation?
Yes, trade unions and employers' organisations may affiliate with international workers' and employers' associations, as per section 10.
Who appoints the Registrar of trade unions?
The Minister shall appoint a Registrar of trade unions and employers organisations and such other officials as may be required, as per section 12.
Is it mandatory for trade unions to register under the Act?
Yes, trade unions and employers' organisations must be registered, as per section 14.
Can the Registrar refuse registration of a trade union?
Yes, the Registrar may refuse registration on specified grounds, as per section 21.
What is the legal status of a registered trade union?
A registered trade union or employers' organisation is a body corporate with perpetual succession, as per section 25.
Can a trade union have branches?
Yes, trade unions may establish branches in accordance with their constitution, as per section 30.
Are trade unions allowed to amalgamate?
Yes, two or more registered trade unions may amalgamate, as per section 31.
Can trade unions form a federation in Tanzania?
Yes, trade unions may form or join a federation of Tanzania trade unions, as per section 32.
What rights do representative trade unions have in the workplace?
Representative trade unions have rights including access to the workplace, deduction of subscriptions, and leave for union activities, as per sections 50-53 (Part VI).
Is there a right to strike under the Act?
Yes, employees have the right to strike subject to conditions and limitations, particularly in essential services, as per sections 63 and 64.
What is the Zanzibar Industrial Court?
The Zanzibar Industrial Court is established under the Act with jurisdiction over labour disputes, as per section 80 (Part X).
Can collective agreements be registered?
Yes, collective agreements may be registered with the Commission, as per section 61.
What is a secondary strike?
A secondary strike is a strike in support of employees of another employer, as per section 67.
Is picketing allowed during a strike?
Yes, peaceful picketing is permitted, but intimidation or annoyance is prohibited, as per sections 70 and 71.
How are labour disputes resolved under the Act?
Labour disputes are resolved through mediation, arbitration, and ultimately the Industrial Court, as per Part IX.
Can an employer use replacement labour during a lawful strike?
No, replacement labour is prohibited during a strike, as per section 68.
What is protest action under the Act?
Protest action is permitted to promote or defend socio-economic interests of workers, as per section 69.
Are parties allowed legal representation in the Industrial Court?
Yes, parties have the right to be represented by an Advocate, as per section 89.
What regulations can the Minister make under the Act?
The Minister may make regulations for various matters including Parts I to VI and general implementation, as per sections 49 and 99.
Explain the purpose of the Labour Relations Act No.1 of 2005.
The purpose of the Act is to provide for the regulation of labour relations and dispute resolution between employers and employees and matters related thereto, as stated in the long title of the Act.
Explain who enacted the Labour Relations Act 2005.
The Act was enacted by the House of Representatives of Zanzibar, as stated after the long title.
Explain the structure of the Act in terms of Parts.

The Act is structured into 11 Parts: Part I Preliminary, Part II Fundamental Rights, Part III Registration, Part IV Constitution and Governance, Part V Property, Funds and Accounts, Part VI Organization Rights, Part VII Collective Bargaining and Collective Agreements, Part VIII Labour Disputes, Part IX Dispute Prevention and Resolution, Part X The Zanzibar Industrial Court, and Part XI Miscellaneous, as per the Arrangement of Sections.
Explain what Part II of the Act covers.

Part II covers Fundamental Rights, including basic employee’s rights (section 4), protection of freedom of association (section 5), basic employer’s rights (section 6), protection of rights (section 7), protection of trade unions against interference (section 8), federations (section 9), international affiliation (section 10), and remedies for infringement (section 11), as per the Arrangement of Sections.
Explain the content of Part III Registration.

Part III deals with Registration, covering appointment of Registrar (section 12), protection of officials (section 13), requirement for trade unions to register (section 14), application process (section 15), register maintenance (section 16), prescribed manner (section 17), certificate (section 18), further particulars (section 19), name alteration (section 20), refusal (section 21), cancellation (section 22), appeal (section 23), and consequences (section 24), as per the Arrangement of Sections.
Explain what sections are included in Part IV Constitution and Governance.

Part IV includes legal status (section 25), liability of members (section 26), membership (section 27), constitution (section 28), registered office (section 29), branches and affiliation (section 30), amalgamation (section 31), federation of Tanzania trade unions (section 32), notice of changes (section 33), effect of changes (section 34), meetings (section 35), dissolution (section 36), assets declaration (section 37), and gazette notification (section 38), as per the Arrangement of Sections.
Explain the topics covered in Part V Property, Funds and Accounts.

Part V covers property and liability (section 39), disposal of property (section 40), applications of funds (section 41), prohibition of payment of fines (section 42), books to be kept (section 43), accounts (section 44), annual returns (section 45), power of Registrar (section 46), injunction (section 47), service of legal process (section 48), and regulations for Parts I to VI (section 49), as per the Arrangement of Sections.
Explain what organizational rights are provided in Part VI.

Part VI provides trade union access to workplace (section 50), deduction of trade union subscription (section 51), agency shop agreement (section 52), and leave for trade union activities (section 53), as per the Arrangement of Sections.
Explain the provisions in Part VII regarding collective bargaining.

Part VII covers right to bargaining collectively (section 54), bargaining subject (section 55), levels of bargaining (section 56), representative trade union (section 57), disclosure of information (section 58), duty to bargain in good faith (section 59), binding nature of collective agreements (section 60), and registration of collective agreements (section 61), as per the Arrangement of Sections.
Explain the sections related to labour disputes in Part VIII.

Part VIII includes strike ballot (section 62), right to strike (section 63), limitation on right to strike or lock-out (section 64), restraining unlawful actions (section 65), protection for lawful strike (section 66), secondary strike (section 67), replacement labour (section 68), protest action (section 69), picketing (section 70), and intimidation or annoyance (section 71), as per the Arrangement of Sections.
Explain the dispute resolution mechanisms in Part IX.

Part IX covers establishment of dispute handling unit (section 72), filing of disputes (section 73), mediation (section 74), arbitration (section 75), assistance by Court (section 76), proceedings in special circumstances (section 77), tripartite committee (section 78), and representation (section 79), as per the Arrangement of Sections.
Explain the establishment and functions of the Zanzibar Industrial Court in Part X.

Part X establishes the Court with jurisdiction (section 80), composition (section 81), staff (section 82), sittings (section 83), functions (section 84), retrospective awards (section 85), interpretation of awards (section 86), appeals (section 87), evidence rules (section 88), representation by advocate (section 89), protection of members (section 90), public/private sittings (section 91), report (section 92), contempt (section 93), summary procedure (section 94), sitting allowance (section 95), and court fees (section 96), as per the Arrangement of Sections.
Explain the miscellaneous provisions in Part XI.
Part XI includes prosecution of offences (section 97), offence and penalty (section 98), regulations (section 99), and repeal and saving (section 100), as per the Arrangement of Sections.
Explain the commencement provisions of the Act.

The Act comes into operation on a date appointed by the Minister via gazette notice, with power to defer any part for up to 12 months, and deferred provisions activate on appointed date or after 12 months, whichever earlier, as per section 1.
Explain the application scope of the Act.

The Act applies to all employees working in Zanzibar and their employers, excludes judiciary, special departments, and House of Representatives employees, applies to Free Economic Zones with restrictions, and Parts I-VI apply equally to trade unions and employers' organisations unless excluded, as per section 2.
Explain how the Act should be interpreted.
Interpretation must give effect to Zanzibar's obligations under ILO treaties ratified by the United Republic of Tanzania, as per section 3(1).
Explain the definition of 'award'.
'Award' includes mediated agreements, arbitrator decisions, and Court decisions following review, as per section 3(2).
Explain what a 'branch' of a trade union is.
A 'branch' is a group of members with their own management committee but under control of the main executive and contributing to general funds, as per section 3(2).
Explain the definition of 'employee'.

An 'employee' is any person working under a contract of service (oral or written, express or implied), including government, local authority, private sector employees, apprentices, and learners, as per section 3(2).
Explain what an 'essential service' entails.
An 'essential service' is one whose interruption endangers life, health, or safety of the population, including services listed in section 64(2), as per section 3(2).
Explain the meaning of 'federation'.
A 'federation' is a combination of two or more trade unions with separate legal existence, as per section 3(2).
Explain what a 'labour dispute' covers.
A 'labour dispute' includes disputes over employment terms, conditions, or socio-economic interests of workers, as per section 3(2).
Explain the definition of 'lock-out'.
A 'lock-out' is employer action excluding, suspending, or refusing to employ employees in furtherance of a dispute, as per section 3(2).
Explain what a 'strike' is defined as.
A 'strike' is concerted cessation of work or refusal to work to compel acceptance/rejection of employment terms, as per section 3(2).
Explain the role of the Registrar.
The Registrar is appointed by the Minister to handle registration of trade unions and employers' organisations, as per section 12 and definition in section 3(2).
Explain the protection given to officials.
Officials are protected from civil liability for acts done in good faith, as per section 13.
Explain the requirement for registration of trade unions.
Trade unions must be registered, with applications required within specified periods, as per sections 14 and 15.
Explain the consequences of cancellation of registration.
Cancellation leads to loss of certain rights like bargaining or holding property beyond winding up, as per section 24.
Explain the legal status of registered organisations.
Registered trade unions or employers' organisations become bodies corporate with perpetual succession, as per section 25.
Explain membership rules for trade unions.
Membership is governed by the constitution, with no personal liability for organisational debts, as per sections 26 and 27.
Explain requirements for a trade union constitution.
The constitution must cover specified matters in the Schedule, as per section 28.
Explain provisions for amalgamation of trade unions.
Two or more registered trade unions may amalgamate with notice to Registrar, as per section 31.
Explain how funds of trade unions must be applied.
Funds must be applied only for constitutional purposes, with prohibition on paying fines, as per sections 41 and 42.
Explain accounting requirements for trade unions.
Trade unions must keep proper books, prepare accounts, and submit annual returns, as per sections 43-45.
Explain trade union access rights to the workplace.
Employers must allow trade union access for recruitment, meetings, and member service, as per section 50.
Explain check-off system for union subscriptions.
Employers must deduct and remit trade union subscriptions upon authorisation, as per section 51.
Explain agency shop agreements.
Non-members may be required to pay fees if benefiting from collective agreements, as per section 52.
Explain leave for trade union activities.
Employees are entitled to paid leave for lawful trade union activities, as per section 53.
Explain the right to collective bargaining.
Employees have the right to bargain collectively through representative unions, as per section 54.
Explain levels at which bargaining can occur.
Bargaining can occur at enterprise, sector, or national levels, as per section 56.
Explain how a trade union becomes representative.
A union is representative if it has majority membership or is the largest in the unit, as per section 57.
Explain the duty to bargain in good faith.
Parties must negotiate genuinely with intent to reach agreement, as per section 59.
Explain the binding nature of collective agreements.
Collective agreements are binding on parties and covered employees, as per section 60.
Explain the requirement for a strike ballot.
A strike requires a secret ballot with majority support, as per section 62.
Explain limitations on strikes in essential services.
Strikes are restricted or prohibited in essential services to protect public safety, as per section 64.
Explain protection during lawful strikes.
Employees participating in lawful strikes are protected from dismissal or prejudice, as per section 66.
Explain what a secondary strike is.
A secondary strike supports workers of another employer, subject to conditions, as per section 67.
Explain the prohibition on replacement labour.
Employers cannot hire replacement workers during a protected strike, as per section 68.
Explain protest action.
Protest action promotes socio-economic interests without being a full strike, as per section 69.
Explain rules for picketing.
Picketing must be peaceful; intimidation is prohibited, as per sections 70 and 71.
Explain the dispute handling unit.
A unit is established for filing, mediation, and initial resolution of disputes, as per section 72.
Explain the mediation process.
Disputes are first mediated to reach voluntary agreement, as per section 74.
Explain arbitration for unresolved disputes.
Unresolved disputes after mediation go to arbitration, as per section 75.
Explain the jurisdiction of the Zanzibar Industrial Court.
The Court has jurisdiction over labour matters, including review of awards, as per section 80.
Explain whether Court awards can be retrospective.
Yes, awards may have retrospective effect, as per section 85.
Explain appeals from the Industrial Court.
Decisions of the Court may be appealed to the Court of Appeal, as per section 87.
Explain representation in Court proceedings.
Parties may be represented by advocates, as per section 89.
Explain contempt procedures in the Court.
The Court has power to punish contempt, including summary procedure, as per sections 93 and 94.
Explain the regulation-making power.
The Minister may make regulations for implementation, including fees and forms, as per section 99.
Explain the repeal and saving provision.
The Act repeals previous laws with saving for existing rights or actions, as per section 100.
Explain the Schedule's role.
The Schedule specifies matters that must be included in trade union constitutions, as referenced in section 28.
Explain basic employee rights under the Act.
Basic rights include forming unions, fair remuneration, safe conditions, and protection from discrimination, as per section 4.
Explain protection of freedom of association for employees.
Employers cannot coerce or discriminate based on union membership or activities, as per section 5.
Explain basic employer rights.
Employers have rights to form organisations and participate in lawful lock-outs, as per section 6.
Explain protection against interference with trade unions.
No interference with union formation, administration, or activities is allowed, as per section 8.
Explain remedies for freedom of association violations.
Remedies include Court orders for compliance, compensation, or reinstatement, as per section 11.
Explain international affiliation rights.
Trade unions and employers' organisations may affiliate internationally, as per section 10.
Explain the process for registering a trade union.
Application with prescribed details to Registrar, who issues certificate if satisfied, as per sections 15-18.
Explain grounds for refusal of registration.
Refusal possible if unlawful, fraudulent, or name conflict, as per section 21.
Explain appeal against registration decisions.
Appeal lies to the Industrial Court against refusal or cancellation, as per section 23.
Explain dissolution of a trade union.
Dissolution per constitution with asset declaration and gazette notice, as per sections 36-38.
Explain property vesting in registered organisations.
Property vests in trustees for the organisation, as per section 39.
Explain the Registrar's inspection powers.
Registrar may inspect books and require information, as per section 46.
Explain disclosure of information in bargaining.
Parties must disclose relevant information in good faith, as per section 58.
Explain tripartite committees.
Tripartite committees assist in certain dispute resolutions, as per section 78.
Explain Court sittings.
Sittings may be public or private, with member allowances, as per sections 83, 91, and 95.
Explain offences and penalties under the Act.
Various offences carry fines or imprisonment, prosecuted by DPP, as per sections 97-98.
Explain the role of the Labour Advisory Board.
The Board advises on regulations, particularly for Free Economic Zones, as per section 2(3).
Explain the definition of 'minor'.
A 'minor' is a person below the age of majority under Zanzibar laws, as per section 3(2).
Explain 'maintenance service'.
A service whose interruption causes material physical destruction to facilities, as per section 3(2).
Explain 'picketing'.
Peaceful action to dissuade non-strikers without going further, as per section 3(2).
Explain 'replacement labour'.
Labour engaged to replace striking workers, prohibited during protected strikes, as per section 3(2) and 68.
Explain 'secondary employer'.
Employer whose workers are supported by secondary strike, as per section 3(2).
Explain 'tripartite committee'.
Committee established under section 78 for dispute resolution, as per section 3(2).
Explain the overall framework for labour relations in Zanzibar.
The Act establishes rights, registration, bargaining, dispute resolution, and judicial mechanisms to promote fair labour relations, as per the entire Act structure.
Explain how the Act aligns with international standards.
Interpretation must comply with ILO conventions ratified by Tanzania, as per section 3(1).
Explain the balance between employee and employer rights.
The Act provides parallel rights for formation of organisations, association, and industrial action (strike/lock-out), as per Parts II and VIII.
Explain the multi-tier dispute resolution system.
Disputes go through filing, mediation, arbitration, and Court adjudication, as per Part IX and X.
Explain protections for lawful industrial action.
Lawful strikes/lock-outs are protected, with no victimisation, as per sections 66 and related.
Explain organisational democracy requirements.
Constitutions must ensure democratic elections, meetings, and accountability, as per section 28 and Schedule.
Explain financial transparency for unions.
Unions must maintain accounts, audit, and report annually, with Registrar oversight, as per Part V.
Explain the role of collective agreements.
They regulate terms binding parties and employees, registrable for enforcement, as per sections 60-61.
Explain restrictions on industrial action.
Ballots required, essential services limited, unlawful actions restrainable, as per Part VIII.
Explain the Industrial Court's flexibility.
Not bound by strict evidence rules, allows advocates, flexible sittings, as per sections 88-91.
Explain how the Act promotes good faith.
Duty to bargain and disclose information in good faith, as per sections 58-59.
Explain the transition from previous laws.
Repeals prior ordinances with savings for existing matters, as per section 100.
Explain the significance of the assent date.
Assented on 5th March 2005 by President Amani Abeid Karume, marking formal approval.
Explain why the Act excludes certain public employees.
Judiciary, special departments, and House employees excluded likely due to separate regimes, as per section 2(2).
Explain the gazette notification requirement.
Commencement and certain changes require publication in the official gazette, as per sections 1 and 38.
Explain the protection of officials from liability.
Good faith actions protected from civil suits, encouraging proper administration, as per section 13.
Explain why name changes may be required.
To avoid confusion with existing organisations, as per section 20.
Explain the effect of amalgamation.
Creates a new entity with transferred rights and obligations, as per section 34.
Explain injunction powers.
Court may restrain improper use of funds or actions, as per section 47.
Explain the importance of registered office.
Serves as official address for legal service, as per section 29 and 48.
Explain why funds cannot pay fines.
To prevent misuse of member contributions, as per section 42.
Explain the purpose of annual returns.
Ensures transparency and compliance monitoring, as per section 45.
Explain why mediation is first step.
Promotes voluntary resolution before escalation, as per section 74.
Explain retrospective awards.
Allows backdating to remedy past wrongs, as per section 85.
Explain why evidence rules are not binding.
For expeditious and equitable labour justice, as per section 88.
Explain the annual report by the Court.
Promotes accountability to the Minister, as per section 92.
Explain general penalty provisions.
Unspecified offences carry standard fines/imprisonment, as per section 98.
What is the full title and purpose of the Labour Relations Act No. 1 of 2005?

The full title is 'An Act to Provide for the Regulation of Labour Relations and Dispute Resolution Between Employers and Employees and Matters Related Thereto,' and its purpose is to regulate labour relations, resolve disputes, and handle related matters, as stated in the long title of the Act.
Who enacted the Labour Relations Act No. 1 of 2005 and who assented to it?

The Act was enacted by the House of Representatives of Zanzibar and assented to by Amani Abeid Karume, President of Zanzibar and Chairman of the Revolutionary Council, on 5th March, 2005, as per the enactment and assent clauses.
Describe the short title, commencement date, and any deferral provisions in the Act.

The short title is the Labour Relations Act 2005. It commences on a date appointed by the Minister via gazette notice. The Minister may defer any part for up to 12 months, after which it becomes operational automatically if not appointed earlier, as per section 1(1)-(3).
To which individuals and entities does the Labour Relations Act apply, and who is excluded?

The Act applies to all employees engaged to work in Zanzibar and their employers. It excludes Judges and Judiciary officers, Members of Special Departments, and Employees of the House of Representatives. It also applies to Free Economic Zones with restrictions prescribed by the Minister in consultation with the Labour Advisory Board, as per section 2(1)-(3).
How does the Act ensure compliance with international labour standards?
The Act must be interpreted to give effect to Zanzibar's obligations under International Labour treaties ratified by the United Republic of Tanzania as an ILO member state, as per section 3(1).
Provide a detailed definition of 'award' as used in the Act.
An 'award' includes an agreement reached after mediation, the decision of an arbitrator, and the decision of the Court following review of an award, as per section 3(2).
What is the comprehensive definition of 'bargaining unit' in the context of collective bargaining?
A 'bargaining unit' means the level at which collective bargaining is taking place, such as enterprise, sector, or national level, as per section 3(2).
Describe what constitutes a 'branch' of a registered trade union.

A 'branch' is any number of members of a registered trade union who, per the union's constitution, have appointed their own management committee but remain under the control of the executive committee and are bound to contribute to the general funds, as per section 3(2).
What does the term 'Commission' refer to in the Labour Relations Act?
The 'Commission' refers to the Labour Commission established under the Labour Act, responsible for various administrative functions, as per section 3(2).
Give a thorough explanation of the definition of 'contract of employment'.

A 'contract of employment' is any contract, whether written or oral, express or implied, to employ or serve as an employee for a period, number of days, task, piece of work, or journey, including foreign contracts of service, as per section 3(2).
What is the 'Court' established under this Act?
The 'Court' is the Industrial Court established under this Act to handle labour disputes and related matters, as per section 3(2).
Elaborate on the definition of 'employee' including all inclusions.

An 'employee' is any person who enters into or works under a contract of service with an employer, by manual labour, clerical work or otherwise, express or implied, oral or written, including government, local authority, private sector employees, apprentices, and learners under agreements, as per section 3(2).
What entities are included in the definition of 'employer'?
An 'employer' is any person, firm, corporation, company, public authority, or body of persons who enters into a contract to employ any person, including the Government, as per section 3(2).
Describe the purpose and inclusion in 'employers' organisation'.

An 'employers' organisation' is an association of employers primarily for representing employers' interests and regulating relations between employers and employees, including federations of such organisations, as per section 3(2).
What services qualify as 'essential service' and why?

An 'essential service' is any service whose interruption endangers life, health, or personal safety of the population, including those listed in section 64(2), to protect public welfare, as per section 3(2).
What is the 'executive' in the context of trade unions or associations?
The 'executive' is the body entrusted with managing the affairs of the trade union or employers' association, as per section 3(2).
How is a 'federation' defined for trade unions?
A 'federation' is any combination or association of two or more trade unions with separate legal existence from the component unions, as per section 3(2).
What broad range of issues constitute a 'labour dispute'?
A 'labour dispute' is any dispute between employers and employees, or among employees, connected with employment, terms, conditions, or economic and social interests of workers, as per section 3(2).
Detail the actions that define a 'lock-out'.
A 'lock-out' is employer action in a dispute excluding employees from work, suspending employment, or refusing to employ them, as per section 3(2).
Who is the 'Minister' referred to in the Act?
The 'Minister' is the Minister responsible for labour matters, as per section 3(2).
What is encompassed in the definition of 'minor'?
A 'minor' is a person who has not attained the age of majority under Zanzibar laws, as per section 3(2).
Describe who qualifies as an 'official' of a trade union.
An 'official' includes executive committee members and branch officials, but excludes trustees or auditors, as per section 3(2).
What is the 'organisation' in the Act's context?
'Organisation' means an employers’ organisation, as per section 3(2).
Explain what 'picketing' entails.
'Picketing' is peaceful action in furtherance of a strike to dissuade non-participants from working, without exceeding that, as per section 3(2).
What is the 'register' maintained by the Registrar?
The 'register' is the register of trade unions maintained under section 16, as per section 3(2).
Define 'registered office' for a trade union.
The 'registered office' is the office registered under section 29, as per section 3(2).
Who can be appointed as 'Registrar'?
The 'Registrar' is appointed by the Minister under section 12(1), including assistants under section 12(2), as per section 3(2).
Provide the detailed definition of 'replacement labour'.
'Replacement labour' means labour engaged to replace employees participating in a strike, as per section 3(2).
What makes a trade union 'representative'?
A 'representative trade union' is one recognised as representing employees in a bargaining unit, as per section 3(2).
Describe the concept of 'secondary strike' in detail.
A 'secondary strike' is a strike by employees against an enterprise where they have no direct interest, to support other employees, as per section 3(2).
Who is a 'secondary employer'?
A 'secondary employer' is the employer of employees supported by a secondary strike, as per section 3(2).
Elaborate on the definition of 'strike'.

A 'strike' is the cessation of work by employed persons acting in combination or refusing to work under common understanding in a trade dispute to compel acceptance or rejection of employment terms, as per section 3(2).
What does 'the Government' include?
'The Government' means the Revolutionary Government of Zanzibar, including all departments and services, autonomous or semi-autonomous, as per section 3(2).
Provide the full definition of 'trade union'.

A 'trade union' is an association of employees, registered or not, for representing employee interests and regulating relations with employers, including federations but excluding employer-dominated associations or employers' associations, as per section 3(2).
What is a 'tripartite committee'?
A 'tripartite committee' is a committee established under section 78, as per section 3(2).
Define 'Union' as used in the Act.
'Union' means a trade union as defined under this Act, as per section 3(2).
What is the 'Unit' referred to?
'Unit' means a dispute handling Unit established under section 72, as per section 3(2).
List and describe the basic employee's rights.
Basic employee's rights include forming unions, fair remuneration, safe conditions, equal opportunity, and protection from unfair dismissal, as per section 4.
How does the Act protect employees' freedom of association?
Employers cannot require non-membership, prejudice for union activities, or threaten regarding union involvement, as per section 5.
What are the basic rights afforded to employers?
Employers have rights to form organisations, participate in their activities, and engage in lawful lock-outs, as per section 6.
Describe protections for basic rights of employees and employers.
No discrimination for exercising rights or participating in proceedings under the Act, as per section 7.
How is a trade union protected against interference?
No coercion, interference with formation, or termination for union activities, as per section 8.
What provisions exist for federations?
Trade unions and employers' organisations may form federations, as per section 9.
Can organisations affiliate internationally?
Yes, with international workers' and employers' associations, as per section 10.
What remedies are available for infringement of freedom of association?
Court may order compliance, reinstatement, compensation, as per section 11.
Who appoints the Registrar and officials?
The Minister appoints the Registrar and other officials, as per section 12.
What protections do officials have?
Protected from liability for good faith actions, as per section 13.
Is registration mandatory for trade unions?
Yes, trade unions must be registered, as per section 14.
Detail the application process for registration.
Unregistered unions with min members apply within 6 months, as per section 15.
What is the register of trade unions?
Registrar maintains a register of unions and organisations, as per section 16.
How is registration conducted?
In prescribed manner, with certificate issued, as per sections 17-18.
Can the Registrar request more information?
Yes, may call for further particulars, as per section 19.
Under what circumstances can name alteration be required?
If name is similar or unsuitable, as per section 20.
What are grounds for refusal of registration?
If unlawful, fraudulent, or non-compliant, as per section 21.
When can registration be cancelled?
For violations or non-operation, as per section 22.
How can one appeal registration decisions?
Appeal to the Industrial Court, as per section 23.
What happens after cancellation of registration?
Loses legal status, cannot function as union, as per section 24.
Describe the legal status after registration.
Body corporate with perpetual succession, can sue/be sued, as per section 25.
What is the liability of members in registered organisations?
No personal liability for debts, as per section 26.
How is membership determined?
Per constitution, open to eligible persons, as per section 27.
What must be included in the constitution?
Matters in the Schedule, like name, purposes, elections, as per section 28.
Why is a registered office required?
For official communications and legal service, as per section 29.
Can unions have branches or affiliate?
Yes, as provided in constitution, as per section 30.
Describe the amalgamation process.
Two or more unions may merge with ballot approval, notice to Registrar, as per section 31.
What is the Federation of Tanzania trade union?
Unions may form or join such federation, as per section 32.
How are changes like name or amalgamation notified?
Notice to Registrar in prescribed form, as per section 33.
What is the effect of name change or amalgamation?
Continues as new entity with transferred rights, as per section 34.
What meetings must trade unions hold?
Per constitution, including annual general meetings, as per section 35.
How is dissolution handled?
Per constitution, with notification to Registrar, as per section 36.
What declaration is required upon dissolution?
Declaration of assets and claims, as per section 37.
Is gazette notification required for dissolution?
Yes, Registrar notifies in gazette, as per section 38.
How is property held and liable?
Vests in trustees, liable for debts, as per section 39.
What rules govern disposal of property?
Per constitution, with member approval if necessary, as per section 40.
What are permissible applications of funds?
Only for constitutional objects, as per section 41.
Why can't funds pay fines?
Prohibited to avoid misuse, as per section 42.
What books must be kept?
Proper financial records, as per section 43.
How are accounts prepared?
Annual audited accounts, as per section 44.
What are annual returns?
Submitted to Registrar with audited accounts, as per section 45.
What powers does the Registrar have over funds?
Can inspect and require information, as per section 46.
When can an injunction be sought?
To restrain unauthorised use of funds, as per section 47.
How is legal process served?
At registered office or on officials, as per section 48.
Can regulations be made for Parts I to VI?
Yes, by the Minister, as per section 49.
Describe trade union access to workplace.
Allowed for recruitment, meetings outside working hours, as per section 50.
How are union subscriptions deducted?
Employer deducts and remits upon written authorisation, as per section 51.
What is an agency shop agreement?
Non-members pay fees for benefiting from agreements, as per section 52.
Is leave granted for union activities?
Yes, reasonable paid leave, as per section 53.
Who has the right to collective bargaining?
Employees not in excluded categories, as per section 54.
What subjects can be bargained?
Any mutual interest matters, as per section 55.
At what levels does bargaining occur?
Enterprise, sector, national, as per section 56.
How is a representative union determined?
By majority membership or largest union, as per section 57.
Is information disclosure required?
Yes, relevant information for bargaining, as per section 58.
What is good faith bargaining?
Genuine effort to reach agreement, as per section 59.
Are collective agreements binding?
Yes, on parties and employees, as per section 60.
Must agreements be registered?
Yes, with the Commission, as per section 61.
What is a strike ballot?
Secret vote for strike authorisation, as per section 62.
What is the right to strike?
Employees have right after procedures, as per section 63.
What limits the right to strike?
Essential services, minimum services, as per section 64.
Can unlawful strikes be restrained?
Yes, by Court order, as per section 65.
What protection for lawful strikes?
No dismissal or prejudice, as per section 66.
Describe secondary strikes.
Support strikes with notice, as per section 67.
Is replacement labour allowed?
No, during protected strikes, as per section 68.
What is protest action?
For socio-economic interests, with notice, as per section 69.
What rules for picketing?
Peaceful, agreed or authorised, as per section 70.
Is intimidation prohibited?
Yes, during disputes, as per section 71.
What is the dispute handling unit?
Established for dispute resolution, as per section 72.
How are disputes filed?
To the unit in prescribed form, as per section 73.
Describe mediation process.
Mediator facilitates agreement, as per section 74.
What happens to unresolved disputes?
Go to arbitration or Court, as per section 75.
Can Court assist in mediation?
Yes, in certain cases, as per section 76.
What special proceedings exist?
For urgent or complex disputes, as per section 77.
What is a tripartite committee?
For specific resolutions, as per section 78.
Is representation allowed in mediation?
Yes, by authorised persons, as per section 79.
Describe the Industrial Court's establishment.
Established with jurisdiction over labour matters, as per section 80.
How is the Court composed?
Chairman and members appointed by President, as per section 81.
Who staffs the Court?
Appointed staff for administration, as per section 82.
Where and when does the Court sit?
As determined, in public or private, as per section 83.
What are the Court's functions?
Adjudicate disputes, review awards, as per section 84.
Can awards be backdated?
Yes, retrospective, as per section 85.
How are awards interpreted?
Court can interpret upon application, as per section 86.
Where do appeals go?
To Court of Appeal, as per section 87.
Are evidence rules strict?
No, not binding, as per section 88.
Can parties use lawyers?
Yes, right to advocate representation, as per section 89.
Are Court members protected?
Yes, from liability for good faith acts, as per section 90.
Are sittings public?
May be public or private, as per section 91.
Does the Court report annually?
Yes, to the Minister, as per section 92.
What is contempt of Court?
Offence punishable by Court, as per section 93.
Is there summary procedure for contempt?
Yes, for quick handling, as per section 94.
Are sitting allowances provided?
Yes, as prescribed, as per section 95.
Are there court fees?
Yes, as prescribed, as per section 96.
Who prosecutes offences?
Director of Public Prosecutions, as per section 97.
What are general offences and penalties?
Fines or imprisonment for violations, as per section 98.
Can the Minister make regulations?
Yes, for carrying out the Act, as per section 99.
What laws are repealed?
Previous Trade Unions Ordinance, with savings, as per section 100.
What are the basic rights of every employee under section 4(1) of the Labour Relations Act?

Every employee has the right to take part in the formation of a trade union or federation of trade unions, and to be a member of a trade union subject to its constitution, as per section 4(1)(a) and (b).
Can an employee participate in trade union activities during working hours?

Yes, every member of a trade union has the right to take part in lawful activities of the trade union outside working hours, or within working hours with the consent of the employer, as per section 4(2)(a).
Does a trade union member have the right to hold office in the union?
Yes, every member has the right, subject to the constitution of the trade union, to seek and hold office in the trade union of which he or she is a member, as per section 4(2)(b).
What rights do trade union members have regarding workplace representatives?

Members have the right to take part in the election of workplace representatives where provision is made for such election, and to be elected or appointed and serve as a workplace representative where provision is made for this, as per section 4(2)(c) and (d).
Are trade union members entitled to exercise other rights under the Act?
Yes, every member has the right to exercise any other right conferred by this Act, as per section 4(2)(e).
What rights do members of a trade union that belongs to a federation have?

Such members have the right, subject to the federation's constitution, to participate in its lawful activities, participate in the election of office bearers or officials, and stand for election and hold office if elected, as per section 4(3).
Can an employer require an employee not to join a trade union?

No, no employer or person acting on behalf of an employer shall require that an employee or person seeking employment shall not join or shall relinquish membership in a trade union or not participate in lawful trade union activities, as per section 5(1)(a).
Is discrimination against employees for trade union membership allowed?

No, employers shall not discriminate, take prejudicial action, or threaten dismissal against employees because of trade union membership, participation in lawful activities, exercise of rights under the Act, or participation in proceedings, as per section 5(1)(b).
Can an employer offer benefits to employees for not exercising rights under the Act?
No, employers shall not benefit, advantage, or promise advantage to employees for not exercising rights under the Act or for not participating in proceedings, as per section 5(1)(c).
Are contract terms that restrain rights under the Act valid?

No, any term in a contract of employment or collective agreement that seeks to restrain an employee from exercising rights conferred or recognised by this Act is null and void, whether agreed before or after the Act's commencement, as per section 5(2).
Does section 5 prevent fair dismissal for valid reasons?
No, nothing in section 5 prevents an employer from fairly dismissing or disciplining an employee for a valid reason in accordance with the Labour Act or other relevant law, as per section 5(3).
What basic rights do employers have under the Act?
Every employer has the right to take part in the formation of an employers’ organisation and to be a member of such organisation in accordance with its constitution, as per section 6(1).
What rights do members of employers' organisations have?
Members have the right, subject to the constitution, to take part in lawful activities, hold office, and exercise rights conferred by the Act, as per section 6(2).
What additional rights do members of federations of employers' organisations have?
They have the right, subject to the federation's constitution, to take part in lawful activities, participate in elections of office bearers, and exercise rights under the Act, as per section 6(3).
Does every eligible person have the right to join a trade union or employers' organisation?
Yes, any eligible person under the constitution has the right to membership on payment of dues and to remain a member while complying with the constitution, as per section 7(1).
Is membership in a trade union compulsory?
No, any person who has the right to join also has the right not to join such trade union or organisation, as per section 7(2).
Are closed shop agreements allowed under the Act?
No, any term in an agreement precluding employment of non-members or requiring union membership as a condition of employment is null and void, as per section 7(3).
Can trade unions or organisations discriminate in membership?

No, they shall not discriminate on grounds of race, colour, national extraction, social origin, religion, political opinion, sex, marital status, family responsibilities, age, or disability, as per section 7(4).
Are affirmative action programmes allowed despite anti-discrimination rules?
Yes, provisions, programmes, or activities aimed at improving conditions of disadvantaged persons are lawful, as per section 7(5).
Can a member be penalised for refusing to participate in unlawful actions?

No, no person refusing to participate in unlawful actions shall be subject to disadvantage, prejudice, cancellation of membership, removal from office, or penalty by the organisation, as per section 7(6).
Is employer domination of trade unions permitted?
No, no employer or employers' organisation shall promote or support a trade union under employer domination or control by financial or other means, as per section 8(1).
Can trade unions have political affiliations?
No, no union or organisation shall join or form part of a trade union movement and shall be independent from political affiliation with any political party, as per section 8(2).
Can trade unions form federations?
Yes, trade unions and employers' organisations may form and be members of federations and take part in their activities in accordance with their constitutions, as per section 9.
Are international affiliations allowed for trade unions and employers' organisations?
Yes, they may affiliate with international workers' or employers' associations, participate in activities, make contributions, and receive assistance, as per section 10.
How can infringements of Part II be addressed?
Any complaint of infringement may be presented to the Labour Court, as per section 11(1).
Who bears the burden of proof in discrimination cases under Part II?
In cases of alleged discrimination, dismissal, or prejudice, the employer must prove the action was for a valid reason, as per section 11(2).
What remedies can the Court order for infringements of freedom of association?
The Court may order reinstatement if requested, restoration of benefits, compensation for damages, and where appropriate, a punitive indemnity, as per section 11(3).
Explain the fundamental rights granted to employees in forming and joining trade unions.
Every employee has the right to participate in forming a trade union or federation and to become a member subject to the union's constitution, as per section 4(1).
Describe the rights of trade union members regarding participation in union activities.

Members can participate in lawful activities outside working hours or with employer consent during working hours, seek and hold office, and participate in workplace representative elections, as per section 4(2).
What protections exist against employer interference in freedom of association?
Employers cannot require non-membership, discriminate for union activities, or offer benefits for non-exercise of rights; such contract terms are void, as per section 5.
Explain the parallel rights provided to employers in forming organisations.
Employers mirror employee rights: formation, membership, participation in activities, holding office, and federation rights, as per section 6.
Describe the non-discrimination and voluntary membership principles in section 7.
Eligible persons have right to join and remain members or not join; no compulsory membership clauses; no discrimination on prohibited grounds, with affirmative action allowed, as per section 7.
What safeguards prevent employer control over trade unions?
Prohibition on promoting or financially supporting dominated unions, and requirement for independence from political parties, as per section 8.
Explain the provisions for forming federations and international affiliations.
Unions and organisations can form federations and affiliate internationally, including financial contributions and assistance, as per sections 9 and 10.
Detail the remedies available through the Labour Court for violations of Part II.
Complaints go to Court; employer proves valid reason in discrimination cases; remedies include reinstatement, restoration of benefits, compensation, and punitive indemnity, as per section 11.
Why is freedom of association considered fundamental in the Act?
Part II establishes core rights for both employees and employers to associate freely, with strong protections and remedies to ensure independence and non-interference, as per sections 4-11.
How does the Act balance employee and employer organisational rights?
It provides nearly identical rights to form, join, participate in, and federate organisations for both sides, with mutual protections against interference, as per sections 4-6.
What is the significance of section 5(2) regarding contract terms?
It declares void any contractual restraint on exercising Act rights, protecting freedom even against pre-existing agreements, as per section 5(2).
Explain the exception for valid dismissals in section 5(3).
Protections do not prevent fair dismissal for valid reasons under other laws, ensuring balance with disciplinary needs, as per section 5(3).
Describe the anti-discrimination grounds in section 7(4).
Unions cannot discriminate on race, colour, national extraction, social origin, religion, political opinion, sex, marital status, family responsibilities, age, or disability, as per section 7(4).
Why does section 7(5) allow certain preferential programmes?
To permit lawful affirmative action for disadvantaged groups without violating anti-discrimination rules, as per section 7(5).
What protection exists for members refusing unlawful actions?
No disadvantage or penalty for refusing unlawful activities, protecting internal democracy, as per section 7(6).
Explain the prohibition in section 8(1).
Prevents employer domination or control of trade unions through promotion or support, ensuring genuine worker representation, as per section 8(1).
Why must unions be independent from political parties under section 8(2)?
To maintain independence of the trade union movement from political affiliation, as per section 8(2).
What benefits does international affiliation provide under section 10?
Allows participation, contributions, and receipt of assistance from international bodies, strengthening global solidarity, as per section 10.
Explain the burden of proof shift in section 11(2).
Shifts burden to employer to prove valid reason in discrimination cases, easing employee claims, as per section 11(2).
What punitive measures can the Court impose under section 11(3)?
Punitive indemnity in addition to compensation, reinstatement, and benefit restoration, deterring violations, as per section 11(3).
Summarise the key principle of freedom of association in Part II.
Part II guarantees free, voluntary, and independent association for employees and employers without interference or discrimination, with effective remedies, as per sections 4-11.
How does Part II align with ILO conventions on freedom of association?
By providing formation, membership, activity, and protection rights mirroring ILO Convention 87 and 98 principles, reinforced by section 3(1).
What scenario would violate section 5(1)(b)?
Dismissing or threatening an employee for participating in lawful union activities or proceedings under the Act, as per section 5(1)(b).
If an employer promises promotion for leaving a union, is this legal?
No, it violates section 5(1)(c) by advantaging non-exercise of rights.
Can a pre-2005 contract require union non-membership?
No, such terms are null and void regardless of when agreed, as per section 5(2).
Is dismissing a shop steward for poor performance protected under section 5?
Yes, if valid reason and fair process under other laws, as per section 5(3).
Can an employer refuse to hire someone because they are not union-recommended?
Yes, such preclusion is null and void, as per section 7(3)(i).
Is a union constitution clause excluding women valid?
No, it discriminates on sex grounds, violating section 7(4).
Can a union fine a member for refusing an illegal strike?
No, such penalty is prohibited, as per section 7(6).
If an employer funds a union to control it, what section is violated?
Section 8(1) prohibiting support for dominated unions.
Can a trade union be affiliated with a political party?
No, unions must be independent from political parties, as per section 8(2).
What if a union receives funds from an international labour organisation?
Permitted under section 10.
If dismissed for union membership, what must the employer prove?
Valid reason unrelated to union activity, as per section 11(2).
What remedies might an employee get for unfair dismissal due to union activity?
Reinstatement, back pay, compensation, and punitive indemnity, as per section 11(3).
Elaborate on the right of employees to form and join trade unions as outlined in the Act.

Every employee has the fundamental right to participate in the formation of a trade union or a federation of trade unions and to become a member of a trade union, provided it aligns with the union's constitution. This ensures workers can collectively organise for better representation and protection of their interests, as per section 4(1)(a) and (b).
Describe the rights of trade union members to engage in union activities and hold office.

Trade union members have the right to engage in lawful union activities outside working hours or during working hours with employer consent, seek and hold office subject to the constitution, participate in elections for workplace representatives, and serve as such representatives where applicable. They can also exercise any other rights under the Act, promoting active involvement in union governance, as per section 4(2).
What protections does the Act provide against employer requirements regarding union membership?

The Act prohibits employers from requiring employees not to join or to relinquish union membership or from discriminating, threatening, or prejudicing employees for union involvement, exercising rights, or participating in proceedings. This safeguards freedom of association from employer coercion, as per section 5(1)(a) and (b).
Explain why contract terms restricting union rights are invalid under the Act.

Any contractual term that attempts to restrict an employee's exercise of rights under the Act, such as freedom of association, is declared null and void, regardless of when the contract was made. This ensures that statutory rights prevail over private agreements, as per section 5(2).
Discuss how the Act balances protection of union rights with employer disciplinary authority.

While protecting against discrimination for union activities, the Act allows employers to dismiss or discipline employees for valid reasons in accordance with the Labour Act or other laws, maintaining a balance between rights and workplace discipline, as per section 5(3).
Elaborate on the rights of employers to form and participate in their organisations.

Employers have the right to form and join employers' organisations, participate in their lawful activities, hold office subject to the constitution, and exercise Act-conferred rights, paralleling employee rights for balanced industrial relations, as per section 6(1) and (2).
What are the rights of members in federations of employers' organisations?

Members can participate in federation activities, elect office bearers, and hold office if elected, subject to the constitution, ensuring employers can engage at higher levels of organisation, as per section 6(3).
Describe the voluntary nature of membership in trade unions or organisations.

Eligible persons have the right to join and remain members by paying dues and complying with constitutions, but also the right not to join, emphasising voluntariness and preventing compulsion, as per section 7(1) and (2).
Why are certain agreement terms declared null and void in section 7(3)?
Terms precluding employment of non-union members or requiring union membership are void to prevent closed shops and ensure freedom of choice in association, as per section 7(3).
Explain the anti-discrimination obligations for unions and organisations.

Unions and organisations must not discriminate in constitutions or actions on grounds like race, religion, sex, or disability, promoting inclusivity, but affirmative action for disadvantaged is permitted, as per section 7(4) and (5).
What protection is there for members refusing unlawful union actions?
Members cannot be disadvantaged, penalised, or removed for refusing unlawful actions, protecting individual integrity within collective structures, as per section 7(6).
Discuss the prohibition on employer-dominated trade unions.
Employers cannot promote or support unions under their control, ensuring unions represent worker interests independently, as per section 8(1).
Why must trade unions remain independent from political parties?
To maintain autonomy and focus on labour issues without political influence, as per section 8(2).
Elaborate on the formation and membership in federations.
Trade unions and employers' organisations can form federations and participate in their activities per constitutions, allowing for broader collective representation, as per section 9.
Describe the scope of international affiliations permitted.
Organisations and federations can affiliate with international bodies, participate, contribute financially, and receive assistance, fostering global labour solidarity, as per section 10.
How are complaints of Part II infringements handled?
Presented to the Labour Court, which can order remedies like reinstatement and compensation, with employer bearing proof burden in discrimination cases, as per section 11.
In a scenario where an employer demotes an employee for union activity, what can the employee do?
The employee can complain to the Labour Court; if proven, the Court may order restoration of position and compensation, as per section 11(1) and (3).
If a collective agreement requires union membership, is it enforceable?
No, such term is null and void, protecting voluntary membership, as per section 5(2) and 7(3).
Explain how the Act supports affirmative action in unions.
Programmes improving conditions for disadvantaged groups are lawful despite anti-discrimination rules, as per section 7(5).
What if an employer funds a union election campaign?
If aimed at control, it violates section 8(1), prohibiting support for dominated unions.
Can a union expel a member for not supporting a political party?
No, as unions must be independent from politics, and expulsion could violate non-discrimination, as per section 8(2) and 7(4).
Describe a case where punitive indemnity might be awarded.
In egregious infringement like repeated discrimination, the Court may award punitive indemnity beyond compensation, as per section 11(3)(iii).
How does section 4(3) extend rights to federation members?
It grants participation in activities, elections, and office-holding in federations, broadening democratic involvement, as per section 4(3).
What role does consent play in union activities during work hours?
Activities during working hours require employer consent to balance rights with operational needs, as per section 4(2)(a).
Explain the inclusion of workplace representatives in rights.
Members can elect and serve as representatives where provided, enhancing shop-floor representation, as per section 4(2)(c)-(d).
If an employer threatens demotion for testifying in a labour case, is it protected?
No, it violates section 5(1)(b)(iii) against prejudice for participating in proceedings.
Can an agreement benefit non-union members preferentially?
No, if it advantages non-exercise of rights, violating section 5(1)(c).
How does the Act ensure employer rights mirror employee rights?
Section 6 provides equivalent rights for employers in organisation formation and participation, promoting equity.
What if a union constitution requires political allegiance?
It violates independence from politics under section 8(2) and possibly non-discrimination under section 7(4).
Explain international financial assistance for unions.
Unions can receive financial and other assistance from international associations, as per section 10.
In court, who must prove the reason for prejudicial action?
The employer must prove it was valid, shifting burden from the complainant, as per section 11(2).
What is the scope of 'prejudicial action' in section 5?
Includes disciplinary action, dismissal, threats, or any disadvantage for union-related reasons, as per section 5(1)(b).
Can federations receive international aid?
Yes, federations can affiliate and receive assistance, as per section 10.
Explain 'lawful activities' in the context of union rights.
Refers to activities permitted under the Act and constitution, such as meetings, elections, without violating laws, as per section 4(2)(a).
If a member is fined for not joining a strike, is it allowed?
No, if the strike is unlawful, as per section 7(6) protecting refusal of unlawful actions.
What constitutes 'domination' by employers in section 8?
Promoting establishment or supporting with means to control the union, as per section 8(1).
Can unions form federations across sectors?
Yes, as long as per constitutions, allowing broad alliances, as per section 9.
Explain the right to remain a member.
As long as complying with constitution and paying dues, ensuring stability, as per section 7(1).
Is age discrimination in union membership prohibited?
Yes, included in prohibited grounds, as per section 7(4).
What if an employer offers bonus for non-union status?
Violates section 5(1)(c) by advantaging non-exercise of rights.
Can employers join international employer groups?
Yes, with full participation and financial exchanges, as per section 10.
In infringement cases, is reinstatement mandatory?
If requested by the employee, as per section 11(3)(i).
Explain 'punitive indemnity' in remedies.
Additional penalty payment where appropriate, beyond compensation, as per section 11(3)(iii).
What is the purpose of prohibiting political affiliation for unions?
To keep unions focused on labour issues and independent, as per section 8(2).
Can a union require members to support a political candidate?
No, as it would violate independence from politics, as per section 8(2).
Explain the right to participate in federation elections.
Members can vote, stand for, and hold office in federations, as per section 4(3)(b) and (c).
If an employee is prejudiced for court testimony, what section applies?
Section 5(1)(b)(iii) prohibiting prejudice for participation in proceedings.
Is disability a ground for union exclusion?
No, discrimination on disability is prohibited, as per section 7(4).
What if a union expels a member for family responsibilities?
Violates non-discrimination on family responsibilities, as per section 7(4).
Can unions receive training from international bodies?
Yes, as 'other assistance' under affiliation, as per section 10.
Explain 'valid reason' in dismissal contexts.
Reasons compliant with Labour Act, not related to protected activities, as per section 5(3).
What is the role of the Labour Court in Part II?
To hear complaints and order remedies for infringements, as per section 11(1).
If no remedy is specified, what can the Court do?
Make any order necessary for compliance, including listed remedies, as per section 11(3).
Explain how section 7(3) prevents closed shops.
By voiding terms requiring union membership or non-member exclusion, as per section 7(3).
Can a union have a programme for disabled members?
Yes, as affirmative action for disadvantaged, as per section 7(5).
What if an employer sets up a company union?
Violates section 8(1) if dominated or controlled.
Are federations subject to the same rules as unions?
Yes, as extensions of unions, with similar rights, as per section 9.
Explain 'participate in activities' for federations.
Members can engage in lawful federation activities, as per section 4(3)(a).
Is threat of prejudicial action prohibited?
Yes, explicitly, as per section 5(1)(b).
Can employers have federations?
Yes, parallel to unions, as per section 9.
What is the effect of void contract terms?
They are unenforceable, protecting rights, as per section 5(2).
Explain holding office in federations.
Eligible to stand and hold if elected, as per section 4(3)(c).
Is political opinion a discrimination ground?
Yes, prohibited, as per section 7(4).
Can unions contribute to international funds?
Yes, financial contributions allowed, as per section 10.
What if the Court finds a complaint unfounded?
No order issued, but if founded, remedies apply, as per section 11(3).
Explain 'restoration of benefit' in remedies.
Reinstating any lost advantage due to infringement, as per section 11(3)(ii).
Is family responsibilities a protected ground?
Yes, against discrimination, as per section 7(4).
Can an employer sponsor union events?
If not for control, but risky under section 8(1).
What is the importance of section 4(2)(e)?
Ensures all Act rights are exercisable by members, as per section 4(2)(e).
If no consent for activities during hours, is it allowed?
No, only outside hours without consent, as per section 4(2)(a).
Explain 'subject to constitution' phrase.
Rights are conditional on union rules, balancing freedom with internal governance, recurring in section 4.
Can union demand membership for employment?
No, void under section 7(3)(ii).
What if discrimination for social origin in organisation?
Prohibited, as per section 7(4).
Explain 'other means' in section 8(1).
Any non-financial support aiming at control, beyond money, as per section 8(1).
Can federations affiliate internationally?
Yes, explicitly included, as per section 10.
What is the Labour Court's role in remedies?
To determine and order appropriate relief for infringements, as per section 11.
If employee doesn't request reinstatement, can Court order it?
No, only if requested, as per section 11(3)(i).
Explain 'compensation for damages'.
Payment for losses suffered due to infringement, as per section 11(3)(iii).
Is marital status protected?
Yes, against discrimination, as per section 7(4).
Can unions have international members?
The Act focuses on affiliation, not individual members, but constitutions may allow, per section 10.
What if prejudice for exercising other Act rights?
Prohibited, as per section 5(1)(b)(ii).
Explain section 6(3) for employer federations.
Mirrors employee federation rights for participation and office, as per section 6(3).
Is removal from office for refusal allowed?
No, if refusal of unlawful action, as per section 7(6).
Can employers form federations?
Yes, as per section 9.
What is the burden in seeking employment cases?
Employer proves non-discrimination, as per section 11(2).
Explain 'take part in formation'.
Active involvement in creating unions or federations, as per section 4(1)(a).
Is consent always needed for activities?
Only during working hours, as per section 4(2)(a).
Can members be officials in branches?
Yes, per definition, but subject to constitution, as per section 4(2)(b).
What if no provision for representatives?
No right to elect/serve, as per 'where provision is made' in section 4(2)(c)-(d).
Explain federation participation rights.
Lawful activities, elections, office-holding, as per section 4(3).
Is relinquishing membership required?
No, prohibited, as per section 5(1)(a).
What is 'prejudicial action'?
Includes disciplinary, dismissal, threats, as per section 5(1)(b).
Can benefits be promised for non-participation?
No, as per section 5(1)(c).
Are old contracts affected by void terms?
Yes, void regardless of date, as per section 5(2).
What laws govern valid dismissals?
Labour Act or other relevant laws, as per section 5(3).
Explain employer right to membership.
Subject to organisation constitution, as per section 6(1)(b).
Can employers hold office?
Yes, subject to constitution, as per section 6(2)(b).
What federation rights for employers?
Participation, elections, office, as per section 6(3).
Is payment of dues required for membership?
Yes, for remaining a member, as per section 7(1).
What if agreement excludes non-members?
Void, as per section 7(3)(i).
List prohibited discrimination grounds.
Race, colour, national extraction, social origin, religion, political opinion, sex, marital status, family responsibilities, age, disability, as per section 7(4).
What is affirmative action?
Programmes improving disadvantaged conditions, lawful, as per section 7(5).
Can penalty for unlawful refusal be imposed?
No, protected, as per section 7(6).
What is 'financial or other means' in domination?
Any support aiming at control, as per section 8(1).
Is political independence mandatory?
